the article in question were clearly sufficiently serious so a to attract the protection of article in respect of mr b reputation see paragraph and above at the same time however the final civil court judgment rendered against the applicant ordering him inter alia to pay an rsd equivalent of approximately eur for the mental anguish suffered and the cost incurred plus statutory interest can not be deemed a severe in itself particularly given that the amount awarded to mr b were never enforced against the applicant see paragraph and above also compare and contrast to tešić cited above and ε conclusion in the light of the above consideration the court is of the opinion that the civil court struck a fair balance between the applicant freedom of expression on the one hand and mr b interest in the protection of his reputation on the other and that the reason given in their judgment in this context were both relevant and sufficient furthermore the civil proceeding against the applicant were themselves concluded before the conclusion of the criminal case brought against mr b which wa why the latter could not have been of any relevance for the outcome of former see paragraph and above see also paragraph and in fine above the alleged incident giving rise to the impugned article involved allegation of a particularly serious and sensitive nature in spite of the essential role of the press in a democratic society however paragraph of article doe not guarantee a wholly unrestricted freedom of expression even with respect to press coverage of matter of serious public concern see for example bladet tromsø and stensaas v norway gc no echr iii and monnat v switzerland no echr x indeed the protection afforded by article of the convention to journalist a well a to editor by implication is subject to the proviso that they act in good faith in order to provide accurate and reliable information in accordance with the tenet of responsible journalism see for example bédat cited above in view of the foregoing there ha been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimouslydeclares the application admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on may pursuant to rule and of the rule of court stanley naismith jon fridrik kjølbro registrar president in the article professional activity had constituted aggravated murder however even if understood in a nonlegal sense the leaflet had made it understood that the applicant had conducted illegal and punishable abortion since the applicant had not clarified that he had only been criticising abortion which were according to the caselaw of the federal constitutional court see paragraph below unlawful but not subject to criminal liability he had exceeded the limit of justifiable criticism a to the claim for damage the court of appeal upheld the firstinstance judgment it also did not grant leave to appeal on point of law on may the federal court of justice refused a request by the applicant for legal aid for his complaint against the denial of leave to appeal on point of law on the ground that the applicant intended appeal on point of law lacked sufficient prospect of success on july the federal constitutional court refused to admit a complaint lodged by the applicant for adjudication for being inadmissible without providing reason no bv r ii relevant domestic law and practice the relevant domestic law and practice have been set out in the court judgment in the case annen no no september the lawalleged violation of article of the convention the applicant complained that the injunction ordering him to desist from asserting that dr s performed unlawful abortion in his medical practice had violated his freedom of expression a provided in article of the convention which read in so far a relevant a follows everyone ha the right to freedom of expression this right shall include freedom to hold opinion and to receive and impart information and idea without interference by public authority and regardless of frontier the exercise of these freedom since it carry with it duty and responsibility may be subject to such formality condition restriction or penalty a are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society for the protection of the reputation or right of others a admissibility the court note that this complaint is neither inadmissible for nonexhaustion of domestic remedy see annen v germany no november nor manifestly illfounded within the meaning of article a of the convention it further note that it is not inadmissible on any other ground it must therefore be declared admissible b merit the party submission the applicant argued that the court of appeal desist order had interfered with his freedom of expression without being justified by the protection of the personality right of dr s he submitted that his leaflet had contributed to a public debate and had not personally attacked dr s but had criticised the legal situation in germany under which abortion performed by a doctor within twelve week of conception and following obligatory counselling were considered to be unlawful but were exempt from criminal liability the use of the term aggravated murder did not have to be understood a a legal qualification of dr s professional activity but a critique of the killing of unborn child the applicant further submitted that abortion could be considered aggravated murder in a legal sense since the killing of defenseless unborn baby could be seen a malicious within the meaning of article of the criminal code in any case in the light of his contribution to a public debate of great importance possible interference with doctor personality right had to be justified the government submitted that the injunction by the court of appeal had not violated the applicant freedom of expression the court had carefully weighed the applicant freedom of expression against the right of dr s arising from article of the convention they acknowledged that the applicant had made his statement in the context of the public debate about abortion within the scope of it margin of appreciation the domestic court had come to the compelling conclusion that the statement in the leaflet distributed by the applicant had constituted such a serious violation of dr s personality right a to justify a restriction on the applicant freedom of expression the government further submitted that the domestic court had carried out an extensive analysis of the leaflet discussed various conceivable possibility of interpretation and come to the convincing conclusion that dr s had been pilloried a a supposed lawbreaker based on this conclusion it had issued an injunction which had been limited to the claim that dr s had performed unlawful abortion and had put these within the same context a aggravated murder andor expressly characterising them a infanticide the applicant had not been prohibited from taking a public and very clear stance against abortion and the court of appeal had even emphasised the applicant right protected by freedom of expression to characterise abortion a an injustice moreover he had also not been prohibited per se from personally and sharply criticising abortion provider such a dr s for their activity the court assessment at the outset the court considers and this is not in dispute between the party that the injunction interfered with the applicant freedom of expression had a legal basis and pursued the legitimate aim of protecting the right and reputation of dr s it therefore remains to be determined whether the interference wa necessary in a democratic society and whether the balancing exercise undertaken by the domestic court wa in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw the fundamental principle concerning the question of whether an interference with freedom of expression is necessary in a democratic society are well established in the court caselaw and have recently been summarised a follows see delfi a v estonia gc no june with further referencesi freedom of expression constitutes one of the essential foundation of a democratic society and one of the basic condition for it progress and for each individual selffulfilment subject to paragraph of article it is applicable not only to information or idea that are favourably received or regarded a inoffensive or a a matter of indifference but also to those that offend shock or disturb such are the demand of pluralism tolerance and broadmindedness without which there is no democratic society a set forth in article this freedom is subject to exception which must however be construed strictly and the need for any restriction must be established convincingly ii the adjective necessary within the meaning of article implies the existence of a pressing social need the contracting state have a certain margin of appreciation in assessing whether such a need exists but it go hand in hand with european supervision embracing both the legislation and the decision applying it even those given by an independent court the court is therefore empowered to give the final ruling on whether a restriction is reconcilable with freedom of expression a protected by article iii the court task in exercising it supervisory jurisdiction is not to take the place of the competent national authority but rather to review under article the decision they delivered pursuant to their power of appreciation this doe not mean that the supervision is limited to ascertaining whether the respondent state exercised it discretion reasonably carefully and in good faith what the court ha to do is to look at the interference complained of in the light of the case a a whole and determine whether it wa proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and whether the reason adduced by the national authority to justify it are relevant and sufficient in doing so the court ha to satisfy itself that the national authority applied standard which were in conformity with the principle embodied in article and moreover that they relied on an acceptable assessment of the relevant fact the court further reiterates that the right to protection of reputation is protected by article of the convention a part of the right to respect for private life see chauvy and others v france no echr vi pfeifer v austria no november and polanco torres and movilla polanco v spain no september in order for article to come into play however an attack on a person reputation must attain a certain level of seriousness and be made in a manner causing prejudice to personal enjoyment of the right to respect for private life see a v norway no april axel springer ag v germany gc no february and delfi a cited above in case that concerned allegation of criminal conduct the court also took into account that under article of the convention individual have a right to be presumed innocent of any criminal offence until proved guilty see among other authority worm v austria august report of judgment and decision v and du roy and malaurie v france no echr x when examining whether there is a need for an interference with freedom of expression in a democratic society in the interest of the protection of the reputation or right of others the court may be required to ascertain whether the domestic authority have struck a fair balance when protecting two value guaranteed by the convention which may come into conflict with each other in certain case namely on the one hand freedom of expression protected by article and on the other the right to respect for private life enshrined in article see hachette filipacchi associés v france no june mgn limited v the united kingdom no january axel springer ag cited above and delfi a cited above although opinion may differ on the outcome of a judgment where a balancing exercise wa undertaken by the national authority in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw the court would require strong reason to substitute it view for that of the domestic court see lillo stenberg and sæther v norway no january with reference to axel springer ag cited above and von hannover v germany no gc no and echr turning to the circumstance of the present case the court observes that while the regional court considered the statement to be statement of fact the court of appeal left this question open a in both case the applicant statement had not been justified it considered that while strictly speaking calling abortion unlawful wa correct the statement read in conjunction with the rest of leaflet could be understood a alleging that dr s professional activity constituted aggravated murder the court reiterates that it ha held in a previous decision see annen v germany dec no march that german law under article a of the criminal code draw a fine line between abortion which are considered to be unlawful but exempt from criminal liability and those abortion which are considered a justified and thus lawful it follows that the applicant statement that the physician performed among others unlawful abortion wa correct from a strictly judicial point of view however having regard to the fact that the applicant primarily addressed his statement to layperson the court accepts that the domestic court also took into account the point of view of a reasonable man with ordinary susceptibility who would assume that the unlawful abortion were forbidden in a stricter sense and subject to criminal liability the court considers that the present case is comparable to the case of annen v germany dec cited above a the leaflet provided no further explanation regarding the fact that doctor providing abortion were exempt from criminal liability under article a of the criminal code in contrast the applicant even reinforced the assumption that the abortion provided by dr s were subject to criminal liability by providing his own definition of aggravated murder in international law in the first leaflet and calling abortion infanticide in the second leaflet the court therefore agrees with the domestic court that when taking into account the leaflet a a whole they could be understood a alleging that dr s professional activity constituted aggravated murder this conclusion is not called into question by the court judgment in the case of annen cited above since in that case the leaflet in question had provided sufficiently clear further explanation according to which the abortion were not subject to criminal liability the court would further reiterate that while the existence of fact can be demonstrated the truth of value judgment is not susceptible of proof however even where a statement amount to a value judgment there must be a sufficient factual basis to support it failing which it will be excessive see jerusalem v austria no echr ii the court note that the applicant ha neither in the domestic proceeding nor before the court submitted any indication that dr s committed aggravated murder or that the abortion performed by him were subject to criminal liability moreover in so far a the applicant argued before the court that abortion could be considered aggravated murder within the meaning of article of the criminal code the court note that there is no evidence for that argument in domestic law or domestic caselaw in contrast article of the criminal code clearly defines abortion that are not exempted from criminal liability under article a of the criminal code in sum the court find that even assuming that the applicant statement were to be considered value judgment there wa not a sufficient factual basis for calling abortion a performed by dr s murder in that regard the court also note that these accusation were not only very serious something reflected in the fact that a conviction for aggravated murder would carry a life sentence but might also incite to hatred and aggression in regard to the seriousness of the sanction imposed on the applicant the court observes that he wa not criminally convicted for slander or ordered to pay damage contrast pedersen and baadsgaard v denmark gc no echr xi in addition the injunction wa limited in scope and only prevented the applicant from stating that dr s wa performing unlawful abortion and putting these within the same context a aggravated murder andor expressly characterising them a infanticide in that regard the court note that the applicant wa not per se prohibited from campaigning against abortion or criticising doctor that conducted abortion lastly the court note that the domestic court carried out a detailed analysis of the leaflet and discussed various possibility of interpreting the statement therein it is therefore satisfied that the legal protection received by the applicant at the domestic level wa compatible with the procedural requirement of article of the convention in these circumstance the court concludes that the injunction wa not disproportionate to the legitimate aim pursued namely the protection of the right and reputation of dr s and that the reason given by the domestic court were relevant and sufficient the interference with the applicant exercise of his right to freedom of expression could therefore reasonably be regarded by the domestic court a necessary in a democratic society there ha accordingly been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the complaint concerning article of the convention admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on september pursuant to rule and of the rule of court claudia westerdiek yonko grozev registrar president

article published on the applicant company internet news portal were of a defamatory nature indeed the applicant company promptly removed the comment once it wa notified by the injured party and internet portal did not infringe the personality right of third person wa in accordance with the guarantee set out in article of the convention in order to resolve this question the court will proceed to analyse in turn a number of factor which it considers to be of importance in the circumstance of the present case firstly the court will examine the context of the comment secondly the measure applied by the applicant company in order to prevent or remove defamatory comment thirdly the liability of the actual author of the comment a an alternative to the applicant company liability and fourthly the consequence of the domestic proceeding for the applicant company the court note that the news article published on the delfi news portal addressed a topic of a certain degree of public interest it discussed a shipping company moving it ferry from one route to another and in doing so breaking the ice at potential location of ice road a a result of which the opening of such road a article dealt with the shipping company activity that negatively affected a large number of people therefore the court considers that the applicant company by publishing the article in question could higherthanaverage risk that the negative comment could go beyond the boundary of acceptable criticism and reach the level of gratuitous insult or hate speech it also appears that the number of comment posted on the article in question wa above average and indicated a great deal of interest in the matter among the reader and those who posted their comment thus the court concludes that the applicant company wa expected to exercise a degree of caution in the circumstance of the present case in order to avoid being held liable for an infringement of other person reputation a regard the measure applied by the applicant company the court note that in addition to the disclaimer stating that the writer of the comment and not the applicant company were accountable for them and that it wa prohibited to post comment that were contrary to good practice or contained threat insult obscene expression or vulgarity the applicant company had two general mechanism in operation firstly it had an automatic system of deletion of comment based on stem of certain vulgar word secondly it had a noticeandtakedown system in place according to which anyone could notify it of an inappropriate comment comment on their own initiative thus the court considers that the applicant company can not be said to have wholly neglected it duty to avoid causing harm to third party reputation nevertheless it would appear that the automatic wordbased filter used by the applicant company wa relatively easy to circumvent although it may have prevented some of the insult or threat it failed to do so in respect of a number of others thus while there is no reason to doubt it usefulness the court considers that the wordbased filter a such wa insufficient for preventing harm being caused to third person the court ha further had regard to the noticeandtakedown system a used by the applicant company indeed the question of whether by applying this system the applicant company had fulfilled it duty of diligence wa one of the main point of disagreement between the party in the present case the court firstly note that the technical solution related to the delfi portal noticeandtakedown system wa easily accessible and convenient for user there wa no need to take any step other than clicking on a button provided for that purpose there wa no need to formulate reason a to why a comment wa considered inappropriate or to send a letter to the applicant company with the pertinent request although in the present case the interested person did not use the noticeandtakedown feature offered by the applicant company on it website but rather relied on making his claim in writing and sending it by mail this wa his own choice and in any event there is no dispute that the defamatory comment were removed by the applicant company without delay after receipt of the notice nevertheless by that time the comment had already been accessible to the public for six week the court note that in the interested person opinion shared by the domestic court the prior automatic filtering and noticeandtakedown system used by the applicant company did not ensure sufficient protection for the right of third person the domestic court attached importance in this context to the fact that the publication of the news article and making public the reader comment on these article wa part of the applicant company professional activity it wa interested in the number of reader a well a comment on which it advertising revenue depended the court considers this argument pertinent in determining the proportionality of the interference with the applicant company freedom of expression it also find that publishing defamatory comment on a large internet news portal a in the present case implies a wide audience for the comment the court further note that the applicant company and not a person whose reputation could be at stake wa in a position to know about an article to be published to predict the nature of the possible comment prompted by it and above all to take technical or manual measure to prevent defamatory statement from being made public indeed the actual writer of comment could not modify or delete their comment once posted on the delfi news portal only the applicant company had the technical mean to do this thus the court considers that the applicant company exercised a substantial degree of control over the comment published on it portal even if it did not make a much use a it could have done of the full extent of the control at it disposal the court ha also had regard to the fact that the domestic court did not make any order to the applicant company a to how the latter should ensure the protection of third party right leaving the choice to the applicant company thus no specific measure such a a requirement of prior registration of user before they were allowed to post comment monitoring comment by the applicant company before making them public or speedy review of comment after posting to name just a few were imposed on the applicant company the court considers the leeway left to the applicant company in this respect to be an important factor reducing the severity of the interference with it freedom of expression the court ha taken note of the applicant company argument that the affected person could have brought a claim against the actual author of the comment it attache more weight however to the government counterargument that for the purpose of bringing a civil claim it wa very difficult for an individual to establish the identity of the person to be sued indeed for purely technical reason it would appear disproportionate to put the onus of identification of the author of defamatory comment on the injured person in a case like the present one keeping in mind the state positive obligation under article that may involve the adoption of measure designed to secure respect for private life in the sphere of the relation of individual between themselves see von hannover no cited above with further reference the court is not convinced that measure allowing an injured party to bring a claim only against the author of defamatory comment a the applicant company appears to suggest would have in the present case guaranteed effective protection of the injured person right to private life it note that it wa the applicant company choice to allow comment by nonregistered user and that by doing so it must be considered to have assumed a certain responsibility for these comment the court is mindful in this context of the importance of the wish of internet user not to disclose their identity in exercising their freedom of expression at the same time the spread of the internet and the possibility or for some purpose the danger that information once made public will remain public and circulate forever call for caution the ease of disclosure of information on the internet and the substantial amount of information there mean that it is a difficult task to detect defamatory statement and remove them this is so for an internet news portal operator a in the present case but this is an even more onerous task for a potentially injured person who would be le likely to posse resource for continual monitoring of the internet the court considers the latter element an important factor in balancing the right and interest at stake it also refers in this context to the krone verlag no judgment where it found that shifting the defamed person risk to obtain redress for defamation proceeding to the medium company usually in a better financial position than the defamer wa not a such a disproportionate interference with the medium company right to freedom of expression see krone verlag gmb h co kg v austria no no november lastly the court note that the applicant company wa obliged to pay the affected person the equivalent of eur in nonpecuniary damage the court is of the opinion that this sum also taking into account that the applicant company wa a professional operator of one of the largest internet news portal in estonia can by no mean be considered disproportionate to the breach established by the domestic court based on the above element in particular the insulting and threatening nature of the comment the fact that the comment were posted in reaction to an article published by the applicant company in it professionallymanaged news portal run on a commercial basis the insufficiency of the measure taken by the applicant company to avoid damage being caused to other party reputation and to ensure a realistic possibility that the author of the comment will be held liable and the moderate sanction imposed on the applicant company the court considers that in the present case the domestic court finding that the applicant company wa liable for the defamatory comment posted by reader on it internet news portal wa a justified and proportionate restriction on the applicant company right to freedom of expression there ha accordingly been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the application admissible hold convention which may come into conflict with each other in certain case namely on the one hand freedom of expression a protected by article and on the other the right to respect for private life a right to respect for private life including whether the impugned statement contributed to a debate of public interest the degree of notoriety of the person affected and the subject of the publication it veracity and the nature and severity of the penalty imposed see among many other authority ibid and von hannover cited above a distinction ha to be made between private individual and individual acting in a public context accordingly whilst a private individual unknown to the public may claim particular protection of his or her right to private life the same is not true of public figure in political issue see among many other authority lingens v austria july series a no β principle relevant to the content form and consequence of the publication the court draw a distinction between statement of fact and value judgment the existence of fact can be demonstrated whereas the truth of value judgment is not susceptible of proof the requirement to prove the truth of a value judgment is impossible to fulfil and infringes freedom of opinion itself however where a statement amount to a value judgment the proportionality of an interference may depend on whether there exists a sufficient factual basis for the impugned statement see among many other authority morice cited above a regard value judgment which have been found by the national court to be of a defamatory character the court ass the national court finding on the question whether the language used in the statement wa of an excessive or dispassionate nature whether any intention of defaming or stigmatising the opponent wa must be established convincingly see among many other authority janowski v poland gc no echr i nilsen and johnsen v norway gc no echr viii the test of necessity in a democratic society requires the court to determine whether the interference complained of corresponded to a pressing social need the contracting state have a certain margin of appreciation in assessing whether such a need exists but it go hand in hand with european supervision embracing both the legislation and the decision applying it even those delivered by an independent court the court is therefore empowered to deliver the final ruling on whether a restriction is reconcilable with freedom of expression a protected by article see among many other authority perna v italy gc no echr v and cumpǎnǎ and mazǎre v romania gc no echr xi the court task in exercising it supervisory function is not to take the place of the competent domestic court but rather to review under article the decision they have taken pursuant to their power of appreciation see fressoz and roire v france gc no echr i this doe not mean that the supervision is limited to ascertaining whether or not the respondent state exercised it discretion reasonably carefully or in good faith what the court ha to do is to look at the interference complained of in the light of the case a a whole including the content of the comment held against the applicant and the context in which he made them see news verlags gmb h co kg v austria no echr i in particular the court must determine whether the reason adduced by the national authority to justify the interference were relevant and sufficient and whether the measure taken were proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued see chauvy and others v france no echr vi in doing so the court ha to satisfy itself that the national authority basing themselves on an acceptable assessment of the relevant fact applied standard which were in conformity with the principle embodied in article see among many other authority zana v turkey judgment of november report of judgment and decision vii pp in addition the fairness of the proceeding the procedural guarantee afforded see mutatis mutandis steel and morris v the united kingdom no echr and the nature and severity of the penalty imposed see ceylan v turkey gc no echr iv and skałka v poland no may are factor to be taken into account when assessing the proportionality of an interference with the freedom of expression guaranteed by article see kyprianou v cyprus gc no echr furthermore the court reiterates that in it practice it ha distinguished between statement of fact and value judgement while the existence of fact can be demonstrated the truth of value judgement is not susceptible of proof where a statement amount to a value judgement the proportionality of an interference may depend on whether there exists a sufficient factual basis for the impugned statement since even a value judgement without any factual basis to support it may be excessive see de haes and gijsels v belgium judgment of february report i p and feldek v slovakia no echr viii the court further observes that there is little scope under article of the convention for restriction on political speech or on debate concerning question of public interest see sürek v turkey no gc no echr ivb application of the above principle to the present case in exercising it supervisory jurisdiction the court must look at the impugned interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression in the light of the case a a whole including the content of the statement concerned the context in which they were made and also the particular circumstance of those involved in the instant case the press conference organised by the applicant on october wa his reply to a series of article published earlier in october alleging that he had sexually abused student when working a a teacher see paragraph and above moreover the statement he made in the rzeczpospolita daily of october november were his comment in response to allegation broadcast on the tvn television channel that he had been convicted in the past for having assaulted a woman see paragraph above the court therefore accepts that the applicant wa defending himself against allegation published in the medium in which he wa accused of having committed criminal offence the court note further that in statement made at the press conference and also published in rzeczpospolita the applicant referred to a plot and accused the journalist of taking part in blackmail and writing defamatory article for money see paragraph and above the firstinstance court made a distinction between the press conference and the rzeczpospolita article and found that an infringement of the plaintiff personal right could be attributable to the applicant only a regard the allegation he made in rzeczpospolita the secondinstance court however having examined what wa said during the press conference and assessed the applicant allegation in the light of statement he made earlier at the same conference considered that the statement made at the press conference had also infringed the plaintiff personal right see paragraph and above a regard the categorisation of the applicant statement the court observes that the polish court classified them a statement of fact rather than value judgment and accepts this classification indeed the allegation that there wa blackmail which we were subjected to today we already know which journalist cooperated and with whom in order to obtain money from u under false pretence or those journalist cooperated with the informer who supplied the information on the basis of which the whole matter wa disseminated and today they are being paid for that do amount to statement of fact which are susceptible of proof in this respect the court note that the domestic court examined the circumstance of the case and found that the applicant had failed to prove the veracity of his assertion either at the time of their publication or thereafter in the course of the civil proceeding moreover he wa not table to provide any evidence in support of his statement see paragraph above the court further note that the domestic court recognised the applicant right to freedom of expression however they found that this freedom could not overstep the limit of permissible criticism and did not permit the making of unfounded public statement infringing the personal right of others see paragraph above the court considers that the domestic court thereby recognised that the present case involved a conflict between the right to freedom of expression and the protection of the reputation and right of others and thus carried out the appropriate balancing exercise see mutatis mutandis keller v hungary dec no april cumpǎnǎ and mazǎre v romania cited above von hannover v germany no gc no and echr and axel springer ag v germany gc no february having regard to the above and to the nature of the statement made by the applicant the court see no reason to depart from the domestic court finding that the applicant lacked a sufficient factual basis for the allegation that the newspaper super express and it former editorinchief had been involved in a plot against him and had prepared defamatory article in return for money from their informer the national authority were thus entitled to take the view that there wa a pressing social need to take action under the applicable law in relation to that allegation a regard the fairness of the proceeding and the procedural guarantee afforded the court note that there is nothing in the casefile which would suggest that the rule governing a fair trial were not respected in the present case the applicant wa questioned in person at a hearing and in particular had a chance to defend himself and to present evidence in support of his allegation see paragraph above his case wa examined on the merit by court at two instance and their judgment contain exhaustive and meticulous explanation setting out the reasoning behind their decision the court reiterates that the nature and severity of the sanction imposed are also factor to be taken into account when assessing the proportionality of the interference under article of the convention see paragraph above in the instant case the applicant wa sued before the civil court and ordered to publish apology addressed to both plaintiff in the rzeczpospolita daily and on the tvn television channel the court admit that publication of apology on a tv channel must have entailed considerable cost for the applicant see paragraph above it note however that the domestic court directed that the apology should be published in the same mass medium in which the defamatory statement had been made by the applicant see paragraph above and that the regional court dismissed a further request from the plaintiff that the apology be published in several other press title see paragraph above it follows that the publication order corresponded to the scope of the publication of the defamatory statement and that the burden imposed on the applicant wa mitigated by the second instance court the court considers therefore that the manner of publication of the apology did not exceed the margin of discretion accorded to the domestic court having regard to the foregoing the court considers that the domestic court finding against the applicant and the sanction imposed on him were not disproportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and that the reason provided by the domestic court justifying those measure were relevant and sufficient the interference with the applicant exercise of his right to freedom of expression could therefore reasonably be regarded by the national authority a necessary in a democratic society for the protection of the reputation and right of others it follows that there ha been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the complaint under article of the convention admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified and the applicant had an obligation to include it in his application form the court could simply have rejected the application a noncompliant with rule of the rule of court if it had known about this application without recourse to any other document this provision refers to the scope of the application and it is to be underlined here that the judgment in paragraph note that the information the applicant received and failed to disclose to the court wa in fact on the scope of the foreign intelligence service file on ub the reason for their creation and their content an important provision of the proposed finding of an abuse of the right of individual application is the result of the best interpretation and application of the provision of article a to the fact of the present case by following the principle of effectiveness a a norm of international law and a a method of interpretation again in my humble view the finding of the judgment that there ha been no abuse of individual application lack any factual and legal basis and defeat the very purpose of article a iv conclusion in the light of all the above i would have rejected the application based on article of the convention for being inadmissible due to an abuse of the right of individual application and this is something that the court might have done under the said provision at any stage of the proceeding but regrettably did not do so dissenting opinion of judge pavlijoined by judge ravarani and zünd i have voted against the finding of no violation of article in this case apart from the difference of opinion on the outcome my disagreement with the majority extends to certain key finding of fact a well a the methodology that ha been followed to reach this conclusion which risk muddying the water of our developing jurisprudence in this relatively novel field first it is necessary to start with an important factual clarification the respondent government have put forward the misleading argument that the applicant wa not denied access to the desired information and he did not argue that the information disclosed to him wa incorrect or insufficient see paragraph of the judgment i am unable to agree with this submission the applicant requested access to thousand of page of primary source information collected by the german intelligence service in relation to the suspicious death of a senior government official several decade ago what he received from the intelligence service a a result of an outofcourt settlement wa merely a highlevel description of the category of information that the relevant file contained see paragraph of the judgment while such information may be quite useful in certain circumstance perhaps a a preliminary step in narrowing down a wideranging request it is simply not what the applicant asked for it is the equivalent of requesting to read a book and being offered it table of content a a perfectly good alternative the applicant ha never received access to a single page from the original file unfortunately the majority have chosen to gloss over this crucial distinction and to accept that the applicant information request wa satisfied at least in part see paragraph of the judgment this fallacy lay the ground for much of the majority reasoning a second steppingstone to the finding of no violation of article is the majority reluctance to hold that the threshold condition for the applicability of article were clearly met in this case the question of applicability is first joined to the merit see paragraph of the judgment and then ultimately left open presumably on the basis that article doe not necessarily grant a right of physical access to government file see paragraph of the judgment this conclusion is based in my view on a significant misunderstanding of both our existing jurisprudence and the way virtually all access to information regime operate in the european space to begin with the majority timidity would seem to suggest that this is the first time the court ha been faced with such a question a this is not the case in my view there wa no need to question or cast doubt on a wellestablished element of our article caselaw a large number of access to information case decided by various section of the court following the grand chamber groundbreaking magyar helsinki judgment magyar helsinki bizottság v hungary gc no november have dealt specifically with request by applicant for access to original document ie primarysource information held by state authority in none of these case ha it been disputed neither by the respondent government nor by the court that article applies in principle to such request this being a question of the court ratione materiae jurisdiction it ought to have been considered in any event of the court own motion a a result it seems obvious to conclude that the court ha long accepted expressly or implicitly that a right of access to the original file or document held by a government authority is protected in principle by article the majority have chosen to ignore this line of caselaw furthermore the majority approach is at odds with a core and widely accepted conception of the right to information in european comparative law a well a under council of europe standardsetting instrument the primary form of access guaranteed by these law including the german federal access law itself is direct access to primary official document and source irrespective of their format whether a an original complete and authentic paper copy electronic copy and so on this is also a matter of common sense any serious journalist or researcher would want to see the original government data not merely information about the information the metadata or a governmentprepared summary of the requested information the fundamental guarantee of article do not rest on the assumption that the government version of event is always to be trusted any researcher who ha spent time leafing through dusty old record in government archive would testify to that the practice is older than the lost library of alexandria the court itself ha emphasised in a national security context that access to original documentary source for legitimate historical research is an essential element of the exercise of the right to freedom of expression see kenedi v hungary no may thirdly the majority find that article ha not been violated despite the national court manifest failure to engage in any meaningful balancing of the applicant article interest in obtaining access to the original file in whole or in part against any ongoing national security interest in preserving their secrecy the judgment doe so by relying on the applicant supposed failure to sufficiently justify before the domestic authority the need for physical access a such an omission that presumably failed to put the domestic authority in a position to engage in the necessary balancing of the competing interest see paragraph of the judgment in other word the majority like the national court wonder why the applicant could not have been satisfied with having received the table of content rather than the whole book while investigating a complex set of event related to a death under disputed circumstance that had attracted a great deal of public interest in fact this core question is tied to a structural problem in the german access to information regime the intelligence service being entirely exempted from the scope of federal access to information law the only option left to journalist and to journalist exclusively for requesting access to their information is to rely on a complex mix of judgemade constitutional remedy andor landbased legislation the applicant case suggests however that these remedy are imperfect and subject to a high substantive threshold and burden of proof to be met by the requester the right of the press to receive information may consolidate to become a right to consult file in person under certain undefined scenario see paragraph of the judgment these national threshold are arguably stricter and therefore incompatible with the fourfactor threshold set by the court grand chamber in magyar helsinki cited above for article to become applicable the lack of a generalised constitutional basis for the right of access to official information at the german federal level such that it would be commensurate with the level of protection guaranteed by article of the convention is another source of complication this idiosyncratic national legal framework a applicable to the intelligence service in this particular case is hardly compatible with our own established jurisprudence an aspect that the judgment doe not address any national legal framework that shield or exempts entire government agency from the operation of the right of access to government information or that categorically bar requester from access to certain primary source in the absence of any balancing of interest is bound to run into similar convention problem in my view nothing in this separate opinion should be taken of course to suggest that people should be able to roam freely through the intelligence agency archive on the other hand a national security data about historical event of general importance become older or liable to be declassified the interest of historical research and the public right to know become stronger and may tip the balance in favour of disclosure in whole or in part see kenedi cited above involving access to historical record of the hungarian secret service established democracy have developed multiple mechanism to do this without undermining the internal working method or source of the service or other remaining national security concern redaction and partial disclosure being among these standard tool in line with the principle of proportionality had the national authority put forward sound substantive reason a to why national security would have been seriously jeopardised by granting the applicant any degree of access to the physical file and had the national court scrutinised such argument in line with article standard the refusal of physical access in whole or in part might be considered justified conversely the failure of the domestic authority to engage in any meaningful balancing of the substantive interest at stake is sufficient in my view to find a violation of article in this case the majority strictly procedural approach mean that the court itself ha also missed an opportunity to enrich our jurisprudence on question of historical memory in a national security context see among other case cangi v turkey no january studio monitori and others v georgia dec no and january centre for democracy and the rule of law v ukraine dec no march centre for democracy and the rule of law v ukraine no march and leshchenko v ukraine no and january the fact that the relevant article complaint may have been found inadmissible on other ground or with respect to the specific nature of the information being requested see eg studio monitori cited above doe not change this general conclusion see in particular the committee of minister recommendation on access to official document and it explanatory memorandum paragraph and including with reference to confidential secret or top secret the applicant wa born in and life in weinheim he is a campaigner against abortion and operates an antiabortion website on and april the applicant distributed leaflet in the vicinity of the medical practice of dr st who performed abortion there the leaflet stated inter alia that the abortion performed by dr st in his practice for which he gave the address were unlawful according to the caselaw of the federal constitutional court in addition the leaflet contained the following statement according to international criminal law aggravated murder is the intentional bringingtodeath of an innocent human being sinngemӓβ au den internationalen strafgesetzen mord ist da vorsӓtzliche zu tode bringen eines unschuldigen menschen the murder of human being in auschwitz wa unlawful but the morally degraded n state allowed the murder of innocent people and did not make it subject to criminal liability die ermordung der menschen in auschwitz war rechtswidrig aber der moralisch verkommene nsstaat hatte den mord an den unschuldigen menschen erlaubt und nicht unter strafe gestellt the applicant also addressed passersby and the physician presumed patient and attempted to engage with them in conversation about abortion dr st lodged an application for a civil injunction against the applicant and on october the mannheim regional court granted the requested injunction the court ordered the applicant to desist from speaking to passersby in the immediate vicinity of the medical practice and labelling the abortion performed by the plaintiff unlawful with the objective of irritating female patient and preventing them from visiting dr sts practice on february the karlsruhe court of appeal upheld the decision and slightly modified the wording specifying the geographical area concerned by the injunction it also refused to grant leave to appeal on point of law the regional court a well a the court of appeal both referred to a previous decision of the federal court of justice in which it had confirmed a civil injunction against similar conduct by the applicant see paragraph below the court held that in the case at issue there were no factual or legal difference justifying deviating from the caselaw of the federal court of justice in so far that the doctor in the present case wa slightly more wellknown than the doctor in the original case the court of appeal held that this wa of minor relevance the fact that dr st had appeared a an expert before the german parliament many year previously did not have any substantial effect on dr sts public profile at that time moreover the involvement of dr st in different legal dispute wa irrelevant a trying to enforce his right in the appropriate legal procedure could not redound to dr sts disadvantage in sum the applicant had vilified the noncriminal professional activity of dr st by implying that he committed criminal act and interfered with the relationship of trust between doctor and patient which deserved special protection against the intervention of others the applicant had therefore severely interfered with dr sts personality right this interference wa not justified by the applicant freedom of expression in view of the massive pillory effect the applicant had created by singling out the plaintiff and criticising him in a harsh way in the immediate vicinity of his practice on may the federal court of justice refused a request by the applicant for legal aid on the ground that the applicant intended appeal on point of law lacked sufficient prospect of success on july the federal constitutional court refused to admit the applicant complaint for adjudication for being inadmissible without providing reason no bv r ii relevant domestic law and practice the relevant provision of the german basic law grundgesetz criminal code strafgesetzbuch and civil code bürgerliches gesetzbuch have been set out in the court judgment in annen no no september in addition on december the federal court of justice confirmed an injunction ordering the applicant to desist from addressing patient and passersby in a specified area in front of a medical practice and from pointing out that in the practice abortion were performed no vi zr it pointed out that the doctor activity were legal and enjoyed protection under his constitutional right to freedom to exercise his profession the court emphasised the important role which the legislature had attributed to gynaecologist both in the protection of unborn life and in the protection of the health of the woman concerned it wa essential that the relationship of trust between the doctor and his patient wa not disturbed by the intrusion of external party the applicant action had adversely affected the plaintiff activity in an unacceptable way and had singled him out without any reason therefore the court concluded that under the circumstance of this particular case the physician personality right prevailed over the applicant freedom of expression a constitutional complaint against the judgment of the federal court of justice wa not admitted for adjudication the lawalleged violation of article of the convention the applicant complained that the injunction ordering him to desist from addressing passersby in the immediate vicinity of dr sts medical practice and from labelling the abortion performed by the plaintiff unlawful had violated his freedom of expression a provided in article of the convention which read in so far a relevant a follows everyone ha the right to freedom of expression this right shall include freedom to hold opinion and to receive and impart information and idea without interference by public authority and regardless of frontier the exercise of these freedom since it carry with it duty and responsibility may be subject to such formality condition restriction or penalty a are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society for the protection of the reputation or right of others a admissibility the court note that this complaint is neither inadmissible for nonexhaustion of domestic remedy see annen v germany no november nor manifestly illfounded within the meaning of article a of the convention it further note that it is not inadmissible on any other ground it must therefore be declared admissible b merit the party submission the applicant argued that the desist order had interfered with his freedom of expression without being justified by the protection of the personality right of dr st he submitted that his distribution of leaflet and the intended conversation with passersby had contributed to a public debate of great importance his action had not personally attacked dr st but had criticised the legal situation in germany concerning abortion which had been performed by a doctor within twelve week of conception and following obligatory counseling those abortion had been considered to be unlawful but had been exempt from criminal liability moreover it had been consistent with the caselaw of the federal constitutional court to call abortion a performed by dr st unlawful the applicant further submitted that the domestic court had not sufficiently taken into account that dr st had not been unknown to the public a the doctor had been in the earlier case decided by the federal court of justice but had appeared a an expert before the german parliament and had been involved in several legal dispute in the context of the debate about abortion the government submitted that the interference with the applicant freedom of expression which had been based on article in conjunction with article of the civil code had been necessary to safeguard dr sts personality right a enshrined in article of the convention by calling abortion unlawful the applicant had created the false impression that dr st had been operating outside of the legal framework in performing such procedure unlike the leaflet in the case of annen cited above the leaflet in the present case did not point out that abortion are permitted in germany under the term of article a of the criminal code and therefore not subject to criminal liability moreover given the applicant goal of forced pavement counselling the applicant had severely disturbed the relationship of trust between doctor and patient the court had already rejected an earlier application by the same applicant against a desist order against similar conduct see annen v germany dec no march in the present case the domestic court had relied on the judgment of the federal court of justice which had been the subject matter of the earlier inadmissibility decision of the court and concluded that the circumstance had been comparable and had not warranted deviating from the existing caselaw when coming to that conclusion the domestic court had paid attention to the fact that dr st had taken a public position in the abortion debate the court assessment at the outset the court considers and this is not in dispute between the party that the injunction interfered with the applicant freedom of expression had a legal basis and pursued the legitimate aim of protecting the right and reputation of dr st a well a the right of patient to medical counseling it therefore remains to be determined whether the interference wa necessary in a democratic society and whether the balancing exercise undertaken by the domestic court wa in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw the fundamental principle concerning the question of whether an interference with freedom of expression is necessary in a democratic society are well established in the court caselaw and have recently been summarised a follows see delfi a v estonia gc no june with further referencesi freedom of expression constitutes one of the essential foundation of a democratic society and one of the basic condition for it progress and for each individual selffulfilment subject to paragraph of article it is applicable not only to information or idea that are favourably received or regarded a inoffensive or a a matter of indifference but also to those that offend shock or disturb such are the demand of pluralism tolerance and broadmindedness without which there is no democratic society a set forth in article this freedom is subject to exception which must however be construed strictly and the need for any restriction must be established convincingly ii the adjective necessary within the meaning of article implies the existence of a pressing social need the contracting state have a certain margin of appreciation in assessing whether such a need exists but it go hand in hand with european supervision embracing both the legislation and the decision applying it even those given by an independent court the court is therefore empowered to give the final ruling on whether a restriction is reconcilable with freedom of expression a protected by article iii the court task in exercising it supervisory jurisdiction is not to take the place of the competent national authority but rather to review under article the decision they delivered pursuant to their power of appreciation this doe not mean that the supervision is limited to ascertaining whether the respondent state exercised it discretion reasonably carefully and in good faith what the court ha to do is to look at the interference complained of in the light of the case a a whole and determine whether it wa proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and whether the reason adduced by the national authority to justify it are relevant and sufficient in doing so the court ha to satisfy itself that the national authority applied standard which were in conformity with the principle embodied in article and moreover that they relied on an acceptable assessment of the relevant fact the court further reiterates that the right to protection of reputation is protected by article of the convention a part of the right to respect for private life see chauvy and others v france no echr vi pfeifer v austria no november and polanco torres and movilla polanco v spain no september in order for article to come into play however an attack on a person reputation must attain a certain level of seriousness and be made in a manner causing prejudice to personal enjoyment of the right to respect for private life see a v norway no april axel springer ag v germany gc no february and delfi a cited above in case that concerned allegation of criminal conduct the court also took into account that under article of the convention individual have a right to be presumed innocent of any criminal offence until proved guilty see among other authority worm v austria august report of judgment and decision v and du roy and malaurie v france no echr x when examining whether there is a need for an interference with freedom of expression in a democratic society in the interest of the protection of the reputation or right of others the court may be required to ascertain whether the domestic authority have struck a fair balance when protecting two value guaranteed by the convention which may come into conflict with each other in certain case namely on the one hand freedom of expression protected by article and on the other the right to respect for private life enshrined in article see hachette filipacchi associés v france no june mgn limited v the united kingdom no january axel springer ag cited above and delfi a cited above turning to the circumstance of the present case the court observes that the domestic court justified the injunction by in essence three point that interfered with the doctor private and professional life and taken together reached a severity that dr st should not have had to endure firstly the applicant had vilified dr st by implying that he had committed criminal act secondly he had singled out dr st from all doctor that had performed abortion and had thereby created a pillory effect and lastly the applicant had interfered with the particularly protected relationship of trust between dr st and his patient in regard to the first aspect the court reiterates that it ha held in a previous decision see annen v germany dec no march that german law under article a of the criminal code draw a fine line between abortion which are considered to be unlawful but exempt from criminal liability and those abortion which are considered a justified and thus lawful it follows that the applicant statement that the physician performed among others unlawful abortion wa correct from a strictly judicial point of view however having regard to the fact that the applicant primarily addressed his statement to layperson the court accepts that the domestic court also took into account the point of view of a reasonable man with ordinary susceptibility who would assume that the unlawful abortion were forbidden in a stricter sense and subject to criminal liability this conclusion is not called into question by the court later judgment in the case of annen cited above since in that case the leaflet in question provided sufficiently clear further explanation according to which abortion were not subject to criminal liability the court therefore agrees with the conclusion of the domestic court regarding the first aspect concerning the issue of singling out dr st the court note that the applicant submitted that the former had been known to the public had appeared a an expert before the german parliament and had been involved in several legal dispute in the context of the debate about abortion however the court also take note of the fact that the domestic court considered these point and concluded that they were only of minor relevance the appearance before the german parliament had been many year previous to that time and therefore did not have any substantial effect on dr sts public profile the involvement of dr st in different legal dispute wa irrelevant a trying to enforce his right in the appropriate legal procedure could not redound to dr sts disadvantage the court would reiterate that a distinction ha to be made between private individual and person acting in a public context a political figure or public figure and that a private individual unknown to the public may claim particular protection of his or her right to private life see axel springer ag v germany gc no february with further reference nonetheless having regard to their direct and continuous contact with their society it is primarily for the domestic court to ass how well known a person is especially where that person is mainly known at national level ibid in conclusion the court find the domestic court reasoning that dr sts prior conduct had only minor relevance for the present assessment acceptable and see no reason to call the court conclusion concerning how well known dr st wa into question turning to the issue of the applicant interfering with the relationship of trust between dr st and his patient the court reiterates that it ha already accepted that a civil injunction wa in particular based on the fact that the applicant approached the doctor patient in the direct vicinity of his medical practice and thus seriously disturbed the exercise of his professional activity see annen v germany dec cited above the court observes that such pavement counselling by the applicant which the regional court described a running the gauntlet did not only interfere with the dr sts legal professional activity but also rendered it more difficult for patient to seek medical assistance the court therefore see no reason to deviate from it previous finding in the present case the foregoing consideration are sufficient to enable the court to conclude that the reason advanced for the interference complained of were relevant and sufficient furthermore the court observes that the applicant wa not criminally convicted for slander or ordered to pay damage contrast pedersen and baadsgaard v denmark gc no echr xi but only prevented from addressing passersby in the immediate vicinity of dr sts medical practice and from labelling the abortion performed by the plaintiff unlawful consequently the injunction wa limited geographically and in scope in regard to the latter the court note that the applicant wa not per se prohibited from campaigning against abortion criticising doctor that conducted abortion or distributing leaflet in sum the court concludes that the level of interference with the applicant freedom of expression wa relatively low and proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued lastly concerning the thoroughness of assessing the conflicting interest by the domestic court the court observes that they in essence referred to the previous judgment of the federal court see paragraph above and assessed whether the present case required deviating from the existing caselaw in case where the balancing exercise between the right to freedom of expression and personality right had already been thoroughly undertaken in a comparable case the court see no problem with referring to the respective judgment and to merely consider the factual and legal difference of the case the court therefore considers that the domestic court thoroughly assessed the conflicting interest there ha accordingly been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the complaint concerning article admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on september pursuant to rule and of the rule of court claudia westerdiek yonko grozev registrar president
