in the partition procedure the second contained consideration on behaviour from which judge should refrain and it consequence in the court view even though the second part of the letter wa drafted in the form of general consideration it can be interpreted only a a criticism of the conduct of the judge x who without being expressly mentioned is the protagonist in the account which constituted the premise of the applicant observation and assessment in those circumstance the court share the finding of the district court and the genoa court of appeal see paragraph and above according to which x wa certainly the subject of the grievance set out in the circular letter it remains to be determined whether the remark in question overstepped the bound of admissible criticism in a democratic society it can be seen from the text of the circular letter see paragraph above that in substance the applicant reproached x on two account a for taking unfair and arbitrary decision and b for being a biased judge and for having wilfully made mistake by malicious intent serious misconduct or negligence in the court view the first criticism amount to a value judgment a to the nature and legal basis of the decision taken by x a indicated in paragraph above according to the court caselaw the truth of such opinion is not susceptible of proof moreover they had a certain factual basis in particular the applicant had been the representative of one of the party to judicial proceeding for the partition of an inheritance in the context of those proceeding the applicant had on a number of occasion sought to have the sale of a flat suspended and his request had been dismissed by x on the basis of reasoning which according to the applicant subjective opinion wa erroneous and contrary to the law the court therefore can not consider the first criticism to be excessive see mutatis mutandis morice cited above where the court found that criticism made by the lawyer acting for the civil party about the conduct of the investigating judge during the judicial investigation were value judgment with a sufficient factual basis the same can not be said however when it come to the second criticism namely that x wa a biased judge who had wilfully made mistake by malicious intent serious misconduct or negligence this criticism implied that x had disregarded the ethical obligation inherent in the duty of a judge or even that she had committed a criminal offence the adoption by a judge of a deliberately erroneous decision could constitute an abuse of authority in any event the circular letter alleged that x did not have the quality of impartiality independence or objectivity quality which characterise the exercise of judicial activity however the applicant never sought to prove the veracity of the conduct attributed to x and adduced no evidence to show any malicious intent in the decision that he contested in the court view his allegation of misconduct on the part of x were based only on the fact that the judge had dismissed the claim he had submitted in the interest of his client contrast morice cited above it is also noteworthy that the applicant who had referred a complaint against judge x see paragraph above sent out his circular letter without waiting for the outcome of the csm proceeding in defending himself before the domestic court the applicant merely argued that his criticism had not been directed at x in person see mutatis mutandis perna cited above and fuchs decision cited above see also by contrast nikula cited above where the court observed that the applicant criticism had only concerned the manner in which a public prosecutor had discharged his duty in a given court case and not any professional or other quality of the prosecutor in question the court however ha already dismissed that argument see paragraph above the court also take account of the context in which the circular letter wa written and distributed in this connection it would first note that the applicant criticism were not made at the hearing or in the course of the judicial proceeding for the partition of an inheritance in that sense the present case can be distinguished from nikula cited above see in particular paragraph where the court found a violation of article of the convention the court further observes that outside the judicial procedure the applicant sent his circular letter to x in person see paragraph above and to many other judge at the lucca district court see paragraph above a the genoa court of appeal rightly observed see paragraph above the distribution of the letter within a small community such a that of a local court would inevitably harm the reputation and professional image of the judge concerned lastly the court note that while it is true that at first instance the applicant wa given a custodial sentence without the benefit of mitigating circumstance in view of his clean criminal record that sanction wa replaced on appeal by a small fine of eur which moreover wa declared fully discharged see paragraph above in addition that mitigation wa applied by the judge at second instance see paragraph above and the amount of the compensation awarded to x eur can not be regarded a excessive the court would further observe that in case such a the present one which call for a fair balance to be struck between the right to respect for private life and the right to freedom of expression it take the view that the adjudication of the application should not in principle vary depending on whether it ha been lodged under article by the person criticised or under article by the author of the criticism the two right merit in principle equal respect see hachette filipacchi associés ici paris v france no july timciuc v romania dec no october and mosley v the united kingdom no may accordingly the margin of appreciation should in principle be the same in both case if the striking of a balance by the domestic court is consistent with the criterion established by the court caselaw the court would require strong reason to substitute it view for that of the domestic court see palomo sánchez and others v spain gc no and echr and mgn limited v the united kingdom no and january in the court view there are no such reason in the present case see mutatis mutandis di giovanni cited above having regard to the foregoing the court find that the applicant conviction for the defamatory remark contained in the circular letter and the sanction imposed on him were not disproportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and that the ground given by the national court were relevant and sufficient for the purpose of justifying those measure the interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression wa necessary in a democratic society in order to protect the reputation of others and to maintain the authority and impartiality of the judiciary within the meaning of article it follows that there ha been no violation of article for these reason the court declares unanimously the application admissible hold by five vote to two that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in french and notified in writing on june pursuant to rule and of the rule of court françoise elens passos päivi hirveläregistrar president in accordance with article of the convention and rule of the rule of court the joint separate opinion of judge wojtyczek and grozev is annexed to this judgment phfep joint dissenting opinion of judge wojtyczek and grozevtranslation we can not agree with the view expressed by the majority that there ha been no violation of article of the convention in the present case the applicant submitted his complaint alleging a violation of his freedom of expression in the context of a conflict between the right of two individual namely between his own freedom of expression and the right of another person to the protection of his reputation moreover the majority have emphasised the fact that the interference with the applicant freedom of expression sought to maintain the authority and impartiality of the judiciary of which x wa a member there is no doubt that the need to protect the reputation of others justifies certain restriction on freedom of expression a person reputation must be protected effectively and any damage caused to it must entail a sanction in situation of conflict between right the national authority must carefully weigh up the right in question and seek solution whereby the right are upheld to the highest degree possible in any event a the majority have observed any interference with a right must always be justified by relevant and serious reason and remain proportionate to the aim pursued in it caselaw the court ha identified a certain number of factor which must be analysed in order to determine whether a restriction on freedom of expression is justified see in particular von hannover v germany no gc no and echr and axel springer ag v germany gc no february among these factor can be mentioned in particular the question whether the remark in question contribute to a public debate the content form and consequence of the remark the conduct of the person affected and the severity of the sanction imposed in the present case the reasoning of the judicial decision delivered in italy appears not to have taken those various factor into account the italian court confined themselves to establishing that the applicant had actually made the offending remark that those remark had been disseminated among the judge of the court in question and that they were directed at a particular judge in that court they further took the view that the remark had overstepped the permissible limit but no analysis of the relevant circumstance a identified in the court caselaw wa carried out the methodology applied by the domestic court doe not meet the requirement of article of the convention a interpreted by the court in particular the reason given by the national court can not be regarded a satisfactory in term of the requirement to give relevant and serious reason in order to justify any interference with the right to freedom of expression in assessing restriction on freedom of expression it is necessary to pay particular attention to the content of the impugned remark and especially to consider whether the person concerned wa mentioned by name and whether any conduct likely to damage his or her reputation wa clearly attributed to that person while a false insinuation may have extremely serious consequence for the reputation of the individual concerned the fact that he or she is not expressly named may nevertheless in certain situation limit the effect of the remark in examining the compatibility of an interference with the requirement of article of the convention it is also necessary to determine the actual consequence of the remark to that end one must take account of the type of readership or audience for which the remark are intended and in particular the number and profession of the addressee we observe that the domestic court did not take these factor into consideration even though they were crucial for the examination of the case we also regret that the majority paid no heed to these question we would observe that in the present case the applicant decided not to mention the judge expressly by name leaving a certain ambiguity about the identity of the person concerned moreover the conduct imputed to judge x wa presented a follows wilfully making mistake by malicious intent serious misconduct or negligence the remark combined observation of certain fact and subjective assessment of those fact the way in which the applicant expressed his remark somewhat lessened their forcefulness we would also note that the impugned remark were addressed to a restricted and specific readership consisting only of judge the general public were not informed of the content of the allegation disseminated to those judge in that context there are three major point to be highlighted firstly the various professional group are often bound together by a corporatist spirit and solidarity thus affecting the way they perceive criticism against their member secondly judge are naturally very wary about remark that are not supported by convincing evidence thirdly judge are used to receiving complaint sometimes very aggressive one from individual who are unhappy with judicial decision or indeed from their lawyer in most case such complaint have no concrete impact on the image of the judge thus criticised these various factor related to the specificity of the readership considerably lessen the consequence of the applicant remark it is questionable whether his letter had a real impact on the image of the judge concerned among that judge colleague criminal proceeding were brought against the applicant and he wa sentenced to a fine of euro for committing a criminal offence in addition the domestic court awarded the complainant judge euro in damage which is a significant sum in our view having regard to the nature of the remark made and the specificity of the very limited readership the sanction applied seen in the whole context is manifestly disproportionate in the circumstance of the case the majority justify the interference with the applicant freedom of expression not only by the need to protect a person reputation but also by the need to maintain the authority of the judiciary in this perspective the interference in question wa supposed to contribute to protecting the authority of the justice system in italy in our opinion on this point given the specific aspect of the case mentioned above the interference with the applicant freedom of expression is likely to have quite the opposite effect

respect of the claim against the second applicant secondly by resuming of his own motion the case against the second applicant judge s had acted in the interest of the plaintiff thereby demonstrating his prejudice against the applicant the government argued that the claim against the author had been correctly and lawfully severed from the claim against the editorial board the editorial board had refused to reveal the identity of the author of the impugned article and the court had had no other choice but to sever the claim after the name of the author had been revealed and the proceeding against him had resumed there had been no procedural obstacle to prevent judge s who had adjudicated the claim against the editorial board from examining the claim against the author under domestic law there were no ground for objecting to judge s the court reiterates that impartiality normally denotes the absence of prejudice or bias and it existence or otherwise can be tested in various way the court ha thus distinguished between a subjective approach that is endeavouring to ascertain the personal conviction or interest of a given judge in a particular case and an objective approach that is determining whether he or she offered sufficient guarantee to exclude any legitimate doubt in this respect see among many other authority gautrin and others v france may report of judgment and decision iii and kyprianou v cyprus gc no echr xiii a to the subjective test the personal impartiality of a judge must be presumed until there is proof to the contrary see padovani v italy february series a no b in the instant case the judge subjective impartiality wa not disputed by the party a to the objective test when applied to a single judge or a body sitting a a bench it mean determining whether quite apart from the personal conduct of the judge or of any of the member of the judicial bench there are ascertainable fact which may raise doubt a to the judge or the bench impartiality in this regard even appearance may be of some importance what is at stake is the confidence which the court in a democratic society must inspire in the public it follows that when it is being decided whether in a given case there is a legitimate reason to fear that a particular judge or judicial bench lack impartiality the standpoint of those claiming that the judge or the bench is not impartial is important but not decisive what is decisive is whether the fear can be held to be objectively justified see gautrin and others and kyprianou both cited above and respectively in the present case the fear of bias stemmed principally from the fact that judge s one of the three judge on the bench examining the claim against the second applicant had already stated his position that the contested statement were defamatory in the case against the first applicant the court accepts that that situation could raise doubt about the impartiality of judge s in the applicant mind it ha thus to decide whether those doubt were objectively justified the court ha found in a number of case that the involvement of the same judge in two set of the proceeding concerning the same event may under certain circumstance cast doubt on that judge impartiality see for example ferrantelli and santangelo v italy august report iii and rojas morale v italy no november where a violation of article wa found because a judge sitting in a criminal case had earlier tried a coaccused and by contrast schwarzenberger v germany no et seq august martelli v italy dec no april and poppe v the netherlands no et seq march where no violation of article wa found in similar circumstance see also fatullayev v azerbaijan no april where the same judge examined question of both civil liability and criminal liability arising from the same fact at the same time the court reiterates that the mere fact that the same judge adjudicated two set of proceeding arising out of the same event is not in itself sufficient to undermine that judge impartiality and that the answer to the question whether an applicant fear are objectively justified depends on the circumstance and the special feature of each particular case see schwarzenberger cited above poppe cited above see also delage and magistrello v france dec no january lindon otchakovsky laurens and july cited above and cañas gómez v spain dec no september all concerning involvement of the same judge in two civil case arising out of the same event turning to the circumstance of the present case the court note that the plaintiff mr p submitted claim simultaneously against the editorial board of the newspaper and the author of the contested article whose identity wa unknown the case wa attributed to judge s given that the first applicant the editorial board of the newspaper refused to disclose the identity of the author judge s severed the claim against the author for adjudication in separate proceeding and stayed those proceeding after the pronouncement by judge s on september of the judgment against the first applicant and while the appeal against that judgment wa pending the second applicant disclosed that he wa the author of the article immediately after that judge s resumed the proceeding against the author on october judge s presiding over a bench of two lay assessor issued the judgment against the second applicant the two set of proceeding were then joined and examined simultaneously by the appeal court in order to determine whether the involvement of judge s in the proceeding against the second applicant after he had participated in the proceeding against the first applicant cast objectively justified doubt on his impartiality the court must take into account the following circumstance the nature and extent of judge s function during both set of proceeding whether the text of the judgment against the first applicant contained any statement concerning the second applicant and created the impression that judge s considered the second applicant liable for defamation and whether in the course of the proceeding against the second applicant judge s gave fresh consideration to the case taking into account the new evidence submitted by the second applicant see ferrantelli and santangelo cited above rojas morale cited above delage and magistrello cited above schwarzenberger cited above and martelli cited above lindon otchakovsky laurens and july cited above poppe cited above and and cañas gómez cited above the court note that in the judgment of september judge s found on the basis of the evidence available to him at that time that the first applicant wa liable for defamation because it had failed to prove the truthfulness of the allegation published by it he did not make any finding a to the liability of the author of the article nor did he use any expression which might create the impression that he had formed any opinion a to the liability of the author see paragraph above further the court observes that when examining the claim against the second applicant judge s wa in no way bound by his first decision which wa not yet final indeed the judgment of october against the second applicant did not contain any reference to the judgment of september judge s gave fresh consideration to the entire case in adversarial proceeding with the benefit of the more comprehensive information obtainable from the second applicant the author of the contested article the second applicant wa free to advance new legal argument or submit evidence showing that the impugned statement authored by him had had a sufficient factual basis or wa otherwise justified a can be seen from the text of the judgment of october the judge took such new argument and evidence into account when deciding whether the second applicant wa liable for defamation see paragraph above in view of the above the court doe not see any reason to suspect that judge s a professional judge who possessed the necessary experience and training to allow him to judge a particular dispute fairly on the basis of it own circumstance see mutatis mutandis craxi v italy no no december wa prejudiced against the second applicant because of his previous involvement in the proceeding against the first applicant a judge s never made any statement implying that he had formed an unfavourable opinion of the second applicant case before presiding over the court that had to decide it the presumption of impartiality can not be said to have been rebutted finally it is relevant that when examining the claim against the second applicant judge s wa not sitting in a singlejudge formation but wa assisted by two lay assessor whose impartiality the applicant did not question see mutadis mutandis diennet v france september series a no a consequently any doubt the applicant may have had a regard the impartiality of judge s can not be held to be objectively justified there ha therefore been no violation of article of the convention a regard the impartiality of the court b equality of arm the applicant further submitted that the judgment of september had been given against the editorial board of the gubernskie vesti newspaper however on september six day after the pronouncement of the judgment the first applicant had been made a defendant by an interim decision issued in it absence the substitution of a defendant disguised a the rectification of a clerical error had resulted in a violation of the applicant procedural right the applicant had been absent from the hearing of september and had been given no opportunity to present their case or submit evidence to the district court counsel who had attended the hearing of september had represented the interest of the editorial board of the gubernskie vesti newspaper that the first applicant had subsequently retained the same counsel to represent it before the appeal court could not remedy the disadvantage created on september the fact remained that at the crucial firstinstance hearing the applicant had been absent and unrepresented and had been deprived of an opportunity to defend their position and comment on the plaintiff claim the government submitted that the first applicant representative had participated in the defamation proceeding from the beginning and had been present at the hearing of september in support of their submission they produced a power of attorney signed by a deputy editorinchief of the first applicant on september appointing mr k and mr r to act a the first applicant counsel in the defamation proceeding see paragraph above they also produced material from the case file showing that all written pleading had been submitted on behalf of the first applicant rather than on behalf of the editorial board of the gubernskie vesti newspaper they also referred to the decision of december by the regional court which found that the judgment of september had defined the right of and imposed obligation on the first applicant because no other organisation had been involved in the proceeding the naming of the editorial board of the gubernskie vesti newspaper a the defendant had been no more than a clerical mistake the court reiterates that it is central to the concept of a fair trial in civil a in criminal proceeding that a litigant is not denied the opportunity to present his or her case effectively before the court and that he or she is able to enjoy equality of arm with the opposing side see steel and morris v the united kingdom no echr ii the principle of adversarial proceeding and equality of arm requires that each party be given a reasonable opportunity to have knowledge of and comment on the observation made or evidence adduced by the other party and to present it case under condition that do not place it at a substantial disadvantage visàvis it opponent see krčmář and others v the czech republic no march and dombo beheer bv v the netherlands october series a no article leaf to the state a free choice of the mean to be used in guaranteeing litigant these right see steel and morris cited above thus given that article of the convention doe not guarantee a right to personal presence before a civil court representation may be an appropriate solution in case where a party can not appear in person see gryaznov v russia no june turning to the citcumstances of the present case the court note that the applicant assertion that the first applicant wa neither present nor represented at the hearing of september is refuted by the document in the case file it is clear from the material in the court possession that from september that is from the very beginning of the defamation proceeding the first applicant wa represented by counsel mr k and mr r see paragraph above they submitted written pleading on the first applicant behalf and participated in all hearing including the hearing of september and the appeal hearing where they made submission on behalf of the first applicant the applicant allegation that mr k and mr r acted on behalf of the editorial board of the gubernskie vesti newspaper doe not therefore find confirmation in the case file moreover the court ha already found that the first applicant and the editorial board of the gubernskie vesti newspaper were one and the same entity see paragraph to above it is therefore not persuaded by the applicant argument that the interim decision of september wa the substitution of a defendant in disguise it is convinced by the domestic court finding that the judgment of september defined the right of and imposed obligation on the first applicant because no other organisation had been involved in the proceeding see paragraph above the amendment of the defendant name wa therefore no more than a rectification of a clerical error correcting a misspelling of the name of the first applicant which acted a the editorial board of the gubernskie vesti newspaper and which had effectively participated a a defendant in the defamation proceeding from their beginning the court concludes that the first applicant representative participated throughout the defamation proceeding and the first applicant wa therefore given an effective opportunity to present it case by commenting on the plaintiff claim making submission and adducing evidence a regard the second applicant absence from the hearing of september it is significant that he wa informed in advance about that hearing he wa therefore given a reasonable opportunity to arrange either for his personal presence or for representation by counsel however he failed to act with reasonable diligence and take the necessary step to ensure that his case wa effectively presented before the court see for similar reasoning milovanova v ukrain dec no october and belan v russia dec no september it is also relevant that the second applicant wa personally present and represented by counsel at the hearing of october and at all appeal hearing in view of the above the court find that the applicant were given a reasonable opportunity to present their case effectively before the court and were able to enjoy equality of arm with the opposing side there ha been therefore no violation of article of the convention a regard the principle of adversarial proceeding and equality of arm for these reason the court unanimously hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention a regard the alleged partiality of the court hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention a regard the principle of adversarial proceeding and equality of arm done in english and notified in writing on may pursuant to rule and of the rule of court be quite effectively protected at the level of search engine without it being necessary to interfere directly with the relevant archived material a situation that by definition raise serious question of necessity in a democratic society it is a crucial consideration that ha been ignored by the domestic ruling which the majority upholds based on a weak procedural argument and with little attention to the general ramification of this potentially farreaching judgment in my view by ordering the applicant to anonymise an archived online article containing information about an old crime committed by the plaintiff in the domestic proceeding mr g the belgian court failed to strike a fair balance between the competing interest protected by article and article of the convention respectively in ratifying the balancing exercise carried out by the national court the judgment go against an emerging but clear european consensus that righttobeforgotten claim in the online realm can and should be effectively addressed through deindexation of search engine result while preserving the integrity of the original historical material unless the privacy claimant can show that for some exceptional reason deindexation would not be sufficient or adequate in the specific case finally the methodological approach followed by the majority in applying the von hannover criterion to the current case is also questionable in my view the essential role of digital press archive i recall at the outset that the court ha repeatedly emphasised the substantial contribution made by digital press archive to preserving and making available news and information thereby constituting an important source for education and historical research see węgrzynowski and smolczewski v poland no july and time newspaper ltd v the united kingdom no and no and echr the maintenance of internet archive is a critical aspect of the role of the press in a democracy ibid the court ha further noted that even with respect to defamatory material it is not the role of judicial authority to engage in rewriting history by ordering the removal from the public domain of all trace of publication which have in the past been found by final judicial decision to amount to unjustified attack on individual reputation see węgrzynowski and smolczewski cited above it follows a fortiori that only very compelling reason can justify direct interference with archived medium content whose legality at the time of the original publication ha not been questioned retrospective cleansing of digital press archive interferes not only with the public article right to be informed about past event and contemporary history but also with the publisher freedom of journalistic expression protected by the same provision in this context the court ha recognised that granting such anonymisation request can have a broader chilling effect on freedom of expression according to the court the obligation to examine the lawfulness of a report at a later stage following an anonymisation request from the person concerned which implies weighing up all the interest at stake would entail a risk that the press might refrain from keeping report in it online archive or that it would omit individualised element in report likely to be the subject of such a request see ml and ww v germany no and june the court observed in that regard that the most careful scrutiny under article is required where measure or sanction imposed on the press are capable of discouraging the participation of the press in debate on matter of legitimate public concern ibid to fulfil their article function digital press archive must be complete and historically accurate any tampering with their content could undermine their underlying purpose which is to maintain a full historical record keeping in mind also that it is not possible to know beforehand which particular information stored in them will at some future point become of renewed public interest for example journalist and others have a legitimate interest in building a moral profile of a political candidate by gathering or crosschecking various fact about his or her past in such a situation the person criminal record may gain new significance whether or not any prior conviction are considered to be spent see jankauskas v lithuania no no june where the court found that spent conviction can legitimately be relied on for the purpose of evaluating a person moral stature in the case of emergent public figure the watchdog function can be seriously compromised if press archive have in the meantime been unnecessarily sanitised in view of the above there is little scope under the convention for measure that have the effect of permanently interfering with the historical record i should note at this point that it make little difference that the historical material ha been left untouched in the printed version of the archive considering that presentday newsgathering investigative journalism and scholarly research rely to a great degree on online source in fact the court ha stressed that the importance of digital press archive stem particularly from the fact that they are readily accessible to the public and are generally free see ml and ww v germany cited above while a person privacy and right to rehabilitation should be generally protected from the casual curiosity of the online mass that doe not necessarily justify the complete erasure of the historical record emerging european consensus on the right to be forgotten it is important to consider the case at hand in the context of the emerging european consensus on balancing private and public interest in case involving press archive an important reference in this regard is the cjeus ruling in google spain to which today judgment refers extensively see paragraph of the judgment at issue in google spain wa an archived online article fully lawful at the time of publication containing a person name in connection with an auction that followed attachment proceeding the cjeu established a data protection remedy that consists in delisting web page containing personal data from namebased search engine result but ensuring that no information get deleted or altered in the original source the cjeus reasoning rested in part on the distinction between the legal regime applicable to general search engine and that applicable to primary publisher with the crucial difference being that only the latter can benefit from journalistic exemption under european union data protection principle the cjeu pointed out that a a result of this difference the data subject will in certain circumstance be capable of exercising his data protection right against the search engine operator but not against the publisher of the web page see paragraph of the cjeu judgment in the same vein the outcome of the weighing of the competing interest at issue may be different in each of the two scenario given that first the legitimate interest justifying the processing may be different and second the consequence of the processing for the data subject and in particular for his private life are not necessarily the same paragraph regarding specifically the consequence of data processing for private life the cjeu found that the inclusion of a web page in namebased search result is liable to constitute a more significant interference with the data subject fundamental right to privacy than the publication on the web page given that the inclusion of information in the search result make access to that information appreciably easier for any internet user making a search in respect of the person concerned and may play a decisive role in the dissemination of that information paragraph in this connection it is important to bear in mind that general search engine have a transformational impact on personal privacy because they allow user to build a complete profile of a person life drawing on practically every piece of information available online in a way that wa not possible in the pre internet day this make general search engine unique in a way that doe not apply to digital press archive or even the search engine of one individual website in continuity with previous eu data protection rule and the google spain judgment the upgraded eu general data protection regulation gdpr expressly lay down the right to erasure of personal data on ground enumerated in article this right is however subject to limitation to the extent that processing is necessary for exercising the right of freedom of expression and information article a the gdpr also provides for exemption and derogation for processing carried out for journalistic purpose if they are necessary to reconcile the right to the protection of personal data with the freedom of expression and information article recital of the gdpr make it clear that this applies in particular to the processing of personal data in news archive and press library in the year since the google spain judgment delisting of namebased search result ha become a wellestablished and functional remedy in europe in case concerning righttobeforgotten claim relating to press publication there is in fact strong comparative evidence pointing towards a reluctance on the part of domestic court to edit the past by anonymising archive with remedy at the level of search engine being favoured instead by way of example i refer to a recent judgment of the spanish constitutional court in a b v ediciones el país which dealt with fact not dissimilar to those at issue in the current case the constitutional court held that once access to the online article in question had been impeded through it deindexation from general search engine and from the internal search engine of el país it wa no longer necessary to alter it content to satisfy the privacy claim since the dissemination of the article had been reduced both quantitatively and qualitatively by disassociating it from the identity of the person concerned also notable is a judgment of the german federal constitutional court of november which introduced a nuanced methodology for balancing private and public interest in case concerning digital press archive with an emphasis on examining all available technical option before resorting to altering the historical record directly while leaving the balancing exercise in casu to the ordinary court the high german court stressed that the aim is to strike a balance that preserve unrestricted access to the original text to the greatest extent possible while also ensuring that where protection is merited in the individual case especially in relation to namebased search via search engine sufficient limitation are put in place paragraph in it methodological guidance to the lower court the federal constitutional court focused on the actual dissemination and visibility of the original publication on the internet see paragraph and an aspect that is also crucial in the present case the allterrain von hannover criterion turning now to our own methodology for considering righttobeforgotten request the majority have resorted to the criterion developed in von hannover v germany no gc no and echr a the general matrix for resolving conflict between article and article interest in fairness the court ha previously followed the same approach in ml and ww v germany cited above the deployment of the von hannover criterion together with the similar but not identical test adopted in axel springer ag v germany gc no february in order to resolve all conflict ranging from invasion of privacy to defamation dispute and now matter of informational selfdetermination ha generated a measure of criticism from both outside and inside the court it ha been argued for example that defamation case differ in many significant respect from privacy tort and that at least some of the criterion developed in von hannover are not equally relevant or transposable to the reputational context i have some sympathy for this line of argument considering that it may be somewhat rigid and overambitious to seek to apply a single set of criterion to the very diverse range of conflict that may arise between article and interest this is especially so in view of the growing scope and diversity of claim that the court ha recognised a falling with the remit of article be that a it may the current context raise an even more challenging question why should the von hannover criterion be applied by default to a dispute about a publication whose original legality is not in question and whose courtordered editing is requested in the name of substantially different consideration for example the notoriety of the person concerned or the contribution of the material to matter of public interest are much more easily assessable at the moment of the original publication in contrast when interference with the archived material is requested many year after the event it is also necessary to consider the potential utility and relevance of the publication at some future time this is an inherently uncertain ponderation and therefore the presumption must be in favour of not interfering directly with original archive material for these reason i fear that the von hannover criterion may have reached the limit of their usefulness in this context it is worth recalling here that the eu regulatory framework on the right to be forgotten relies on a simpler set of criterion that are more germane to the context of personal data protection though certainly not without their own interpretative challenge delisting versus editing of the press archive in the present case turning to the merit of the present case i do not question that the plaintiff in the domestic proceeding had a legitimate article interest in not being casually confronted with his spent conviction with a view to his reintegration in society it is however important to pinpoint where exactly that interest lay he took the initial step against le soir because he realised that the article at issue appeared among the top search result when his name wa typed into search engine see paragraph of the judgment in his submission to this court mr g sought to demonstrate the impact of the archived article on his private life precisely by reference to the fact that the article featured prominently in the search result linked to his name on a major search engine and on the internal search engine of le soir see paragraph of the thirdparty submission it is also notable even though not decisive that mr g wa prepared to accept a an alternative remedy the delisting of the article from search engine result for query containing his name should anonymisation of the article prove technically impossible see paragraph of the judgment it is clear from the above that the plaintiff root concern wa with the online search result not the article itself with this in mind his legitimate interest in not being confronted with the article in question in his daily personal and professional life could have been adequately protected by removing the article from namebased search result on general search engine according to current statistic more than percent of belgian internet user tend to use one of two major search engine such a measure would have prevented the article from becoming easily accessible through curiositydriven or other random search query at the same time it would have preserved the integrity of the press archive and allowed full access to the unaltered original source to those person journalist researcher or others who might become specifically interested in the past event covered in the article while delisting remains a significant interference with the freedom to receive and impart information and idea it is still le onerous for the applicant and le detrimental to his article right it can not be excluded that in certain circumstance a privacy interest may be so strong a to warrant the anonymisation of an archived news article where a person make a compelling case that the harm caused to him or her a a result of an online publication can not be undone by delisting other remedy may need to be considered put differently for anonymisation to be compatible with article a person must show that substantial harm to his or her private life doe not result merely from a piece of information being easily discoverable but rather from the fact that the information continues to exist in the online space at all for example when it involves particularly sensitive personal data or especially vulnerable person however no such special circumstance are present in the instant case how do the majority deal with this conundrum they find that since the plaintiff had not requested deindexation from the search engine and had in fact chosen to go after the newspaper archive it wa not for the national court or for this court to consider possible alternative in the abstract see paragraph of the judgment in other word because the plaintiff ha demanded that the neighbour wall be taken down in order to get rid of some graffiti on it let the plaintiff have his wish alternative and proportionality be damned i am not persuaded that the belgian court seriously considered any readily available alternative to direct interference with the archived material in this case the majority have therefore upheld domestic decision that failed to engage in the kind of careful balancing that other national and supranational court across the continent have sought to develop in this delicate context while one ought to have sympathy for the predicament of the plaintiff in the domestic proceeding we can not ignore the broader consequence of the precedent we are creating in conclusion today judgment stand in strong tension with the principle of our own jurisprudence on the integrity of press archive a well a the emerging european consensus on the application of the right to be forgotten in adopting this judgment the court may have opened the door with no good reason in my view to the facile cleansing of the journalistic record case c euc google spain sl and google inc it is notable that the liège court of appeal took note of google spain in it decision in the case at hand and wa therefore aware of the newly established remedy see paragraph of the judgment see article data protection working party guideline on the implementation of the court of justice of the european union judgment in the case of google spain sl and google inc v agencia española de protección de datos aepd and mario costeja gonzález c adopted on november see for instance the recent judgment of the high court of england and wale in nt and nt v google and the information commissioner ewhc qb and the judgment of the french court of cassation first civil division may no judgment june bv r november see among others h tomlinson privacy and defamation strasbourg blur the boundary january at inforrmorg and s e gale defamation and the misuse of private information a comparative analysis tort law review at see although in a more specific context the joint dissenting opinion of judge sajó and karakaş in satakunnan markkinapörssi oy and satamedia oy v finland gc no june see paragraph above i am also unable to follow the majority suggestion that the applicant entity should have requested deindexation from the search engine while the rightsholder wa not prepared to do so himself this would be against the principle of data protection and it is not surprising that the search engine failed to act on a third party request

judgment jfkhb concurring opinion of judge koskelo i have joined the majority in concluding that there ha been no violation of article in the present case but i have done so with considerable hesitation i will briefly set out the reason for this the factual background to the case in a nutshell is the following the applicant a journalist and civilsociety activist exercised their freedom of expression and assembly in relation to commonplace matter of general interest see paragraph of the present judgment in the wake of those activity they were targeted on the website of a rightwing movement and in certain progovernment medium with very serious and repeated accusation alleging that the applicant through their association with protest organised under the banner dont let belgrade drown were involved in a foreignled conspiracy by extremist directed against the elected government and aimed at it overthrow or even the assassination of the prime minister the applicant sought in vain to obtain protection by the domestic criminal justice system according to the competent prosecuting authority there wa no ground to believe that any criminal offence which wa subject to public prosecution had been committed they considered that the reported action had had no consequence and entailed no deprivation or restriction of anyones right nor had the publication of the article promoted or incited hatred discrimination or violence against any group based on their religion nationality or other personal characteristic it wa acknowledged that the reported act could perhaps have been classified a an insult which however wa not subject to public prosecution the applicant subsequent constitutional appeal wa rejected it is well known that the court approach ha been critical and restrictive towards the use of criminal remedy in the context of measure by state authority to sanction the exercise of freedom of expression in many situation there are very wellfounded and solid reason to justify that approach indeed there are obvious risk involved in recourse being had to the repressive penal power of the state especially when it come to interference in the exercise of criticism directed at institution or person in position of power that being said any assessment of the act or omission of state authority whether in the field of their negative or positive obligation under the convention must however remain sensitive to the context and adequately differentiated according to the specific circumstance what is at issue in the present case are accusation directed at the applicant by other private actor denouncing and discrediting them on account of the protest activity in which they participated given the very serious nature of the accusation levelled against the applicant and the general context it seems wellfounded to consider a the applicant did that the action they complained of went beyond mere insult indeed it appears that freedom of expression wa employed against the applicant with a view to suppressing their freedom to act and express their opinion thus the present case is not about any chilling effect that might arise from sanction applied against those who engage in criticism it is on the contrary about the chilling effect that risk being created through the failure to impose sanction on those who seek to attack others for the usual exercise of their freedom and who do so not by engaging in an exchange of argument on the subject matter of the issue addressed but through attempt to stigmatise the opponent a traitor and conspirator that is to say enemy of the state instead of treating them a legitimate participant and interlocutor in the normal affair and controversy of society the danger of such aggressive potentially toxic and intimidating smear campaign for the condition and the quality of necessary democratic debate and exchange of argument should not be underestimated after all the ultimate aim of freedom of expression is to enable and to maintain democracy not to undermine it therefore it is indeed very important in the interest of protecting democracy to uphold the positive obligation incumbent on the state party to create by establishing an effective system for the protection of journalist a well a member of civil society a favourable environment for participation in public debate this should enable the expression of opinion and idea without fear even if they may run counter to those defended by the official authority or by a significant part of public opinion see khadija ismayilova v azerbaijan no and january in this context the availability of recourse to various civil remedy alone may not be sufficient especially in term of the necessary dissuasive effect i note for instance that in the domestic civil judgment mentioned in paragraph of the present judgment the award of compensation amounted to serbian dinar equivalent to no more than roughly euro even where outright hate speech is not involved act amounting to intimidation smear campaign or other form of persistent harassment aimed at others because of their normal exercise of freedom under article may reasonably call for a reaction and protection of the victim by the criminal justice system this may be particularly relevant if suppressive action by some actor or group directed at those holding and expressing different view become a more general pattern of behaviour in this regard one must note with concern the information contained in paragraph of the present judgment relating to the general environment of medium freedom and debate in the respondent state in my view the circumstance of the case together with the more general context were of such a nature a to create a heightened duty of scrutiny on the part of the domestic authority in connection with the positive obligation arising for them under article given the very limited and superficial reasoning provided see paragraph of the judgment i remain in doubt a to whether the domestic authority primarily the prosecution service actually conducted a sufficiently thorough assessment of the applicant grievance in particular a regard the offence set out in article of the criminal code a that provision concern an offence which is subject to public prosecution it fell to be considered even if it wa not expressly referred to by the applicant themselves given the inherent limit of the information accessible in the material before u and the necessary caution mandated by the partial view available to u i have voted in favour of finding no violation despite the doubt expressed above

assessment of the relevant fact see vogt v germany september series a no and jerusalem cited above with further reference and whether the interference corresponded to a pressing social need and wa proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued see i̇a cited above with further reference in order to determine it proportionality the court must consider the impugned interference not only in the light of the content of the statement at issue but also the context in which they were made furthermore the nature and severity of the penalty imposed are also factor to be taken into account see for example gündüz cited above where the balancing exercise ha been undertaken by the national authority in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw the court would require strong reason to substitute it view for that of the domestic court see von hannover v germany no gc no and february ii application of the above principle to the instant case the court note at the outset that the subject matter of the instant case is of a particularly sensitive nature and that the potential effect of the impugned statement depend to a certain degree on the situation in the country where the statement were made at the time and the context in which they were made accordingly and notwithstanding some of the domestic court consideration such a the duration of the marriage in question the court therefore considers that the domestic authority had a wide margin of appreciation in the instant case a they were in a better position to evaluate which statement were likely to disturb the religious peace in their country the court note that the domestic court considered the applicant statement a having been made in public see paragraph in fine above indeed the seminar were widely advertised to the public on the internet and via leaflet the latter were sent out by the head of the rightwing freedom party addressing them especially to young voter and praising them a top seminar in the framework of a free education package the applicant intervention wa entitled basic information on islam and wa meant to be a critical analysis of islamic doctrine allowing for a discussion with the participant of the seminar the title gave the in hindsight misleading impression that the seminar would include objective information on islam it appears that anyone interested wa able to enrol there wa no requirement to be a member of the freedom party the applicant therefore could not assume that there would only be likeminded people in the room who would share her very critical view of islam but had to expect that there could also be people among the audience who might be offended by her statement it is of little relevance that only thirty people attended on average the applicant statement were in fact recorded by a journalist who had participated in the seminar and whose employer subsequently reported them to the public prosecutor see paragraph above the court reiterates that a religious group must tolerate the denial by others of their religious belief and even the propagation by others of doctrine hostile to their faith a long a the statement at issue do not incite to hatred or religious intolerance article of the criminal code see paragraph above doe not in fact incriminate all behaviour that is likely to hurt religious feeling or amount to blasphemy but additionally requires that the circumstance of such behaviour were capable of arousing justified indignation and thus aim at the protection of religious peace and tolerance the court note that the domestic court explained extensively why they considered that the applicant statement had been capable of arousing justified indignation on the ground that they had not been made in an objective manner aimed at contributing to a debate of public interest but could only be understood a having been aimed at demonstrating that muhammad wa not a worthy subject of worship see paragraph above the court endorses this assessment when saying what do we call it if it is not paedophilia the applicant according to her own statement wa quoting a conversation she had had with her sister who wa of the opinion that one had to paraphrase the accusation that muhammad wa a paedophile say it in a more diplomatic way the court note that the applicant described herself a an expert in the field of islamic doctrine already having held seminar of that kind for a while her argument that the impugned statement had been made in the context of a lively discussion in which they could not be revoked see paragraph above is therefore not convincing contrast gündüz cited above the court therefore agrees with the domestic court that the applicant must have been aware that her statement were partly based on untrue fact and liable to arouse justified indignation in others in that context the court reiterates that the convention state are required in accordance with their positive obligation under article of the convention to ensure the peaceful coexistence of religious and nonreligious group and individual under their jurisdiction by ensuring an atmosphere of mutual tolerance see paragraph above the court endorses the regional court statement in it judgment of february that presenting object of religious worship in a provocative way capable of hurting the feeling of the follower of that religion could be conceived a a malicious violation of the spirit of tolerance which wa one of the base of a democratic society see paragraph in fine above the court note that the domestic court qualified the impugned statement a value judgment based on a detailed analysis of the wording of the statement made see in particular paragraph above they found that the applicant had subjectively labelled muhammad with a general sexual preference for paedophilia and had failed to neutrally inform her audience of the historical background which consequently had not allowed for a serious debate on that issue see paragraph and above the court therefore agrees with the domestic court that the impugned statement can be classified a value judgment not having a sufficient factual basis even if they were to be classified a factual statement a the applicant insisted she failed to adduce any evidence to that end both during the domestic proceeding and before the court a to the applicant argument that a few individual statement had to be tolerated during a lively discussion the court considers that it is not compatible with article of the convention to package incriminating statement in the wrapping of an otherwise acceptable expression of opinion and deduce that this render statement exceeding the permissible limit of freedom of expression passable moreover the applicant wa wrong to assume that improper attack on religious group had to be tolerated even if they were based on untrue fact see paragraph above on the contrary the court ha held that statement which are based on manifestly untrue fact do not enjoy the protection of article see mutatis mutandis giniewski cited above and medžlis islamske zajednice brčko and others v bosnia and herzegovina gc no echr lastly the court reiterates that the applicant wa ordered to pay a moderate fine of only eur in total for the three statement made although the criminal code alternatively provided for up to six month imprisonment furthermore the fine imposed wa at the lower end of the statutory scale of punishment of up to dayfines namely only dayfines and the domestic court applied only the minimum daily amount of eur although the applicant had no previous criminal record and this wa taken into account a a mitigating factor her repeated infringement had to be considered a an aggravating factor under the circumstance the court doe not consider the criminal sanction to be disproportionate in conclusion the court find that in the instant case the domestic court comprehensively assessed the wider context of the applicant statement and carefully balanced her right to freedom of expression with the right of others to have their religious feeling protected and to have religious peace preserved in austrian society they discussed the permissible limit of criticism of religious doctrine versus their disparagement and found that the applicant statement had been likely to arouse justified indignation in muslim in addition the court considers that the impugned statement were not phrased in a neutral manner aimed at making an objective contribution to a public debate concerning child marriage contrast aydın tatlav and giniewski both cited above but amounted to a generalisation without a factual basis thus by considering them a going beyond the permissible limit of an objective debate and classifying them a an abusive attack on the prophet of islam which wa capable of stirring up prejudice and putting religious peace at risk the domestic court came to the conclusion that the fact at issue contained element of incitement to religious intolerance the court accepts that they thereby put forward relevant and sufficient reason and find that the interference with the applicant right under article did indeed correspond to a pressing social need and wa proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued therefore the court considers that the domestic court did not overstep their wide margin of appreciation in the instant case when convicting the applicant of disparaging religious doctrine accordingly there ha been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the application admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on october pursuant to rule and of the rule of court claudia westerdiek angelika nußberger registrar president

freedom of expression limit of permissible criticism are wider with regard to a public authority than in relation to a private citizen or even a politician in a democratic system the action or
