the applicant wa born in and life in vienna he is of bulgarian origin on july a letter signed by the applicant wa sent to the sofia municipality in that letter the applicant complained of construction work undertaken by his nephew ak which had significantly altered the house which had been owned by his parent and where he had been born the applicant had become aware of that during his stay in sofia in may he expressed his indignation about the work undertaken a well a doubt a to their legality and requested to be sent copy of all document concerning them stating that he intended to bring the matter to court he stated in addition that ak held for the property in question an illegal notarial deed acquired on the basis of a forged notarial deed these allegation concerned the notarial deed of and described in paragraph below ak had been the beneficiary under both of them the applicant indicated an intention to challenge these deed in court in december ak initiated a private criminal prosecution of the applicant in his complaint he stated that he had become aware of the applicant letter by chance and claimed that the applicant had defamed him in particular by stating that he had an illegal notarial deed acquired on the basis of a forged notarial deed this implied that ak had committed a criminal offence namely using a forged document in the same proceeding ak also brought a tort action against the applicant claiming bulgarian lev bgn the equivalent of euro eur in nonpecuniary damage the applicant objected to the complaint against him contending that what he had stated wa true and that he had never claimed that ak had actually used the forged document in a decision of the sofia district court of october the criminal prosecution of the applicant wa discontinued a timebarred and the examination of the case continued only a regard ak tort action that action wa allowed in a judgment of the sofia district court of january the domestic court stated expressly in that judgment that it did not have to establish the element of the criminal offence of defamation it had to establish in accordance with section of the obligation and contract act see paragraph below whether the applicant behaviour amounted to a tortious act and whether ak had suffered any damage a a result a to the fact of the case the sofia district court established that ak had become the owner of part of the property at issue after his mother had donated to him a share in and he had purchased another share from a coowner in both transaction had been attested in notarial deed in a further notarial deed of ak had been recognised a the owner of part of the property in he had obtained a permit to enlarge the existing house the construction work had been carried out in and a representative of the building control authority had visited the site on july and had established breach of the relevant rule but no administrative sanction had been ordered against ak an additional check had been carried out on november after one of the coowners of the property not the applicant had complained that check had showed that part of the construction work undertaken by ak did not correspond to the construction permit it appears however that ak had not been ordered to demolish the unlawfully constructed part further complaint by the coowners concerning the construction undertaken by ak had been sent to the municipality on may the sofia district court heard in addition witness who said that following the applicant allegation against him ak had become nervous and had had unspecified problem with the authority the sofia district court found that it had never been shown that the notarial deed in ak favour had been flawed meaning that they had to be considered valid the applicant allegation that one of these deed had been illegal and another one forged could have affected ak good name in society a they suggested that ak had profited from using unlawful mean those allegation had also damaged ak professional reputation since he wa working in construction this wa so even bearing in mind that the municipal authority had taken no particular action against ak and that check on the construction site had been incited by other coowners of the property the above consideration were valid regardless of whether the applicant had committed the criminal offence of defamation since this wa not the subject of the proceeding the applicant had had resort to his constitutional right to petition the authority but the exercise of that right did not have to involve causing damage to others the sofia district court ordered the applicant to pay ak bgn the equivalent of eur in nonpecuniary damage plus default interest it considered such an award to be just pointing out that ak had enjoyed a good name in society that the applicant allegation had also affected ak professional reputation and that the allegation had been made before a municipal body and not in private correspondence upon an appeal by the applicant in a final judgment of august the sofia city court upheld the district court judgment endorsing it reasoning the applicant ha not submitted document showing that he actually paid the amount awarded to ak nor ha he claimed to have made any such payment ii relevant domestic law and practice article of the constitution of provides that citizen have the right to make complaint proposal and petition to the authority article of the criminal code criminalises defamation the offence and the relevant domestic practice concerning it have been described in marinova and others v bulgaria no and others and july section of the obligation and contract act provides that everyone is obliged to make good the damage which they have through their fault caused to another by article of the code of criminal procedure the criminal court is obliged to rule on a civil claim that ha already been accepted for examination in the criminal proceeding even after the associated criminal prosecution ha become timebarred or the accused ha been acquitted according to the supreme court of cassation the criminal court ha to rule on a civil claim even where it can not rule on the criminal liability of the accused because civil liability stem from a tortious act and not from a criminal offence тълкувателно решение от г на вкс по тълк д г оснк решение от г на вкс по н д г i н о нкthe lawi alleged violation of article of the convention the applicant complained under article of the convention that after having complained to the authority he had been found liable to pay damage to ak for defamation article of the convention read a follows everyone ha the right to freedom of expression this right shall include freedom to hold opinion and to receive and impart information and idea without interference by public authority and regardless of frontier this article shall not prevent state from requiring the licensing of broadcasting television or cinema enterprise the exercise of these freedom since it carry with it duty and responsibility may be subject to such formality condition restriction or penalty a are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interest of national security territorial integrity or public safety for the prevention of disorder or crime for the protection of health or moral for the protection of the reputation or right of others for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence or for maintaining the authority and impartiality of the judiciary a admissibility the court note that the application is not manifestly illfounded within the meaning of article a of the convention it further note that it is not inadmissible on any other ground it must therefore be declared admissible b merit argument of the party the government contended that the interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression had been in compliance with the requirement of article in particular it had been lawful since the relevant provision of the criminal code were clear and accessible and pursued the legitimate aim of protecting the reputation of others moreover the interference had been proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued for the following reason the applicant criminal prosecution had been discontinued and the criminal court had only examined ak civil claim against him the applicant had not been a journalist or a whistleblower nor had ak been a public official which meant that the authority had owed no special protection to the applicant and ak had not been obliged to tolerate criticism the applicant had made a statement of fact not a value judgment and had not proven the veracity of the fact alleged those fact were such that they could have affected ak reputation the damage ordered against the applicant had not been excessive the award of damage had been made in adversarial proceeding and the domestic court had given sufficient reason for their decision the applicant pointed out that his letter had aimed to trigger a check by the authority on possible irregularity and argued that being held liable on that ground had been contrary to the principle of democracy and could dissuade potential future complainant he contested in addition many of the domestic court finding a to the fact of the case the court assessment the general principle developed in the court caselaw concerning freedom of expression have recently been summarised in morice v france gc no echr and medžlis islamske zajednice brčko and others v bosnia and herzegovina gc no june turning to the case at hand the court observes that the court decision finding the applicant liable to pay damage to ak amounted to an interference with his right to freedom of expression under article of the convention in previous case against bulgaria under article of the convention concerning complaint addressed to the authority and where the applicant had been convicted of defamation in criminal proceeding the court expressed doubt a to the lawfulness of the interference with their right these were based on the fact that the applicant had not disseminated injurious statement while the dissemination wa an requisite element of the offence of defamation a interpreted by the former bulgarian supreme court and the current supreme court of cassation the applicant case had not reached the supreme court of cassation so that it could authoritatively rule on the matter however the court decided that it did not have to pronounce on the question of lawfulness since it considered that the interference with the applicant right were in any event disproportionate see marinova and others no and others july zdravko stanev v bulgaria no no july sapundzhiev v bulgaria committee no september in the present case similarly to the one cited in the previous paragraph the proceeding against the applicant were initially concerned with his criminal liability for defamation however his criminal prosecution subsequently became timebarred and the domestic court did not seek to establish whether the applicant had committed the criminal offence of defamation they only examined the civil claim brought by ak in the same proceeding see paragraph and above in view thereof the court see no reason to call into question the lawfulness of the interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression a it did in the case cited in the previous paragraph on the ground of any failure of the domestic court to establish the element of the criminal offence of defamation the interference wa based on section of the obligation and contract act see paragraph and above the court find therefore that the interference with the applicant right wa prescribed by law a required under article of the convention the court considers furthermore that the interference pursued a legitimate aim namely the protection of the reputation and right of ak the salient question is whether the interference wa necessary in a democratic society that is to say whether it corresponded to a pressing social need whether it wa proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and whether the reason given by the national authority were relevant and sufficient see among others janowski v poland gc no echr i the applicant wa found civilly liable for having stated that ak wa in possession of an illegal notarial deed acquired on the basis of a forged notarial deed see paragraph above the court see no reason to question the domestic court finding of fact in that regard namely that the applicant had made that statement and that it wa untrue moreover even if it acknowledges that the impugned statement wa not particularly aggressive denigrating or insulting and note that no adverse practical consequence for ak such a check or inspection on the part of the authority stemmed from the applicant letter the court is not to question the national court conclusion that ak nevertheless suffered some damage a a result that conclusion wa based in particular on witness testimony and appears to be adequately reasoned see paragraph above the applicant wa found civilly liable for one particular statement contained in his letter of july namely a mentioned above that ak wa in possession of an illegal notarial deed acquired on the basis of a forged notarial deed see paragraph above that statement wa addressed to the sofia municipality but that local authority wa not competent to verify such a matter or take any measure the applicant said in his letter that he intended to challenge ak notarial deed in court which wa indeed the authority competent to resolve the matter but ha not shown that he took any action in that regard accordingly it can not be said that the applicant wa found liable for having made before an authority a complaint the latter wa competent to deal with contrast marinova and others and sapundzhiev both cited above on the contrary it would appear that in making the impugned statement the applicant deliberately sought to harm his nephew the statement at issue wa not made impulsively or in the heat of a discussion but wa sent to the authority about two month after the applicant had visited sofia and had become aware of the construction undertaken by his nephew see paragraph above it is also significant that no sanction wa imposed to the applicant with regard to the remaining statement in his letter of july in particular that he wa indignant about the work undertaken by his nephew and that he had doubt a to their legality in addition the applicant did not make allegation of misconduct against a public official with regard to whom the limit of acceptable criticism would have been wider contrast marinova and others cited above for the reason above the court find that the interference with the applicant freedom of expression corresponded to a pressing social need a mentioned above it note furthermore that in finding the applicant civilly liable for having made the impugned statement the domestic court gave relevant and sufficient reason a to the sanction imposed on the applicant the court observes that the criminal prosecution against him became timebarred and he wa only found civilly liable the applicant wa ordered to pay to ak a sum equivalent to eur plus default interest see paragraph above the applicant ha not submitted detail on his personal financial situation and the court is unable to ass whether such an award against him wa excessive and imposed on him a disproportionate burden furthermore the applicant doe not appear to have actually paid any part of that sum see paragraph above nor ha it been claimed that ak ha attempted to obtain such a payment moreover seeing that a noted above the case did not concern a complaint by the applicant to an authority competent to deal with it it can not be said that the finding of the applicant civilly liable risked having the effect of stifling potential future complaint contrast sapundzhiev cited above having regard to the above the court concludes that the interference with the applicant freedom of expression wa necessary in a democratic society and thus met the requirement of article of the convention there ha accordingly been no violation of article for these reason the court unanimously declares the application admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on may pursuant to rule and of the rule of court claudia westerdiek angelika nußberger registrar president

interpretation the court note that the requested rectification had a sufficient connection to the impugned article with regard to the applicant company argument that the domestic court should have refused k request for a rectification on the basis of her refusal to answer it question see paragraph above the court reiterates that a person conduct prior to publication will only reduce his or her legitimate expectation regarding the effective protection of his or her private life under specific circumstance see axel springer ag v germany gc no february with further reference usually such a consequence will require the person concerned to have sought the limelight himself ibidem or result from the person own illicit action such a for example the commission of a criminal offence see mikolajová v slovakia no january the court observes moreover that while press organ are held to report in good faith in order to provide reliable and precise information in accordance with the ethic of journalism see axel springer ag cited above and thus should give the person concerned the chance to defend him or herself the fact that the impugned allegation were communicated doe not confer unrestricted freedom to publish unverified allegation neither doe it preclude the right of reply of the person concerned in order to correct fact claimed to be inaccurate therefore and taking into account that the applicant company argument doe not concern any illicit behaviour on the part of k prior to the publication of the contested article her refusal to answer the applicant company question can not serve a an argument for limiting her right to a rectification of incorrect fact the court further observes that the statement in question were published in a daily newspaper see paragraph above there is no indication that there wa an undue delay between the publication of the impugned article and the lodging of a request for a rectification see paragraph and above with regard to the proportionality of the rectification order the court note at the outset that there is a material difference between the rectification of fact claimed to be inaccurate and sanction such a the prohibition on publication criminal sanction and the order to pay damage for value judgement in defamation case see mutatis mutandis lingens cited above and oberschlick cited above in determining the proportionality of the rectification order the court of appeal considered that the applicant company presented k connection to company with alleged tie to the sed in some detail accordingly it found that the information provided in k reply in this regard had not exceeded what wa necessary to counter the applicant company allegation the court see no reason to challenge this assessment it observes in addition that the rectification wa to be printed on the same page a that on which the original article had appeared and that a request to have the rectification announced on the newspaper frontpage had been refused see paragraph above furthermore there is no indication that the length of k reply exceeded the length of the statement in question see for a similar factual situation and a fortiori funke woman group gmb h v germany dec committee no and december similarly nothing suggests that the publication of the reply constituted a punishable offence lastly the court note that k reply did not bear the date of the final version the applicant company had been ordered to publish but instead the date of k original request to the applicant company see paragraph above in this regard the court of appeal considered that the discrepancy did not render the published information manifestly incorrect while the text of the original reply had been modified several time in order to alleviate the domestic court legal concern the core message of the reply wa identical see paragraph above the court see no reason to disagree with this assessment in the light of the aforementioned consideration the court find that in assessing the circumstance submitted for it appreciation the court of appeal gave due consideration to the principle and criterion a laid down by the court caselaw for balancing the right to respect for private life and the right to freedom of expression the court discerns no strong reason that would require it to substitute it view for that of the court of appeal see the caselaw quoted in paragraph above accordingly there ha been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the application admissible hold that there ha been bladet tromsø and stensaas v norway gc no echr iii it is open to the relevant state authority to adopt appropriate measure in order to react without excess to defamatory accusation that are devoid of foundation or formulated in bad faith moreover freedom of expression carry with it duty and responsibility and any person who chooses to disclose information must carefully verify to the extent permitted by the circumstance in question that it is accurate and reliable see guja v moldova gc no echr furthermore the more serious the allegation the higher the level of diligence that must be exercised before bringing it to the attention of the relevant authority or the public see medžlis islamske zajednice brčko and others cited above when the freedom of expression of person with public responsibility is at stake the duty and responsibility referred to in article are of particular importance in that regard an important aspect is the privileged position that person with public responsibility enjoy in accessing the medium owing to their position of authority see poyraz v turkey no december ii application of the relevant general principle to the present case the present case concern defamation proceeding against the applicant who wa in office a the chairman of the supervisory board of the bank which wa partly owned by the state he provided comment to the journalist regarding allegation of undocumented advertising and marketing expense that he had raised at the bank supervisory board meeting a a result during the month which preceded the parliamentary election nra published numerous article about the upcoming election including nine article referring to the applicant allegation which later turned out to be unfounded the court can accept that the applicant allegation were made in the context of a public debate prior to the parliamentary election and concerned al who wa one of the leader of a newly established political party and who stood for election also it wa undisputed in the domestic proceeding and before the court that al during his time in office a the president of the bank and throughout the preelection period had acted in a public context while the domestic court did not provide full analysis of the criterion laid down in the court caselaw see paragraph above the court doe not consider it necessary to examine this further because the crux of the present case is the question of whether the applicant allegation contained a factual basis that wa sufficient in view of the particular circumstance of the present case the court note that the party to the present case disagreed a to whether the applicant allegation of undocumented advertising and marketing expense in the bank constituted statement of fact or value judgment the domestic court reasoning in this respect wa rather succinct a they limited themselves to finding that the applicant allegation turned out to be unfounded which fact the applicant did not contest and had thus been false from the very beginning while the court considers that some of the applicant assertion could be regarded a constituting value judgement his pronouncement also included statement of fact susceptible of proof in any event the court is of the view that the issue that must be determined in the present case is whether there wa at least a sufficient factual basis for the applicant allegation the reasonableness of the effort made to verify the accuracy of the information disclosed must be determined in the light of the situation at the time that the statement were made rather than with the benefit of hindsight on the basis of the subsequent internal and external audit report see mutatis mutandis medžlis islamske zajednice brčko and others cited above the court also refers here to the duty and responsibility associated with freedom of expression see paragraph above and note their pertinence to the present case given the applicant public status under the domestic law a the chairman of the supervisory board of the partly stateowned bank a well a his own affirmation that he had the duty to inform the public of the supervisory board activity it is undisputed that the applicant allegation were based on his initial report that he had prepared for the purpose of the supervisory board meeting see paragraph above he had requested and received internal information from the marketing and economics department in this regard and informed the supervisory board about his personal finding of undocumented advertising and marketing expense in the bank he also commented on his allegation to the journalist who on the day after the supervisory board extraordinary meeting published the first article alleging that under the bank previous management large sum of money had been transferred without any documentation in order to finance advertising and marketing activity the applicant wa directly quoted a stating that somebody is receiving this paid money back and this is money that ha been stolen from the shareholder in later newspaper article the applicant wa also quoted a saying it is possible that this is the money that provided the foundation for the latvia first party sizable advertising campaign these statement made by the applicant see also paragraph above contained serious allegation the senate of the supreme court relying on the journalist testimony held that the applicant allegation had specifically concerned al and not a claimed by the applicant the bank management a a whole what is in issue in the present case is whether the applicant exceeded the limit of acceptable criticism by commenting on his allegation to the journalist at the material time the court agrees with the domestic court that the limit of acceptable criticism are wider for politician than in relation to private individual moreover candidate in parliamentary election are exposed to the widest scrutiny by the press and by the public that being said in view of the consequence that serious allegation of misconduct may have on public opinion and potentially on the result of election duty and responsibility inherent in freedom of expression require particularly close scrutiny a to whether there wa a sufficient factual basis for such serious allegation the applicant initial report not having been made available the court note several factor which call into question the way in which the applicant acted when commenting on his allegation to the journalist in the present case given his position his knowledge of the relevant event and the point in time at which he made his allegation first of all the applicant must have been aware of his status under domestic law a a public official and that the journalist could in accordance with section of the law on the mass medium rely on his statement see paragraph and above the domestic court established that the journalist had had no reason to doubt the credibility of the information provided by the applicant owing to his position a the chairman of the supervisory board indeed the journalist could not further verify the applicant allegation given that they concerned the bank internal document and did not appear to have been publicly available compare bladet tromsø and stensaas cited above secondly the court note that the applicant formed his view concerning undocumented advertising and marketing expense after consulting the head of the marketing and economics department it is unclear given the seriousness of the allegation why he did not solicit any relevant information from the internal audit department before giving his comment to the press the court note that it took only around fourteen day for the internal audit department to carry out it preliminary verification of the applicant allegation and to dismiss them nonetheless the applicant commented on his allegation to the press without awaiting the outcome of the internal audit which wa still ongoing when he made those comment thus the applicant knowingly chose to disclose unverified information to the journalist thirdly the applicant comment were made during the month preceding the election at the time when a political debate wa at it peak such allegation were capable of carrying a certain weight on public opinion about the newly established party and one of it leader given the applicant position at the bank and the nature of his allegation the court doe not consider that the applicant could rely on the degree of exaggeration or even provocation that can usually be used in the exercise of freedom of expression in the context of a political debate see mutatis mutandis petrina v romania no october compare also standard verlagsgesellschaft mb h v austria no no february therefore given the circumstance of the case the need for a sufficiently accurate and reliable factual basis wa particularly relevant lastly it appears that the applicant took no step to voice his disagreement a press release official comment or retraction etc with the publication of further article citing him a a source and providing further quote of his statement when a early a october the first result of the internal audit were made available to the supervisory board finding no proof for undocumented advertising and marketing expense in the bank a noted by the government he appears not to have taken any further step to remedy the situation after the final result had been made available by the internal audit and external audit in view of the foregoing the court concludes that the applicant initial report on the basis of which he made comment on such serious allegation a misappropriation of the bank fund by it former president who wa a candidate in the parliamentary election contained no sufficient factual basis even if the applicant comment were to be regarded a constituting value judgment the applicant accordingly overstepped the limit of acceptable criticism in relation to al the court is therefore satisfied that the disputed interference wa supported by relevant and sufficient reason and that the authority of the respondent state struck a fair balance between the applicant freedom of expression on the one hand and al interest in protection of his reputation on the other hand thus acting within their margin of appreciation compare poyraz cited above accordingly there ha been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the complaint under article of the convention admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on june pursuant to rule and of the rule of court claudia westerdiek angelika nußberger registrar president

follows in the case of micallef v malta gc no echr impartiality normally denotes the absence of prejudice or bias and it existence or otherwise can be tested in various way according to the court constant caselaw the existence of impartiality for the purpose of article must be determined according to a subjective test where regard must be had to the personal conviction and behaviour of a particular judge that is whether the judge held any personal prejudice or bias in a given case and also according to an objective test that is to say by ascertaining whether the tribunal itself and among other aspect it composition offered sufficient guarantee to exclude any legitimate doubt in respect of it impartiality see inter alia fey v austria february and series a no a and wettstein v switzerland no echr xii a to the subjective test the principle that a tribunal shall be presumed to be free of personal prejudice or partiality is longestablished in the caselaw of the court see for example kyprianou v cyprus gc no echr xiii the court ha held that the personal impartiality of a judge must be presumed until there is proof to the contrary see wettstein cited above a regard the type of proof required the court ha for example sought to ascertain whether a judge ha displayed hostility or ill will for personal reason see de cubber v belgium october series a no in the vast majority of case raising impartiality issue the court ha focused on the objective test however there is no watertight division between subjective and objective impartiality since the conduct of a judge may not only prompt objectively held misgiving a to impartiality from the point of view of the external observer objective test but may also go to the issue of his or her personal conviction subjective test see kyprianou cited above thus in some case where it may be difficult to procure evidence with which to rebut the presumption of the judge subjective impartiality the requirement of objective impartiality provides a further important guarantee see pullar v the united kingdom june report iii a to the objective test it must be determined whether quite apart from the judge conduct there are ascertainable fact which may raise doubt a to his impartiality this implies that in deciding whether in a given case there is a legitimate reason to fear that a particular judge or a body sitting a a bench lack impartiality the standpoint of the person concerned is important but not decisive what is decisive is whether this fear can be held to be objectively justified see wettstein cited above and ferrantelli and santangelo v italy august report iii the objective test mostly concern hierarchical or other link between the judge and other actor in the proceeding see court martial case for example miller and others v the united kingdom no and october see also case regarding the dual role of a judge for example mežnarić v croatia no july and wettstein cited above where the lawyer representing the applicant opponent subsequently judged the applicant in a single set of proceeding and overlapping proceeding respectively which objectively justify misgiving a to the impartiality of the tribunal and thus fail to meet the convention standard under the objective test see kyprianou cited above it must therefore be decided in each individual case whether the relationship in question is of such a nature and degree a to indicate a lack of impartiality on the part of the tribunal see pullar cited above in this respect even appearance may be of a certain importance or in other word justice must not only be done it must also be seen to be done see de cubber cited above what is at stake is the confidence which the court in a democratic society must inspire in the public thus any judge in respect of whom there is a legitimate reason to fear a lack of impartiality must withdraw see castillo algar v spain october report viiib application of those principle to the present case the court referral of the matter to the minister of justice and the interview in the newspaper clearly had different aim the aim of the first wa to trigger disciplinary proceeding against the judge that being a procedural remedy available to a lawyer in respect of shortcoming on the part of the judiciary the aim of the second action wa to draw the attention of the general public to failing in the judicial investigation concerning this wellknown case i do not believe that one can find fault with a lawyer who ha procedural remedy by which to make good any shortcoming in judicial proceeding whether he us them a in the present case or not for having prompted a public debate a those two path lead in different direction in addition any disciplinary sanction imposed on a judge will not necessarily be known to the public even though clear failing could be seen in the judge work in the present case in any event a lawyer mission is in the very interest of the judicial system to use his best endeavour to ensure that the judicial investigation is conducted objectively and impartially a the court pointed out in kyprianou for the public to have confidence in the administration of justice they must have confidence in the ability of the legal profession to provide effective representation the principle of fair justice encompasses the right to be assisted by an independent lawyer who discharge his professional duty without excessive restriction or interference the possibility of freely expressing his opinion is an indispensable condition for a lawyer to be able to fulfil his principal professional duty the defence of his client interest indeed the lawyer speech argument and persuasion whether oral or written is his main resource a my honourable colleague judge casadevall ha written on this subject speech the sole weapon together with the pen or the keyboard and a very simple but nevertheless formidable one at the lawyer disposal when he is defending a party to proceeding the possibility of filing a complaint with a disciplinary body is not really an appropriate mean of expression when it come to a lawyer freedom of speech moreover public debate a to a problem arising in judicial proceeding is necessary in a democratic society it is clear that any criticism by a lawyer must be assessed in a very stringent manner for the public ha more confidence in the comment of a lawyer who ha inside knowledge of the case than for example those of journalist reporting on a trial in the medium but it would not be rational to leave the possibility of criticism only to outside observer for a wall of silence imposed on professional in relation to a trial that is important for public opinion would discredit the court in the public eye more than the criticism emanating from those professional it is precisely the lawyer who appear in the case before the court and who have the requisite qualification to see the fault and defect in the proceeding that the public count upon to receive information to turn court proceeding into a closed forum where one should not air one dirty washing would in my opinion affect the image of the judicial system more than explicit criticism provided of course that it doe not become offensive or purely speculative with that in mind i do not think that the expression used by the applicant can be regarded a unfounded attack lastly the lawyer conviction for making value judgment appears disproportionate the very existence of criminal proceeding ha a chilling effect lawyer defending their client right should not have to fear prosecution on that account having regard to the foregoing i have reached the conclusion that in the present case the applicant right under article of the convention were not duly upheld partly dissenting opinion of judge lemmensi voted with the majority in finding a violation of article of the convention and no violation of article however i disagreed with my colleague a regard the application of article of the convention in the present case the only violation found by the court concerned the composition of the bench of the criminal division of the court of cassation which dismissed the applicant appeal on point of law the violation related more specifically to only one of the ten judge on the bench the court did not take the view that the court of cassations decision wa open to criticism in term of it content having regard to the convention on the contrary it dismissed the article complaint in those circumstance i am of the view that the finding of a violation of article of the convention would in itself have constituted sufficient redress for the nonpecuniary damage sustained by the applicant nikula v finland no echr ii see mutatis mutandis kudeshkina v proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and whether the reason adduced by the national authority to justify it are relevant and sufficient in doing so the court ha to satisfy itself that the national authority applied standard which were in conformity with the principle embodied in article and moreover that they relied on an acceptable assessment of the relevant fact the court further reiterates that employee have a duty of loyalty reserve and discretion to their employer this is particularly so in the case of the public service since the very nature of public service requires it the employer or the public at large see guja cited above and heinisch v germany no july the court task is therefore to determine whether in the light of the case a a whole the sanction imposed on the applicant wa proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and whether the reason given by the national authority to justify it were relevant and sufficient compare palomo sánchez and others v spain gc no and september fuentes bobo cited above it ha to take into account the circumstance of the case including inter alia the applicant motivation for his statement it legal and factual base the actual wording and it possible interpretation the impact it had on the employer and the sanction inflicted on the applicant turning to the circumstance of the instant case with regard to the applicant motivation the court observes that at the time of the staff meeting the deputy mayor decision dated back almost two year moreover it appears that the applicant addressed his concern neither to w superior nor to the public prosecution the applicant himself claim that he did not want to address the public finally the issue wa not closely related to any subject on the agenda of the staff meeting the court further note that the federal labour court see paragraph above held that the applicant statement wa not aimed at uncovering an unacceptable situation within the housing office but wa rather motivated by the applicant personal misgiving about the deputy mayor arising from the prospect of the impending dissolution of his subdivision the current case ha therefore to be distinguished from case of whistleblowing an action warranting special protection under article of the convention in which an employee report a criminal offence in order to draw attention to alleged unlawful conduct of the employer see heinisch cited above the court further observes that the saxon labour court of appeal on the basis of a thorough examination of the factual and legal situation at the time the impugned demolition permit had been issued considered that the decision taken by the deputy mayor had been lawful and the applicant accusation of perversion of justice unfounded the court considers that the applicant a the longserving head of the subdivision in charge of sanctioning misuse of housing property must have been wellacquainted with the legal background accordingly the court is not convinced that he acquitted himself of the obligation to verify carefully whether his allegation were accurate insofar a the applicant alleged that he had used the term perversion of justice in a colloquial way and therefore had only intended to say that the disputed action of had been unlawful without implying any intention of w relevant under criminal law the court note that the federal labour court found that the applicant a the head of a subdivision of a public authority dealing with legal issue wa more adept in legal matter than the general public it is thus not unreasonable to assume that he should have been aware of the legal implication of the term perversion of justice in particular that it described an intentional abuse of public authority punishable with a minimum of one year imprisonment under article of the criminal code thus considered a felony under domestic law see paragraph above the court considers the unfounded allegation of a serious crime rather a defamatory accusation than a criticism in the interest of the public compare barfod v denmark no february and note that the saxon labour court of appeal held in it judgment that the applicant had never withdrawn his allegation that w had committed this crime the court further observes that the applicant wa given the opportunity to substantiate his allegation and that he repeated his accusation in written form more than a week after the staff meeting using the term perversion of justice several time in bold letter it follows that the dismissal wa not only based on the applicant spontaneous statement during the meeting but also on a written statement he submitted after having been given time to reflect on the impact of his allegation see palomo sanchez and others cited above and de diego nafría v spain no march moreover if in doubt he had the opportunity to verify the legal significance of the term perversion of justice after the staff meeting with respect to the damage suffered by the authority the domestic court found that the applicant accusation were not only likely to damage the deputy mayor reputation but also to interfere seriously with the working atmosphere within the housing office by undermining the deputy mayor authority the court observes that the accusation were not made publicly but during a staff meeting it note however that the federal labour court when assessing the impact of the applicant statement considered that not all person present at the staff meeting had been staff member and that there had been a risk that the applicant allegation would be made known to a wider public the court acknowledges that this intensified the potential impact of the accusation a well a the fact that the crime in question wa a felony and a such the attack on w reputation wa even graver for these reason the case must be distinguished from the case of rubin v latvia no january in which the domestic court had not established that insult had been made and the applicant based his accusation on fact undisputed by the party involved the court further note that the applicant did not act in the context of an ongoing labour conflict compare and contrast palomo sanchez and others cited above nor submit any trade union activity on the issue at stake nor claim to be a union activist himself the court observes that the applicant dismissal from office constituted the heaviest sanction possible under labour law compare heinisch cited above it further note that the saxon labour court of appeal in it judgment of november held that the applicant nonobjectionable conduct at another working place within the municipality of dresden wa likely to be due to his dismissal and the pending proceeding the court further observes that the labour court of appeal acknowledged the applicant difficulty in finding new employment at the age of but still found the dismissal necessary because the applicant behaviour also during the proceeding before the domestic court had shown that the applicant wa likely to reproach the deputy mayor conduct in the presence of other employee and in public it view that the municipality could rightfully fear that the applicant would return to his past behaviour if reinstated taking into account further element such a the applicant written comment and his letter to the editor is not unreasonable and a such is acceptable under the convention having regard to the above consideration and in particular to the fact that the federal labour court and the saxon labour court of appeal in it subsequent judgment both carefully examined the case in the light of the applicant right to freedom of expression the court considers relevant and sufficient the domestic court reason for deciding that the applicant right to freedom of expression did not outweigh the public employer interest in his dismissal the dismissal can not therefore be considered to amount to a disproportionate interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression the court concludes therefore that there ha been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the application admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on september pursuant to rule and of the rule of court claudia westerdiek mark villiger registrar considering that the applicant wa found guilty of and fined for an act which had in his view amounted to a proper exercise of his right to freedom of expression on a matter of public interest see the court thus find that he ha suffered a significant disadvantage accordingly it dismisses the government objection pertaining to article b of the convention the court further note that the applicant opinion of judge elósegui and zündc dissenting opinion of judge seibert fohr joined by judge pavli groc concurring opinion of judge ravarani i am in agreement with the conclusion reached by the majority of judge that in the circumstance of the case there ha been no violation of article i should like however to make clear that i reached that conclusion only because of the specificity of the known fact and moreover lacuna in the presentation of other fact which might have been relevant for the assessment of the alleged violation based on the available information it appears to me that the case wa not about i the applicant allegedly impaired right to express his opinion but rather ii his noncompliance with a legal and proportionate police order based on the risk of degeneration of the peaceful conduct of the gathering into which he had introduced himself a a matter of fact the applicant and mr b were not actually prevented from expressing their opinion at any point during the demonstration it is true a stated in paragraph of the judgment that the police invited them to remove the provocative banner but they refused to do so moreover they were able to remain in the middle of the pro putin gathering and to display their banner during the entire meeting until it very end so there actually wa no concrete impediment to expressing their opinion it is true that at some point the police invited them to remove their banner i am in agreement with the majority that there wa a genuine risk to the peaceful conduct of the event and it appears quite astonishing that only two participant in the demonstration showed discontent with the provocative banner being displayed in their midst the police did not to my mind take an unreasonable or excessive step in inviting the applicant and mr b to remove their banner on the contrary such action showed sound riskassessment it is futile to speculate on how the police would have reacted had they stepped out of the demonstration and displayed their banner outside the pro putin crowd in a quite visible way using their right to counterdemonstrate had there had been an intervention by the police in such a situation there would certainly have been an issue under that right in this context i feel obliged to distance myself from the statement contained in paragraph of the judgment according to which the applicant banner distorted and undermined the message that other participant and the overall demonstration wanted to convey which wa in support of mr putin a it is highly ambiguous and could be understood a restricting the right to counterdemonstrate which is protected by article of the convention see the reference to the court caselaw in that field in paragraph of the judgment it is also true that once the gathering wa over the police stepped in and took the applicant to the police station in order to record the administrative offence of noncompliance with a legal order it appears to me that a a matter of fact the applicant had indeed failed to abide by such an order this did not in itself impair his freedom of expression a it doe not appear from the fact that the given order wa aimed at preventing him from expressing his opinion but rather at avoiding uproar and violence a the applicant actually continued to display his banner and did not step out of the gathering had he done so and the police had nevertheless recorded an administrative offence an issue under article would certainly have arisen the fact of taking the applicant to the police station could have given rise to a violation of convention guarantee if it had been shown that it wa triggered by the content of his banner rather than by the refusal to abide by an invitation that quite legitimately tried to minimise a risk of physical violence not least directed against the applicant and mr b themselves there could also have been a convention issue if the applicant had been taken by force to the police station and been obliged to remain in the premise longer than necessary to draw up the offence record however the fact surrounding this episode are unknown or at the least unexplained see paragraph of the judgment and the applicant ha not lodged a complaint under article of the convention joint concurring opinion of judgeselósegui and zünd in the present case of manannikov v russia we have voted with the majority because we agree with the finding that there ha been no violation of article of the convention the reason for our concurring opinion is to emphasise one of the element which ought to be taken into consideration a a limitation on the right to freedom of expression namely the right of expression of other citizen we agree with the reasoning in the judgment to the effect that there is a double reason for finding no violation namely the legitimate aim of protecting the right of others and preventing a disturbance of public order our caveat is that in the current circumstance different part of the population demonstrate on an increasingly frequent basis in public space because they hold different opinion about social matter such a for instance the policy imposed by state with regard to pandemicrelated publichealth measure we are living in tense society all around europe for very different cause and reason in our view what it is important under article is that those citizen who have requested official permission to demonstrate in one or another direction should be able to do so without being hampered by other citizen who think differently in the present case the fact that the applicant mr manannikov introduced himself into the middle of an authorised demonstration distorted the message that the other participant wished to express in fact by displaying a banner stating that putin is better than hitler he changed the overall image of the demonstration which wa intended to express support for mr putin in our view this behaviour of course increased the risk of conflict but moreover it also failed to respect the right of others to freedom of expression the applicant is free to think in another way but he is not entitled to impede others from expressing their view in the way that he did the caselaw of the court ha insisted on the idea that the exercise of one individual freedom may be limited if it impedes the right of others for instance in the case of steel and others v the united kingdom september report of judgment and decision vii the first applicant together with approximately sixty others took part in a protest against a grouse shoot on wheeldale moor yorkshire ibid she wa arrested for a breach of the peace moreover according to the police she wa intentionally impeding the progress of a member of the shoot by walking in front of him a he lifted his shotgun to take aim thus preventing him from firing ibid she wa further charged with using threatening abusive or insulting word or behaviour within the hearing or sight of a person likely to be caused harassment alarm or distress ibid the court found that the measure taken against her had not given rise to a violation of article we would like to emphasise that the court ha consistently underlined the importance of the right to counterdemonstration which could be held at the same time and venue a a demonstration see for example öllinger v austria no echr ix and fáber v hungary no july see paragraph of the present judgment however this right to counterdemonstration is not absolute and it ha to respect the right of others see plattform ärzte für da leben v austria june series a no fáber cited above and berkman v russia no december see also paragraph of the present judgment this wa not so in the present case a outlined in paragraph above dissenting opinion of judge seibertfohrjoined by judge pavli while we agree with the majority that there ha been an interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression we come to a different conclusion with respect to it necessity whereas the contracting state enjoy a certain margin of appreciation in assessing whether and to what extent an interference is necessary this margin go hand in hand with european supervision when carrying out that supervision the court must ascertain whether the impugned measure are proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued due regard being had to the importance of freedom of expression in a democratic society see perinçek v switzerland gc no december in our view it ha not been shown in the present case that it wa necessary to take and hold the applicant at a police station for several hour after the demonstration had ended let alone to impose a fine on him the government have failed to demonstrate that there were no le restrictive mean at their disposal to protect public order see glor v switzerland no echr we agree with the majority that public authority may legitimately intervene in case where public order is at stake and take action in order to avoid conflict between demonstrator and counterdemonstrator a the court ha explained in ärzte für da leben v austria no june in a democracy the right to counterdemonstrate can not extend to inhibiting the exercise of the right to demonstrate genuine effective freedom of peaceful assembly can not therefore be reduced to a mere duty on the part of the state not to interfere article sometimes requires positive measure to be taken even in the sphere of relation between individual if need be therefore state may be required to take positive measure in order to protect a lawful demonstration against counterdemonstration see also öllinger v austria no june for this reason it may be necessary to take step to deescalate tension before a real risk of inflicting bodily harm materialises see berkman v russia no december what kind of measure are permissible will depend on the particular situation at hand in fáber v hungary no july the court considered that the state had had a positive obligation to protect the right of assembly of both demonstrating group by identifying the least restrictive mean that would in principle enable both demonstration to take place in the present case the authority have failed to demonstrate that the order to remove the banner followed by the imposition of a fine on the applicant wa indeed necessary to protect public order the applicant conduct wa neither threatening nor abusive he did not hinder other participant from participating or expressing their view the reason for the applicant conviction wa the fact that he displayed a banner which wa considered provocative compare fáber v hungary cited above two participant in the event were displeased by the banner and asked for it removal see paragraph of the judgment however the applicant refusal to take the banner down did not lead to any further reaction by other participant the banner continued to be displayed until the end of the event without any further incident nonetheless the police took the applicant to a police station after the meeting had ended in their submission see paragraph the government argue that the divergence from the event programme might have provoked the participant in the public event and led to public disorder however repressive measure can not be based on such hypothetical effect inviting the police to decide on their own which view are consistent with an event programme would significantly undermine the right to freedom of expression an expression which is considered to be provocative is therefore in itself insufficient to justify intervention if provocative expression do in fact lead to a disruption of the main event or to tension with other demonstrator who consider the message of the event to be distorted preventative deescalating measure need to be considered such a separating the demonstrator on site while allowing both group an opportunity to express their view see öllinger v austria cited above in the present case however the police did not consider such preventative measure to be necessary the applicant wa not directed to an adjacent area in order to avoid tension with the other participant or to prevent the alleged distortion of the event and disruption to it participant instead the police waited until the applicant wa already on his way home before sanctioning him the course of event thus contradicts the assumption that the applicant presence rendered it difficult for the police to ensure the peaceful conduct of the event we acknowledge that during a public event the police are required to determine the appropriate measure on the basis of an ex ante evaluation of the security risk and the likelihood of disturbance however this doe not absolve the authority from pointing to concrete fact such a actual disruption prior disturbance or violent act in past event in order to establish a pressing social need to prohibit the expression of an opinion moreover based on the relevant risk assessment the police need to resort to the least restrictive measure see fáber v hungary cited above we are doubtful that the discomfort experienced by two other demonstrator with regard to the banner wa sufficient to justify the order to remove it entirely rather than asking the applicant to move to an adjacent area at a sufficient distance from the demonstrator in any event once subsequent event showed that the alleged risk of disorder the assumption of which had been hasty did not materialise there were no ground for taking the applicant to the police station after the event holding him there and sentencing him to a fine for these reason and in the absence of any demonstration of a pressing social need for the applicant conviction we would have found a violation of article in the present case

the first applicant organisation is the vienna chamber of medical doctor ärztekammer für wien the chamber represents all medical practitioner in vienna and also ha it own website the second applicant wa the chamber president at the time of the event a statement in issue and injunction proceeding on january the second applicant published a letter on the first applicant organisation website which wa addressed to all member of the chamber in vienna and wa also sent out to all of them via email the letter wa titled locust fund want to take over medical practice heuschreckenfonds wollen ordinationen übernehmen the second applicant went on to state that he had been forced to write to his colleague for a serious reason namely because it had been reported in the medium that the f company planned to go into the radiology business he added that sharebidding company planned to offer medical service initially in the area of radiology but soon enough in other area of the profession a well and that doctor risked becoming mere employee of such locust company if they would not act according to the company wish they would be dismissed the second applicant then explained the assumed legal and organisational basis of such a plan radiology service which were currently being provided by medical practice could in future also be offered by limited company share of those company could then be bought by the f company and the locust would reach their goal namely control of the medical profession giving an example of a risky development the second applicant stated that in the last year colleague had founded laboratory which had reciprocal agreement with certain health insurance board today almost all of those laboratory were owned by the f group which in turn wa owned by insurance company investment fund and foundation and which employed a large number of doctor the second applicant ended his letter by stating that he could guarantee one thing that the doctor professional representative body would make use of all legal and political mean available to stop such a disastrous development from going ahead to prevent that the quality of medical treatment being determined by manager and controller and to ensure inter alia that existing medical practice were protected from the competition from international locust fund internationale heuschreckenfonds on january the f company lodged an action against the two applicant and an application for an injunction with the vienna commercial court handelsgericht wien the applicant contested the application on february the vienna commercial court issued an injunction prohibiting the applicant each of them individually from repeating the statement that the f company wa ruthless towards third party in particular medical professional the injunction prevented the applicant from referring to the f company a a locust locust company or locust fund the applicant were further prohibited from stating that the provision of service by the f company particularly service in the area of radiology wa a disastrous development the court found that there wa a competitive relationship between the f company and the applicant and found the statement made by the applicant to be defamatory under article of the civil code and unethical under the unfair competition act bundesgesetz gegen den unlauteren wettbewerb the applicant appealed against the injunction on october the vienna court of appeal oberlandesgericht wien partly granted the appeal and prohibited the applicant from alleging that the f company wa ruthless towards third party and medical practitioner and from calling it inter alia a locust company however it dismissed the f company application to prohibit the applicant from calling it provision of service a disastrous development the court of appeal found that the first applicant organisation had locus standi in the injunction proceeding the chamber of medical doctor held official authority status in relation to certain area of it work bereich der hoheitsverwaltung in addition to representing the interest of it member it wa therefore considered a legal entity under the official liability act amtshaftungsgesetz however when acting a a special interest group it represented it member interest from a mainly economic perspective rather than acting in it capacity a an official authority according to the court of appeal the letter in issue pursued the interest of the chamber member outside the chamber official sphere of activity the court of appeal further established referring inter alia to wikipedia that the term locust company heuschreckenunternehmen wa introduced into the political discussion in german speaking country in by mr franz müntefering a german politician and is ever since used in political debate a a pejorative term for privateequity company or other form of capital fund with shortterm or exaggerated return expectation like hedge fund or vulture fund which also had negative connotation the domestic court found that there wa a need to balance the interest involved in the present debate reiterating that extreme opinion were only unlawful if they were excessive a a result of that balancing exercise the court of appeal found that the locust statement had to be considered a lawful criticism in the context of a public debate and that the f company could therefore not base it claim on article of the civil code however the court of appeal classified the applicant action a competitive in nature statement of fact made in violation of the unfair competition act could not be justified by the right to freedom of expression the court of appeal found that austrian law provided wideranging protection for commercial and economic interest those who published an opinion in an economically competitive context were obliged to exercise a higher level of diligence with regard to the fact and base of their allegation than those who acted in the noncompetitive context of a public debate of general interest therefore the court of appeal upheld the injunction decision with regard to the statement about the locust company however a regard the further statement namely that provision of certain service by the f company wa a disastrous development the court of appeal found that read in context the statement indicated a general assessment and did not refer to a particular service of the f company it wa therefore to be considered a personal opinion and thus a value judgment that wa not defamatory under article of the civil code it also did not fall under section of the unfair competition act the applicant lodged an extraordinary appeal with the supreme court oberster gerichtshof on january the supreme court dismissed the extraordinary for a wider margin of appreciation under article of the convention with regard to commercial language the commercial court observed that a competitor wa required to be more diligent in the context of greater the public interest in being properly informed and the le the statement related to commercial interest the more the statement would be protected by article of the convention in the present lodged an extraordinary appeal on point of law against that judgment which wa rejected by the supreme court on july the supreme court found that the applicant had not only called the f company a the welfare of patient herrschaft über den ärztlichen berufstand kündigung nicht spurender ärzte orientierung an ökonomischen erwägungen und damit nicht am wohl der patienten therefore the expression the specific circumstance of the case the prohibition ruled upon by the lower court wa justified even though the applicant had taken part in a debate of general public interest an untrue and damaging statement of fact wa not protected by freedom of expression furthermore the issuing of warning concerning the potential risk of the provision of medical service by company wa not a such prohibited by
