public importance and had not aimed at personally attacking prof dr b even though the domestic court had accepted that the applicant had focussed on the issue and had clarified that he had not used abusive criticism they nonetheless had by misinterpreting the actual statement construed an insult in respect of prof dr b which had exceeded the actual content of his press release the applicant further submitted that the court had insufficiently taken into account that prof dr b had been part of the public debate and had acted a an unofficial spokesperson of the scientist conducting stemcell research in germany consequently sharper criticism and mentioning him by name had been justified the government accepted that the criminal conviction had interfered with the applicant freedom of expression however they submitted that this interference had had a legal basis in article of the criminal code which had served to protect prof dr b personality right and reputation and had been necessary in a democratic society the domestic court had after analysing the text of the press release reasonably interpreted the statement a an implication that the stemcell research carried out by prof dr b had been equivalent to the human experiment performed by scientist during nazi time after weighing up the interest of the applicant against the right of prof dr b the court had ultimately found that priority should be given to protecting the personality right of prof dr b in the undertaken balancing exercise the court had taken into account that the applicant press release had been protected by the right to freedom of expression that he had had a right to express insulting criticism and that he had been contributing to a public debate however they had also considered the historical and social context of the comparison the severity of the violation of prof dr b personality right and the fact that the applicant could have made an equally important or noteworthy contribution to the debate without referring to the professor in question by name the government argued that the court had therefore taken adequate account of the applicant right and that the decision had not fallen outside the margin of appreciation a granted by the court to domestic authority the thirdpartys submission the thirdparty intervener amcb submitted that the convention granted particular protection to statement that contributed to a public debate moreover since ngo had a similar function to the press in a democratic society a public watchdog their statement required even further increased protection under article of the convention this held true also for unofficial association which expressed unpopular or minority opinion article also protected idea that offend shock or disturb and it wa the right of the person who expressed her or his opinion to choose the most efficient way to do so amcb therefore argued that comparison with the holocaust could be considered legitimate expression of opinion even when taking the historical and social context into account the court assessment at the outset the court considers and this is not in dispute between the party that the criminal conviction interfered with the applicant right to freedom of expression that it wa prescribed by law namely article of the criminal code and that it pursued the legitimate aim of protecting the reputation or right of others it therefore remains to be determined whether the interference were necessary in a democratic society the fundamental principle concerning the question of whether an interference with freedom of expression is necessary in a democratic society are well established in the court caselaw and have recently been summarised a follows see delfi a v estonia gc no june with further referencesi freedom of expression constitutes one of the essential foundation of a democratic society and one of the basic condition for it progress and for each individual selffulfilment subject to paragraph of article it is applicable not only to information or idea that are favourably received or regarded a inoffensive or a a matter of indifference but also to those that offend shock or disturb such are the demand of pluralism tolerance and broadmindedness without which there is no democratic society a set forth in article this freedom is subject to exception which must however be construed strictly and the need for any restriction must be established convincingly ii the adjective necessary within the meaning of article implies the existence of a pressing social need the contracting state have a certain margin of appreciation in assessing whether such a need exists but it go hand in hand with european supervision embracing both the legislation and the decision applying it even those given by an independent court the court is therefore empowered to give the final ruling on whether a restriction is reconcilable with freedom of expression a protected by article iii the court task in exercising it supervisory jurisdiction is not to take the place of the competent national authority but rather to review under article the decision they delivered pursuant to their power of appreciation this doe not mean that the supervision is limited to ascertaining whether the respondent state exercised it discretion reasonably carefully and in good faith what the court ha to do is to look at the interference complained of in the light of the case a a whole and determine whether it wa proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and whether the reason adduced by the national authority to justify it are relevant and sufficient in doing so the court ha to satisfy itself that the national authority applied standard which were in conformity with the principle embodied in article and moreover that they relied on an acceptable assessment of the relevant fact the court further reiterates that the right to protection of reputation is protected by article of the convention a part of the right to respect for private life see chauvy and others v france no echr vi pfeifer v austria no november and polanco torres and movilla polanco v spain no september in order for article to come into play however an attack on a person reputation must attain a certain level of seriousness and be made in a manner causing prejudice to personal enjoyment of the right to respect for private life see a v norway no april axel springer ag v germany gc no february and delfi a cited above when examining whether there is a need for an interference with freedom of expression in a democratic society in the interest of the protection of the reputation or right of others the court may be required to ascertain whether the domestic authority have struck a fair balance when protecting two value guaranteed by the convention which may come into conflict with each other in certain case namely on the one hand freedom of expression protected by article and on the other the right to respect for private life enshrined in article see hachette filipacchi associés v france no june mgn limited v the united kingdom no january axel springer ag cited above and delfi a cited above in case that require the right to respect for private life to be balanced against the right to freedom of expression the court considers that the outcome of the application should not in theory vary according to whether it ha been lodged with the court under article of the convention or under article indeed a a matter of principle these right deserve equal respect see von hannover v germany no gc no and echr the court ha already found that regardless of the forcefulness of political struggle it is legitimate to try to ensure a minimum degree of moderation and propriety and that a clear distinction must be made between criticism and insult if the sole intent of a particular form of expression is to insult a person an appropriate sanction would not in principle constitute a violation of article of the convention see genner v austria no january the court ha further differentiated between statement of fact and value judgment the classification of a statement a fact or a a valuejudgment is a matter which first and foremost fall within the margin of appreciation of the national authority in particular the domestic court see prager and oberschlick v austria april series a no while the existence of fact can be demonstrated the truth of value judgment is not susceptible of proof however even where a statement amount to a value judgment there must be a sufficient factual basis to support it failing which it will be excessive see jerusalem v austria no echr ii in addition when the court examined case concerning value judgment which the domestic court had found to be of a defamatory character it assessed whether the language used had been of an excessive or dispassionate nature and whether an intention of defaming or stigmatising the opponent had been disclosed see genner cited above turning to the circumstance of the present case the court note that the mannheim regional court classified the press release in it entirety a a value judgment and will therefore proceed on the assumption that the statement are to be considered value judgment the court observes that the domestic court understood the text of the press release a implying that the conduct of the scientist carrying out stemcell research and in particular of prof b wa seen a equivalent to the atrocity committed by the nazi the applicant challenged this understanding of his press release the court note however that the applicant press release contained a series of comparison between modernday stemcell research and experiment carried out on human during the nazi regime which culminated in the sentence the time ha finally arrived to overcome the spirit of auschwitz given these statement the court see no reason to call into question the domestic court conclusion that the applicant did indeed directly link the work of the scientist and in particular of prof dr b to the atrocity during nazi time the court further note that the allegation made by the applicant were particularly serious even if a in the instant case regarded a value judgment such serious and particularly offensive comparison demand a particularly solid factual basis compare genner cited above while the court accepts that the moral responsibility of scientist wa the issue discussed this alone doe not provide a solid factual basis for targeting personally prof b scientific work this all the more so a the comparison used wa not only shocking and disturbing but went beyond the limit of any acceptable criticism the court also note that the domestic court concluded that the focus of the press release had been on the issue and had sought to contribute to a public debate rather than defaming the individual doctor it accepts this finding but would add that the applicant nonetheless made allegation against the scientist and doctor conducting stemcell research and in particular against prof dr b the court therefore find that even though the intention behind the applicant press release wa not mainly to defame the scientist by naming prof dr b it still had a stigmatising and defaming effect in regard to the seriousness of the personal attack on the scientist and prof dr b the court reiterates that the impact an expression of opinion ha on another person personality right can not be detached from the historical and social context in which the statement wa made see annen v germany no november and hoffer and annen v germany no and january the comparison of modernday stemcell research to experiment carried out on human in concentration camp must therefore be seen in the specific context of german history the court ha previously accepted that in the light of their historical role and experience state which have experienced the nazi horror may be regarded a having a special moral responsibility to distance themselves from the mass atrocity perpetrated by the nazi see perinçek v switzerland gc no echr extract and nix v germany dec no march the court therefore concludes that the attack on prof dr b reputation wa serious and that the historical context is a weighty factor to be taken into account when assessing whether there existed a pressing social need for interfering with the applicant right to freedom of expression compare nix cited above the court also observes that prof dr b and the other scientist had by responding to the criticism voiced by bishop f entered the public debate concerning stemcell research before the publication of the applicant press release and therefore find that they could not claim the same particular protection a individual completely unknown to the public notwithstanding the fact that the applicant statement sought to contribute to a public debate and that prof dr b had entered the public stage to a certain degree the court concludes that the domestic court provided relevant and sufficient reason for the criminal conviction of the applicant the court recall that where the balancing exercise ha been undertaken by the national authority in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw the court would require strong reason to substitute it view for that of the domestic court see delfi a cited above with further reference it find that the decision by the domestic court were based on a reasonable assessment of the statement in question the right of prof dr b and of the circumstance of the present case lastly the court observes that the sanction wa criminal in nature which is in view of the existence of other mean of intervention and rebuttal particularly through civil remedy one of the most serious form of interference with the right to freedom of expression see perinçek cited above and frisk and jensen v denmark no december while the use of criminallaw sanction in defamation case is not in itself disproportionate the nature and severity of the penalty imposed are factor to be taken into account because they must not be such a to dissuade the press or others who engage in public debate from taking part in the discussion of matter of legitimate public concern ziembiński v poland no no july with further reference in that regard it note that the applicant wa sentenced to a penalty of daily fine of eur each and thereby to a sentence at the lower end of the possible criminal sanction for insult having regard to the seriousness of the violation of prof dr b personality right and the nature of the personalized attack when seen in the historical context see paragraph above the court find that the penalty appears moderate and did not fall outside of the domestic court margin of appreciation there ha accordingly been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the complaint concerning article of the convention admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on october pursuant to rule and of the rule of court claudia westerdiek yonko grozev registrar the applicant and his family having to leave liechtenstein a he wa to lose his residence permit a a foreign national without employment having regard also to the medium coverage regarding the that judgment the court reiterated that the protection afforded by article of the convention to journalist wa subject to the proviso that they acted in good faith in order to provide accurate and obey the ordinary criminal law on the basis that a journalist article affords them a castiron defence see among other authority mutatis mutandis stoll v switzerland gc no echr v bladet tromsø and exercising the right to freedom of expression the offence in question wa committed during the performance of his or her journalistic function see pentikäinen cited above furthermore all person including journalist who exercise their freedom of expression undertake duty and responsibility the scope of which depends on their situation and the technical mean they use see for example handyside v the united kingdom december in fine series a no thus notwithstanding the vital role played by the press in a democratic society journalist can not in principle be released from their duty to obey the ordinary criminal law on the basis that article affords them protection paragraph of article doe not moreover guarantee a wholly unrestricted freedom of expression even with respect to press coverage of matter of serious public concern see stoll cited above and pentikäinen cited above lastly the court reiterates that in assessing the necessity of a specific interference with the exercise of freedom of expression it ha regard to several criterion namely the assessment of the competing interest the applicant conduct the review carried out by the domestic court and the proportionality of the penalty imposed see stoll cited above pentikäinen cited above and boris erdtmann v germany dec no january ii application of these principle in the present case it should be noted at the outset that unlike other case where journalist have applied to the court under article of the convention including among many other example stoll cited above the present case doe not concern the prohibition complained of in the present case the penalty consisted of custodial sentence of one year and three month for the first two applicant and six month for the third together with the seizure of their radio equipment the court reiterates that the concept of responsible journalism requires that whenever a journalist conduct flouts the duty to abide by ordinary criminal law the journalist ha to be aware that he or she is liable to face legal sanction including of a criminal character see pentikäinen cited above in the present case while seeking to obtain information for publication in a local newspaper the applicant acted in a manner that according to domestic law and the settled approach of the court of cassation contravened criminal law which lay down a general prohibition on a person interception of any conversation not intended for him or her including those between lawenforcement officer the applicant action moreover involved a technique which they used routinely in the course file to show that they served them accordingly the penalty imposed on the applicant do not appear disproportionate the court made an appropriate distinction between the applicant duty to abide by convention i concur in the judgment however i am writing separately a i consider the reasoning adopted by the court to be somewhat too broad in substance investigative journalism is an important feature of democratic society a history ha demonstrated responsible journalism can if pursued effectively uncover information of great value for the public interest and thus promote and strengthen the fundamental democratic value of accountability and transparency a the court ha previously held the concept of responsible journalism a a professional activity which enjoys the protection of article of the convention is not confined to the content of information which is collected andor disseminated by journalistic mean that concept also embrace inter alia the lawfulness of the conduct of a journalist including his or her public interaction with the authority when exercising journalistic function importantly the mere fact that a journalist ha breached the law in his or her journalistic v although it may be undisputed that a journalist ha violated the criminal law for example a in stoll by publishing information that wa confidential the mere fact that a journalist ha acted in breach of a criminallaw provision is not the end of the matter for the purpose of the necessity and proportionality assessment which must be carried out under article of the convention otherwise contracting state would be free to subject journalist to criminal sanction whenever they came close to uncovering activity that cast those in power in an unfavourable light and would thereby subvert the vital role of the press in the functioning of a democratic society but it is clear that journalist can not claim exclusive immunity from criminal liability for the sole reason that unlike other individual exercising the right to freedom of expression they committed the offence in question during the performance of their journalistic function all person including journalist who exercise their freedom of expression undertake duty and responsibility the scope of which depends on their situation and the technical mean they use see pentikäinen v finland gc no echr and stoll cited above ii the applicant complain that the seizure of their vehicle and radio equipment and their subsequent conviction constituted a disproportionate interference with their freedom of expression within the context of their attempt to access information a journalist the court begin it inquiry by leaving open the question whether the applicant suffered an interference within the meaning of article of the convention a the it can be difficult to determine whether prepublication activity a part of investigative journalism is conduct which in itself trigger the protection of article of the convention however on the particular fact of this case i would have been comfortable in finding that article wa indeed applicable and that an interference occurred here i consider differently from my colleague see paragraph of the french version of the judgment that such a finding would have been logically consistent with the recent finding of the grand chamber in pentikäinen cited above where the court considered that the applicant in the exercise of his journalistic function had been adversely affected a he wa present at the scene a a newspaper photographer in order to report on the event when he wa apprehended by the interference pursued a legitimate aim see paragraph of the judgment at paragraph the court then correctly refers to the following stoll criterion a the framework for the analysis of the fact see my dissenting opinion in pentikäinen cited above the interest at stake the review of the measure by the domestic court the conduct of the applicant and whether the penalty imposed wa proportionate see stoll cited above however it is in the application of these criterion to the fact of the case that i find the reasoning problematic and overly broad in scope i would have applied a narrower more factsensitive analysis in the following manner firstly although i agree that the fact do not disclose the same kind of public interest a those at stake in stoll or pentikäinen the assessment should illegal activity by government official or elected representative also the fact that the newspaper is published for the benefit of a local community is irrelevant in my view also considering that the content of the news portal in question wa published online having said that even analysing the case through this narrower more factsensitive prism it nonetheless transpires that the nature of the correctly estimated that it had been necessary to balance the right to private life on the one hand and freedom of expression which contributed to a debate of public interest on the other holding that to insult to defame a person can not be justified and legitimate when one party aim to unilaterally expose in the press private litigation of a commercial nature involving two private party in assessing the existing conflict between the exercise of freedom of expression in the press and the necessity to protect the reputation and the right of others the court estimate that even though the applicant allegation made in a press article during an electoral campaign concerned a potential member of the romanian parliament thus were of public interest there are limitation to freedom of expression the applicant having been bound to act within the limit given by the public interest in protecting the reputation and the right of another person including his or her right to be presumed innocent undoubtedly when the article wa published in the newspaper f the applicant did not comply with the minimum requirement of diligence prescribed by article of the convention in the sense of convention the applicant complained that the obligation imposed on him by the domestic court to compensate mii for nonpecuniary damage had amounted to a breach of his right to freedom of expression guaranteed under article of the convention he relied in addition on article and article of the convention the court is of the view that it suffices to examine the complaint solely under article which read a follows everyone ha the right to freedom of expression this right shall include freedom to hold opinion and to receive and impart information and idea without interference by public authority and regardless of frontier this article shall not prevent state from requiring the licensing of broadcasting television or cinema enterprise the exercise of these freedom since it carry with it duty and responsibility may be subject to such formality condition restriction or penalty a are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interest of national security territorial integrity or public safety for the prevention of disorder or crime for the protection of health or moral for the protection of the reputation or right of others for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence or for maintaining the authority and impartiality of the judiciary a admissibility the court note that this complaint is not manifestly illfounded within the meaning of article a of the convention it further note that it is not inadmissible on any other ground it must therefore be declared admissible b merit argument of the party the applicant submitted that his publication of the article for which he had been found liable had pursued the aim of informing the public about mii a public person aspiring to become a parliament deputy he argued that the statement had not infringed any of the right set down in the convention being purely a manifestation of his own right to freely impart public information he further stated that he wa not challenging the proportionality of the measure but rather the sanction itself considering that the domestic court had abused their power after being influenced by the political nature of the case the government submitted that the interference had been provided for by law namely article of the civil code in force at the time see paragraph above it had been legitimate aiming at protecting the right of others and finally it had been proportionate a a fair balance had been struck between the right to reputation of a third party mii and the applicant right in that respect they argued that the statement had concerned fact of a serious nature which however had been outside the limit of political debate moreover the applicant had been unable to establish the truthfulness of what he had written although he had been given the possibility to do so lastly the sanction had not been excessive or unreasonable in support of their argument the government cited mihaiu v romania no november and ciuvică v romania dec no january the court assessment the party do not dispute the fact that the domestic court judgment amounted to an interference with the applicant exercise of the right to freedom of expression the court also find that the interference complained of wa prescribed by law namely article of the civil code in force at the time see paragraph above and pursued the legitimate aim referred to in article of the convention namely the protection of the reputation or right of others what remains to be established is whether the interference wa necessary in a democratic society when examining the necessity of an interference in a democratic society in the interest of the protection of the reputation or right of others the court may be required to verify whether the domestic authority struck a fair balance when protecting two value guaranteed by the convention which may come into conflict with each other in certain case namely on the one hand freedom of expression protected by article and on the other the right to respect for private life enshrined in article see hachette filipacchi associés v france no june and mgn limited v the united kingdom no january the court emphasis that in order for article of the convention to come into play an attack on a person reputation must attain a certain level of seriousness and it manner must cause prejudice to personal enjoyment of the right to respect for private life see a v norway no april and axel springer ag v germany gc no february where the balancing exercise between those two right ha been undertaken by the national authority in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw the court would require strong reason to substitute it view for that of the domestic court see mgn limited cited above and and palomo sánchez and others v spain gc no and others echr the relevant criterion in this regard are a the contribution made by the article to a debate of general interest b how well known is the person concerned and what is the subject of the report c the conduct of the person concerned prior to publication of the article d method of obtaining the information and it veracity e content form and consequence of the publication and f severity of the sanction imposed see axel springer ag cited above the court also reiterates that a distinction ha to be made between private individual and person acting in a public context a political figure or public figure accordingly whilst a private individual unknown to the public may claim particular protection of his or her right to private life the same is not true of public figure see minelli v switzerland dec no june and petrenco v moldova no march in respect of whom limit of critical comment are wider a they are inevitably and knowingly exposed to public scrutiny and must therefore display a particularly high degree of tolerance see ayhan erdoğan v turkey no january and kuliś v poland no march see also milisavljević v serbia no april and von hannover v germany no gc no and echr in the present case the court note that the applicant criticism wa directed at mii a candidate in parliamentary election for a national political party he wa thus a politician in respect of whom the limit of acceptable criticism are wider than in the case of a private individual see lingens v austria july series a no and satakunnan markkinapörssi oy and satamedia oy v finland gc no echr extract by standing in the parliamentary election mii entered the political scene and inevitably and knowingly laid himself open to close scrutiny scrutiny of his every word and deed by both journalist and the public at large for these reason he wa required to display a greater degree of tolerance for similar reasoning see among the most recent authority genner v austria no january nevertheless the court also note that the applicant wa sanctioned for his statement in particular his utterance of the idea that mii wa an impostor a person who wa ready to accept any compromise and betray his elector for financial advantage according to the cluj napoca court of first instance those insulting expression harmed miis reputation and dignity and should not have been made public via the medium especially because they referred to private matter see paragraph above furthermore the court took into consideration the harmful effect that the distribution by third party of electoral leaflet reproducing the content of the applicant article had had on miis reputation see paragraph above it emphasised the necessity to balance the right to private life on the one hand and the freedom of expression on the other this reasoning wa upheld by the county court which underlined the seriousness of the applicant allegation and of the act imputed to mii and considered that these statement had not been trustworthy notwithstanding the dose of exaggeration or provocation allowed in such situation see paragraph above moreover in their assessment the domestic court took into account the context in which the impugned allegation had been made namely during an electoral campaign and confirmed the fact that they had been of public interest in so far a they had concerned a public figure the court considers it relevant that in reaching the conclusion to allow in part the claim in the defamation proceeding against the applicant the domestic court considered that the latter had not intended to criticise miis activity a a public figure but rather to publicly expose a unilateral view of private litigation of a commercial nature involving two private party in this respect they also held that the applicant had not complied with the minimal requirement of diligence in the sense of acting in good faith see again paragraph above in the light of the above the court agrees with the domestic judicial authority that the impugned statement were an attack on miis reputation reaching the requisite level of seriousness and causing prejudice to personal enjoyment of his right to respect for private life under article it also find that the domestic court did undertake a satisfactory balancing exercise between the right at stake in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw furthermore they convincingly established the need for placing the protection of the defendant right to protection of reputation above the applicant freedom of expression in this context the court recall that it would require strong reason to substitute the court view for that of the domestic court see paragraph above such strong reason are lacking in the present case lastly the court observes that the applicant wa ordered to pay damage of eur see paragraph above and take note of the fact that the applicant ha not shown what his financial situation wa at the time and whether or not he struggled to pay that amount furthermore it ha not been argued let alone shown that the amount the applicant wa obliged to pay had a disproportionate impact on his financial situation in fact the applicant did not in any manner rely on the severity of the sanction but rather contested the measure itself see paragraph above the court is therefore satisfied that in the particular circumstance of the present case the imposed sanction can not be found to have been disproportionately severe see mutatis mutandis dorota kania v poland no no october and genner v austria no january and can not be considered to have been capable of having a chilling dissuasive effect on the applicant exercise of his right to freedom of expression having regard to all the foregoing factor and the margin of appreciation afforded to the state in this area the court concludes that the domestic court struck a fair balance between the applicant freedom of expression under article and miis right to have his reputation respected under article and that this assessment wa made in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw there ha accordingly been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court declares unanimously the application admissible hold by five vote to two that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on january pursuant to rule and of the rule of court marialena tsirli ganna yudkivska registrar president in accordance with article of the convention and rule of the rule of court the separate opinion of judge de gaetano and vehabović is annexed to this judgment gymtjoint dissenting opinion of judge de gaetano and vehabović we regret that we can not share the view of the majority in this case that that there ha been no violation of article of the convention in the instant case the applicant criticism wa directed at mii a candidate in parliamentary election for a national political party mii wa thus to all intent and purpose a politician in respect of whom the limit of acceptable criticism are wider than in the case of a private individual see lingens v austria july series a no and satakunnan markkinapörssi oy and satamedia oy v finland gc no june by standing in the parliamentary election mii entered the political arena and inevitably and knowingly laid himself open to close scrutiny scrutiny of his every word and deed by both journalist and the public at large for these reason he wa required to display a greater degree of tolerance see among the most recent authority genner v austria no january the applicant wa punished for his statement in particular his utterance of the idea that mii wa an impostor a person who wa ready to accept any compromise and betray his elector for financial advantage according to the cluj napoca court of first instance those statement had harmed miis reputation and dignity and should not have been made public via the medium especially because they referred to private matter see paragraph of the judgment furthermore the court took into consideration the harmful effect that the distribution by third party of electoral leaflet reproducing the content of the applicant article had had on miis reputation see paragraph however and this is crucial for our dissent the domestic court failed in our view to undertake a balancing exercise between m ii reputation and the applicant freedom of expression in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw they also attached no particular relevance to the overall context of the text the general aim of the applicant article wa to draw voter attention to the question of miis suitability to be a candidate for national public office the statement in the article therefore concerned a matter of public interest for the local community even if some of them might appear harsh or farfetched a a general rule the court considers that opinion and information pertinent to election which are disseminated during an electoral campaign should be considered a forming part of a debate on question of public interest unless proof to the contrary is offered according to the court caselaw in respect of matter of public interest restriction on freedom of expression should be interpreted narrowly see by way of example kość v poland no june furthermore we are of the view that the domestic court did not clearly ass whether the contested statement were value judgment and if they were whether there wa a sufficient factual basis for them see for example morice v france gc no echr while it is true that some of the applicant statement such a those concerning miis alleged imposture and propensity to make immoral compromise could be considered statement which lacked a sufficient factual basis the thrust of the applicant article wa to cast doubt on the suitability of a local politician for public office admittedly the applicant article and in particular the expression used could be considered a polemical involving at least a certain degree of exaggeration the court however ha stated that person taking part in a public debate on a matter of general concern are allowed to have recourse to a degree of exaggeration or even provocation or in other word to make somewhat immoderate statement see mutatis mutandis do carmo de portugal e castro câmara v portugal no october and the instant case is about exactly that we are of the view that the said expression do not amount to a gratuitous personal attack because the author supported them with an objective explanation namely the existence at the time of the article of an actual commercial dispute before the arbitration tribunal concerning miis alleged refusal to repay a loan see paragraph of the judgment moreover the court ha also held that in the field of political debate political invective often spill over into the personal sphere such are the hazard of politics and the free debate of idea which are the guarantee of a democratic society see among the most recent authority lykin v ukraine no january in the light of all this and in the absence of any pertinent reasoning provided by the domestic court in line with the court caselaw we can not consider that the applicant acted in bad faith the applicant wa moreover ordered to pay damage to the tune of eur see paragraph of the judgment the court ha repeatedly noted the chilling effect that a fear of sanction ha on the exercise of freedom of expression although the applicant ha not shown what his financial situation wa at the time and whether or not he struggled to pay that amount we are of the view that in the circumstance the sanction imposed wa capable of having a chilling dissuasive effect on the applicant exercise of his right to freedom of expression see for instance lombardo and others v malta no april and ghiulfer predescu v romania no june to sum up we are of the view that the domestic court failed to strike a fair balance between the relevant interest and to establish a pressing social need for putting the protection of miis reputation protected by article of the convention above the applicant right to freedom of expression under article of the convention and this in the context of political repartee we therefore ineluctably conclude that the interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression wa not necessary in a democratic society and that there ha accordingly been a violation of article of the convention

or allegation made by the person arrested or the circumstance of the arrest therefore i respectfully distance myself from the criticism expressed by the court in paragraph and of the judgment but the interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression we have serious doubt a to whether the police intervention and the applicant arrest were based on any statutory provision we start the demonstrator this would amount to the end of freedom of expression in public space the majority following the government argument considered the interest in public order and the prevention of crime to constitute sufficient ground for the police intervention this approach is in our view too broad because it give the police carte blanche when it come to identity check we start from the selfevident maxim that under the rule of law the police are also required to respect fundamental human right including freedom of expression according to the caselaw of this court interference with the exercise of a fundamental human right in the abstract name of public order without consideration of the necessity of such interference in a democratic society amount to a violation of article of chilling effect of similar police practice state authority may compile list of people participating in demonstration andor distributing leaflet or other material which are officially not considered freedom of expression especially in the given circumstance see kara cited above it is unfortunate that the crucial restriction which the targeted police action entailed wa obfuscated by legal formality and the alleged disobedience of police order a situation that emerged because of the disregard by the police of the applicant freedom to distribute leaflet the only reason why the police requested the identity card of the applicant and her friend wa the fact that the leaflet were being distributed by person whom the police suspected to be tayad member or supporter in our opinion this seemingly minor incident disguised a the neutral application of a neutral law in a simple situation deserves the utmost attention by the court because the exercise of a fundamental freedom can not exist without the authority showing the necessary respect and tolerance compare and contrast éva molnár v hungary no october the court must always be vigilant in ensuring that state not only safeguard the right to distribute leaflet a a manifestation of the freedom of expression protected by article of the convention but also refrain from imposing unreasonable indirect restriction on that right the essential aim of article and article of the convention is to protect the individual against arbitrary interference by public authority with the exercise of the right protected see mutatis mutandis oya ataman v turkey no december with this judgment that aim ha been dismissed

lustration in his opinion the domestic court had failed to make a distinction between factual statement and value judgment those of his statement that had allegedly infringed am right had been value judgment which had had a sufficient factual basis during the proceeding he had referred to numerous statement made by am and had insisted that his opinion had described am position towards lustration in poland despite that the court had relied on a very narrow reading of the phrase fierce defender of agent and had held that the impugned statement should have been understood a a factual statement in the applicant view this very formalistic approach on the part of the domestic court had effectively deprived him of the protection afforded by article of the convention the applicant referred to the fact that the warsaw regional court had confirmed that some of am statement might have constituted a sufficient basis for the applicant to use the expression fierce defender of agent nevertheless the court had refused to read the applicant statement in this way and had persisted with a narrow linguistic interpretation of the phrase taking all those element into account the applicant considered that his statement had not overstepped the limit of the protection afforded to him by article of the convention the government submission the government submitted that the statement in question had concerned legal case against the applicant and that therefore it had not formed part of an open discussion on matter of public concern since the applicant although a publicist had been acting a a private individual on this occasion they further considered that the domestic authority rightly qualified the applicant statement a a statement of fact rather than a a value judgment yet the applicant had failed to prove the veracity of his allegation they further noted that freedom of expression could not justify making public statement that were untrue and which infringed the personal right of others they concluded by saying that the domestic court had provided detailed reasoning for their decision furthermore the interference had not been disproportionate a the applicant had only been ordered to publish an apology and to pay pln to charity consequently the government invited the court to find no violation of article of the convention in the present case the court assessmenta the general principle the general principle for assessing whether an interference with the exercise of the right to freedom of expression is necessary in a democratic society within the meaning of article of the convention are well settled in the court caselaw they were recently restated in pentikäinen v finland gc no echr and bédat v switzerland gc no march the court must also ascertain whether the domestic authority struck a fair balance taking into consideration the margin of appreciation afforded to the contracting state between the protection of freedom of expression a enshrined in article and the protection of the reputation of those against whom allegation were made a right which a an aspect of private life is protected by article of the convention in two fairly recent case the court defined it own role in balancing these two conflicting interest it went on to identify a number of relevant criterion where the right to freedom of expression is balanced against the right to respect for private life see axel springer ag v germany gc no february and von hannover v germany no gc no and echr b application of the above principle to the present case it wa not disputed that the court decision in the present case and the sanction imposed on the applicant amounted to an interference with his right to freedom of expression a guaranteed by article of the convention such interference wa undoubtedly prescribed by law namely under article and of the civil code the court further accepts that the interference pursued the legitimate aim of protecting the reputation or right of others namely the good name reputation and credibility of am within the meaning of article of the convention accordingly the only outstanding issue is whether the interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression wa necessary in a democratic society in the instant case the applicant when commenting for rzeczpospolita on civil lawsuit against him lodged by am stated that in a way it is quite interesting to note who ha lodged civil claim against me so far two agent and one their fierce defender the domestic court examined the veracity of this statement and concluded that there wa no basis for believing that am had defended any person who had collaborated with the communistera security service the court take note of the fact that the phrase in question constituted an attack on am good name on account of his alleged indulgence for abuse committed under the communist regime such an utterance wa capable of attaining a sufficient level of seriousness in a manner causing prejudice to personal enjoyment of the right to respect for private life the domestic authority were thus faced with the difficult task of balancing two conflicting value namely freedom of expression for the applicant on the one hand and am right to respect for his reputation on the other see axel springer ag gc cited above in such case one factor the court ha taken into account is the position of the person concerned by the publication whether or not he or she wa a public figure or had otherwise entered the public scene another important factor is whether the statement in question contributed to a debate of general interest see krone verlag gmb h v austria no june in the present case the court observes that am is a former dissident a leading polish intellectual and the editorinchief of one of the country biggest daily newspaper who is actively engaged in political life and debate on current issue the court ha already held that journalist and publicist like other person actively involved in public life should display a greater degree of tolerance for criticism against them see kurski v poland no july despite the government assertion see paragraph above the court considers that the statement at issue dealt with a matter of public concern namely the lustration of journalist such a matter could and in the present case did give rise to a public debate in this respect the court reiterates that there is little scope under article of the convention for restriction on freedom of expression when a matter of public interest is at stake see couderc and hachette filipacchi associés v france gc no echr extract the court further observes that the domestic court correctly recognised the context in which the applicant allegation had been made they expressly referred to the ongoing public debate in poland about the necessity of lustration see paragraph above and even noted that had the applicant used a more general formulation his statement would have fallen within the limit of acceptable criticism see paragraph above with regard to the classification of the statement at issue the applicant argued before the domestic court that his statement had described am position towards lustration in poland see paragraph above the domestic court referring to expert opinion considered that the phrase in question had been a statement of fact see paragraph and above there is no reason to depart from this assessment even statement made in the context of a wider debate on an issue of public concern should have a solid factual basis on which to base that allegation see ärztekammer für wien and dorner v austria no february however the domestic court after carefully examining example of public statement made by am concluded that there had been no such factual basis while am had indeed been critical towards the lustration law he had never defended the two person named a agent by the applicant see paragraph and above the court doe not see a reason to find the domestic court conclusion unreasonable or arbitrary therefore the court considers that the reason given by the domestic court were relevant and sufficient finally a regard the proportionality of the sanction the court note that the applicant wa ordered to cover the cost of proceeding to pay pln approximately eur to a charity and to arrange for the publication of an apology the fee for which wa originally set at pln approximately eur but in respect of which the applicant benefitted from a substantial discount in an unknown amount the court further note that in deciding on the amount to be paid to charity the domestic court carefully weighed the possibility and determined the amount of the fine imposed on the applicant in the light of his financial situation see paragraph above it ha not been argued let alone shown that the amount the applicant wa obliged to pay had a disproportionate impact on him therefore the sanction imposed can not be found to have been disproportionate see mutatis mutandis genner v austria no january having regard to the above the court is satisfied that the authority struck a fair balance between the interest of the protection of the plaintiff reputation on the one hand and the applicant right to exercise his freedom of expression where issue of public interest are concerned on the other and that this assessment wa made in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw the interference could thus be reasonably considered necessary in a democratic society within the meaning of paragraph of article of the convention there ha accordingly been no violation of that provision for these reason the court unanimously declares the application admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in valuejudgment is a matter which first and foremost fall within the margin of appreciation of the national authority in particular the domestic court see prager and oberschlick v austria april series a no however the court can change this classification under it supervisory role see kharmalov v russia no october pinto pinheiro marque v portugal no january in previous case the court ha emphasised that the truth of value judgment is not susceptible of proof the requirement to prove the truth of a value judgment is impossible to fulfil and infringes freedom of opinion itself which is a fundamental part of the right secured by article however even where a statement amount to a value judgment there must exist a sufficient factual basis to support it failing which it will be excessive jerusalem v austria no echr ii a the court ha noted in previous case the difference lie in the degree of factual proof which ha to be established see scharsach and news verlagsgesellschaft v austria no echr xi a regard value judgment which have been found by the national court to be of a defamatory character the court ha assessed the national court finding on the question of whether the language used in the statement wa of an excessive or dispassionate nature whether an intention of defaming or stigmatising the opponent wa disclosed and if the statement wa built on a sufficient factual basis see lindon otchakovsky laurens and july v france cited above and kincses v hungary cited above the court further considers that the use of the term nazi doe not automatically justify a conviction for defamation on the ground of the special stigma attached to it see scharsach and news verlagsgesellschaft v austria no echr xi concerning the term neofascist see karman v russia no december b application of the above principle in the present case the court observes that the interference with the applicant freedom of expression wa based on article and of the criminal code that law is formulated with sufficient precision to enable a citizen to regulate his conduct and the applicant doe not provide any reasonable argument against this assumption accordingly the interference is prescribed by law the court further agrees with the government that the interference did pursue the aim of the protection of the reputation or right of others namely those of lp and the close member of her family in particular her husband which constitutes a legitimate aim within the meaning of paragraph of article see edition plon v france cited above the court like the party considers that the applicant statement concerned an issue of public interest and may be seen a a contribution to a political debate of public interest namely that concerning the situation of asylum seeker and foreigner under the then new immigration police act fremdenpolizeigesetz and the asylum act asylgesetz this intention is shown by the reporting of specific individual story of asylum seeker the court note that the domestic court classified the statement under consideration a a value judgment the court will proceed on the assumption that this classification is correct it is furthermore undisputed that lp a after her unexpected death a fact that intensified the impact of the word used the applicant statement wa published within the immediate period of her family grief and wa likely to cause considerable damage to the late minister reputation see lindon otchakovsky laurens and july v france cited above the court observes that the timing of the impugned statement is a relevant circumstance in the present case and therefore ha to be taken into consideration when balancing the conflicting right under article and the statement wa an expression of satisfaction with the sudden death of lp the applicant made the day after she had passed away to express insult on the day after the death of the insulted person contradicts elementary decency and respect to human being see edition plon v france cited above see also leroy v france no october and is an attack on the core of personality right a regard the content of the applicant statement the court considers that the applicant did not discus the subject matter in a general and substantial manner but immediately launched a personal attack on the late minister he first of all expressed satisfaction about her death suggesting that no decent human should feel grief about her passing away and then continuing by comparing her to highranking nazi official who had committed atrocity and war crime during the second world war by calling her a desk war criminal schreibtischtäterin it is true that in the statement published on january in the newspaper der standard the applicant apologised to the family of lp for his statement but even before this court he insisted that the comparison of lp to nazi war criminal had been correct and justified the court however considers that even if regarded a value judgement such serious and particularly offensive comparison immediately after lp death demand a particularly solid factual basis in this respect the court considers that the applicant did not make any distinction between the person of lp asylum law which constituted clear violation of the individual right granted by the federal constitution and the convention however the court observes that the vienna court of appeal carefully guilty of the torture of a person being detained pending expulsion the vienna court of appeal evaluated this argument and found that lp unwillingness to apologise in the republic name did not go to show that lp had ordered or at least tolerated the torture further evidence submitted by the applicant wa of a general kind regarding the political situation in austria a a whole and therefore did not provide a sufficient factual basis for the personal accusation against lp lastly the applicant submitted copy of press interview with the head of other ngo and newspaper article in order to show that his opinion that the situation of asylum seeker in austria wa constantly deteriorating wa shared by others having examined these document the court can not identify a factual basis for the motif of lp a alleged by the applicant within these same document therefore the court considers that the reason given by the court were relevant and sufficient a regard the proportionality of the sanction the court note that the applicant wa ordered to pay a fine of eur half of the fine being suspended on probation that amount appears moderate taking into account the nature of the applicant statement and the circumstance in which it wa made and disseminated therefore the penalty imposed can not be found disproportionate it follows that there ha been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the complaint admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on january pursuant to rule and the rule of court ilse freiwirth yonko grozev deputy registrar president in accordance with article of the convention and rule of the rule of court the dissenting opinion of judge guerra martin joined by judge vehabović and motoc is annexed to this judgment ygrif dissenting opinion of judge guerra martin joined by judge vehabović and motocwith all due respect to my colleague i am unable to subscribe to their view that article ha not been violated the main legal issue in this case is to ass whether the decision of the domestic court struck a fair balance between the competing right at stake the freedom of expression and the public freedom of information under article the right to respect for one private life and the right to protection of one own image under article of the convention and ruled in accordance with the criterion established by the court for that purpose it is not unusual that in case raising issue of conflict of right where a fair balance must be struck between two different right it may be difficult to draw a clear dividing line between violation and nonviolation because it depends on the weight that each person give to each individual criterion and to all of them together a for striking a balance between the freedom of expression and the right to respect for one private life the court already ha wellestablished criterion for doing so it go without saying that i do not wish to depart from those criterion accordingly i can accept the reasoning of the majority concerning some of the criterion for example the part of the judgment on how wellknown the person affected by the news wa in my opinion however the majority underestimated other criterion for instance the contribution to a debate of general interest and the veracity of the information and also overestimated others for example the lapse of time between the conviction the release and the publication of the information in short my main divergence with the majority concern the assessment of the first criterion relating to the contribution to a debate of general interest i can not accept the domestic court conclusion that publishing hs photo in a report on nh political milieu did not contribute to a debate of general interest ie the debate on the election in my view given that the article drew attention to the neo nazi past of someone who might still be close to a presidential candidate even if it is highly unlikely the public ha the right to have access to that information in principle an elector with access to all the relevant information is betterplaced and freer to choose between two or more candidate than an elector who lack that information this assertion is even more valid in the context of the election in question which had been disputed and wa subject to a decision of the constitutional court declaring the first election void the runoff ballot thus had to be repeated to put it differently while for the majority publishing hs photograph in a report on nh political milieu with an incomplete accompanying text did not contribute to the debate on the election despite the particular public interest in the report a such for me on the one hand the particular context of those election justified the broadest possible diffusion of information by the medium on the candidate and their entourage and on the other hand that context meant that it wa quite important for the public to know who might be supporting each candidate in my opinion democracy ha to protect itself from certain political party and person who want to destroy it membership of a neo nazi party is such a serious threat to democracy that the mere suspicion that a presidential candidate might have such individual among hisher supporter is ample justification for publishing the photograph in question i would take the view that the domestic court did not have regard to the importance of the medium in protecting democracy particularly where the neo nazi ideology is concerned the court attached greater importance for instance to the lapse of time between the conviction the release and the publication of the article than to the information itself for me by contrast the neo nazi past of a person who might could still have a slight connection to a politician standing for president in a democratic country even if that connection is minimal is important even if there is a long lapse of time between hisher neo nazi past and the election additionally i can not follow the majority a regard the scant importance which it attached to the veracity of the fact concentrating much more on the fact that the news wa not complete for me on the contrary the veracity of the fact is crucial the omission of some aspect doe not undermine such veracity to conclude my divergency with the majority have led me to conclude that there wa a violation of article of the convention

should not be envisaged unless there are particularly strong reason for doing so see jersild v denmark september series a no thoma v luxembourg no echr iii and verlagsgruppe news gmb h v austria no december most of the case concerned statement made by third person whose identity were known however it is important to note that the court own examination of whether there had been a violation of article of the convention involved an assessment of the news item or newspaper article a a whole in accordance with the criterion developed by it caselaw among other criterion the court looked into the question whether the reporting wa balanced and had regard to the context in which the offensive quotation had been made see for instance jersild cited above the case cited by the applicant company which related to the publication of a letter to the editor whose author could not be identified indicates that journalist or editor may also quote anonymous statement albert engelmann gesellschaft mb h cited above however the case also demonstrates that the final assessment of whether there ha been a violation of article depends on a balancing of all relevant criterion the court did not share the domestic court view that the fact that the letter to the editor had been an anonymous one wa of relevance it finding of a violation of article in that case wa mainly based on the consideration that the offending statement contained in the anonymous letter were value judgment which had a sufficient factual basis in statement which the claimant himself had previously made ibid in the present case a ha already been noted above there had been no allegation against cm and jm before the publication of the anonymous letter and there is no indication that their own conduct provided any factual basis for the value judgment contained in the anonymous letter which were thus no more than a gratuitous attack on their reputation in these circumstance the court accepts that there were strong reason for considering that the publication of the anonymous letter transgressed the limit of permissible reportinge content form and consequence of the publication in respect of the content form and consequence of the publication the domestic court had regard to the fact that the impugned article in the bezirksblatt had not only reported on the anonymous letter in the context of the upcoming election of the chairman of the local tourism association but had reproduced the anonymous letter and thus had disseminated it to a far larger public than the restricted circle of initial recipient see paragraph and above they also referred to the negative repercussion cm and jm had experienced in their professional life a practising lawyersf severity of the sanction imposed the court note that the sanction imposed namely the order to pay compensation of eur to each of the claimant and to publish the regional court judgment is not of a degree of severity which would render the interference disproportionateg overall conclusion the foregoing consideration are sufficient to enable the court to conclude that the domestic court duly applied the criterion established by the court caselaw when ordering the applicant company to pay compensation to cm and jm under article of the medium act they gave relevant and sufficient reason for arriving at the conclusion that while the publication of the article itself contributed to a debate of general interest reproduction of the anonymous letter amounted to defamation the court doe not see any strong reason to substitute it own view for that of the contested decision of the domestic court there ha accordingly been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the application admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on october pursuant to rule and of the rule of court andré wampach isabelle berro lefèvre deputy
