adding that corruption of a prison officer on the scale present in the applicant case undermined public confidence in the prison service see paragraph above these consequence were considered to be serious none of the conclusion by the domestic court can be said to have been unforeseeable or surprising lastly the description of the seriousness test itself in attorney general reference no of tends to suggest that the scope and scale of the behaviour in question could be a relevant factor when assessing seriousness in the present case a the trial judge and the court of appeal pointed out see paragraph and above the applicant disclosed information to a newspaper in exchange for payment on forty occasion over a period of five year in flagrant breach of rule of which he wa well aware in particular in his sentencing remark the judge emphasised the very serious breach of trust which had occurred in the case when imposing a custodial sentence of twenty month imprisonment the applicant ha argued that his behaviour ought to have been sanctioned only in disciplinary proceeding rather than by way of a criminal prosecution the court observes that conduct doe not fall outside the scope of the criminal law merely because it also constitutes a disciplinary offence a noted above the applicant placed some reliance on the law commission work see paragraph above the court observes that the law commission final report identifies a concern a to legal certainty from the perspective of article but this is limited to the definition of public office the applicant did not contest that this criterion wa evidently satisfied in his case see paragraph and above in any event the report recognises that the classification of public office is clear for civil servant a category which included the applicant while the report also note that the nature of the seriousness threshold ha led to concern that the offence is being prosecuted in circumstance not sufficiently blameworthy a to justify criminal consequence this is clearly not the case here a explained in the preceding paragraph the domestic court in the applicant case pointed to the serious nature of his offending the court doe not exclude that there may be case in which given their specific fact prosecution and conviction for misconduct in public office were arguably not foreseeable however for the reason outlined above it doe not consider the applicant prosecution and conviction to be such a case in conclusion the court is satisfied that the applicant ought to have been aware if necessary after having sought legal advice that by providing internal prison information to a journalist in exchange for money on numerous occasion over a fiveyear period he risked being found guilty of the offence of misconduct in public office there ha therefore been no violation of article of the convention alleged violation of article of the convention the applicant complained that the disclosure of his identity by mgn to the police and his subsequent prosecution and conviction violated his right to protection a a journalistic source under article of the convention which provides everyone ha the right to freedom of expression this right shall include freedom to hold opinion and to receive and impart information and idea without interference by public authority and regardless of frontier the exercise of these freedom since it carry with it duty and responsibility may be subject to such formality condition restriction or penalty a are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interest of national security territorial integrity or public safety for the prevention of disorder or crime for the protection of health or moral for the protection of the reputation or right of others for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence or for maintaining the authority and impartiality of the judiciary the court considers it appropriate to examine each of these two complaint separately the disclosure of the applicant identity admissibilityc the party submission the government submitted that article did not apply to the mere provision by mgn and receipt by the police of voluntary information they underlined that the disclosure had been voluntary there had been no compulsion involved they argued that it would be inimical to the right and freedom of a democratic society were a journalist unable to disclose criminal wrongdoing to the police or the police unable to rely on voluntary disclosure made by journalist moreover in their view there wa no freestanding right of anonymity for a source under the convention the protection afforded by article in this respect wa accorded only to the journalist accordingly the government submitted the disclosure of the applicant name to the police did not engage article the applicant argued that the right of a source not to be identified by a journalist wa a necessary corollary of the right of the journalist not to disclose the source and therefore an inseparable element of the protection afforded by article by asking for and receiving information about his identity the police had acted incompatibly with his article right moreover the disclosure by mgn had not been truly voluntary since the company had acted under pressure to avoid a corporate prosecution he argued that the disclosure of his name without any prior review of the proposed disclosure by an independent body amounted to an interference with his right to speak out but remain anonymousd the court assessment in the absence of a court order compelling disclosure of the applicant identity the court must examine whether the complaint is compatible ratione persona with the provision of the convention within the meaning of article a of the convention the applicant position wa that the disclosure by mgn wa not voluntary but resulted from improper pressure from the police and wa therefore akin to the compelled disclosure by the state of his name a a journalistic source the court can not accept this argument a the court of appeal pointed out the reference by the trial judge to the motivation of mgn in assisting the police can not be equated to a finding that pressure wa put on mgn to disclose the applicant name see paragraph above even though the mo u did not expressly refer to article it term allowed mgn to refuse to disclose information on article ground including the right to protect journalistic source see paragraph and above mgn enjoyed access to legal advice and a the court of appeal found it is inconceivable that they did not give careful consideration to whether to make disclosure to the police in the context of the publicity which operation elveden and the leveson inquiry were attracting in these circumstance the court accepts the finding of the court of appeal that the disclosure wa truly voluntary see paragraph above in the absence of any compulsion on mgn to disclose the applicant name the applicant ha failed to demonstrate that the disclosure wa attributable to the respondent state in particular it can not be said that merely by requesting the information agreeing an mo u or accepting receipt of the information the police interfered with the applicant article right the applicant complaint concerning the disclosure of his information is accordingly incompatible ratione persona with the provision of the convention and must be declared inadmissible pursuant to article a the prosecution and conviction of the applicant admissibility in imparting information to the journalist in this case the applicant could assert his right to freedom of expression his prosecution and conviction for disclosing the information amounted to an interference with his article right the court is therefore of the opinion that the complaint raise sufficiently complex issue of fact and law so that it can not be rejected a manifestly illfounded within the meaning of article a of the convention and is not inadmissible on any other ground it must therefore be declared admissible meritse the party submissionsi the applicant the applicant argued that the decision to prosecute him and to refuse his application for abuse of process and no case to answer violated his article right given the circumstance of the disclosure of his name to the police he contended that the offence wa vague and his prosecution on the basis of his action had not been foreseeable at the time he carried them out he also argued that there had been a clear public interest in the information he had provided and that disclosure of the information had not been harmful he claimed that he had taken step to raise his public interest concern at the prison on numerous occasion but that no action had been taken causing him to finally resort to providing information to a journalist to highlight these important issue he disputed that the information had been received by him in confidence or that it disclosure had been harmful he underlined the chilling effect that the prosecution and conviction had had on freedom of expression his treatment would leave source concerned that without more their identity could be disclosed to the police by journalist and discourage them from contacting the mediaii the government the government submitted that any interference because of the applicant prosecution or his conviction had been justified under article the criminal offence of misconduct in public office wa accessible and foreseeable and thus prescribed by law for the reason advanced in respect of the article complaint see paragraph above any interference wa also necessary in a democratic society in the interest of public safety for the prevention of disorder or crime for the protection of health or moral for the protection of the reputation or right of others and for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence the government pointed out that the applicant had committed a serious offence and that the information he had provided had been principally received in confidence consisting to a large extent of private information about prisoner and staff obtained in the course of his duty it disclosure had had a harmful impact on staff and prisoner and a negative effect on safety security and order within the prison it had also been in flagrant breach of duty the public interest in free speech had been carefully considered at each stage of the process the mo u had allowed mgn to withhold the information on public interest ground the decision to prosecute had been reviewed by the cps in the light of emerging clarification from the court of appeal a to the public interest defence available and public interest wa a defence to the charge itself which would have resulted in the applicant acquittal had it been made out the applicant had been prosecuted and convicted precisely because his conduct did not fall within this defence the jury verdict represented a finding of fact that the applicant conduct had not been in the public interestf the court assessmenti general principle article expressly protects the freedom to receive and impart information and idea without interference by public authority the necessity of any restriction on freedom of expression must be convincingly established it is for the national authority to ass in the first place whether there is a pressing social need for the restriction and in making their assessment they enjoy a certain margin of appreciation see goodwin v the united kingdom march report of judgment and decision ii the court task in exercising it supervisory function is not to take the place of the national authority but rather to review the case a a whole in the light of article and consider whether the decision taken by the national authority fell within their margin of appreciation the court must therefore look at the interference and determine whether the reason adduced by the national authority to justify it were relevant and sufficient ibid it is clear from the court caselaw that freedom of expression is of particular relevance to the press whose duty it is to impart in a manner consistent with it obligation and responsibility information and idea on all matter of public interest see bédat v switzerland gc no march accordingly the safeguard to be afforded to the press a part of it right to freedom of expression are of particular importance see sanoma uitgevers bv v the netherlands gc no september and goodwin cited above the court ha explained that the most careful scrutiny under article is required where measure or sanction imposed on the press are capable of discouraging the participation of the press in debate on matter of legitimate public concern see bladet tromsø and stensaas v norway gc no echr iii and time newspaper ltd v the united kingdom no and no and echr accordingly a particularly narrow margin of appreciation will normally be accorded where the remark concern a matter of public interest see bédat cited above furthermore the court ha confirmed that under article the signalling by an employee in the public sector of illegal conduct or wrongdoing in the workplace should in certain circumstance enjoy protection this is particularly true where the employee concerned is the only person or part of a small category of people aware of what is happening at work and is thus best placed to act in the public interest by alerting the employer or the public at large see guja v moldova gc no echr and goryaynova v ukraine no october in such circumstance the court must enquire into whether there existed any alternative channel or other effective mean for the applicant to remedy the alleged wrongdoing such a disclosure to the person superior or other competent authority or body which the applicant intended to uncover see guja cited above ii application of the general principle to the fact of the case the court ha no doubt that the prosecution and conviction of the applicant were prescribed by law within the meaning of article it ha already found that the offence for which he wa prosecuted wa sufficiently clear and foreseeable in the circumstance of his case see paragraph above the court further accepts that the prosecution and conviction of the applicant pursued the aim cited by the government namely the interest of public safety the prevention of disorder or crime the protection of health or moral the protection of the reputation or right of others and the prevention of the disclosure of information received in confidence a to whether the applicant prosecution and conviction were necessary in a democratic society the court note that the applicant conduct spanned a period of five year over the course of which he provided story in exchange for payment on forty occasion this conduct wa a the trial judge concluded in flagrant breach of the rule which applied to him a a prison officer and constituted a very serious breach of trust see paragraph above the applicant did not dispute before the court of appeal a the trial judge had found that he wa aware of the rule and he accepted that his conduct had amounted to a disciplinary offence see paragraph above there can therefore be no doubt that the applicant knowingly engaged in a course of conduct contrary to the requirement of his public office and that the scope and scale of his unlawful conduct wa significant the court also attache significant weight in this context to the serious harm caused to other prisoner to staff and to public confidence in the prison service a a result of the applicant behaviour see paragraph above there wa therefore a strong public interest in prosecuting him in order to maintain the integrity and efficacy of the prison service and the public confidence in it on the other hand the domestic court noted that there wa no public interest in the majority of the information disclosed by the applicant nor had he been primarily motivated by publicinterest concern in his sentencing remark the judge recorded the applicant own concession in evidence that on a number of occasion he had disclosed information when the public interest had had nothing at all to do with what he wa disclosing see paragraph above the judge found a fact that the applicant had been motivated by money and by an intense dislike of the prison governor see paragraph above the court of appeal having set out the article for which the applicant had been the source and after careful consideration of the nature of those article likewise noted that there wa no public interest in the disclosure see paragraph above since the applicant moreover did not claim before this court to have acted a a whistleblower a defined in the court caselaw see paragraph above there is no need for the court to enquire into the kind of issue which ha been central in the above caselaw on whistleblowing namely whether there existed any alternative channel or other effective mean for the applicant to remedy the alleged wrongdoing which the applicant intended to uncover compare guja cited above the court would nonetheless observe in this respect that the sentencing judge pointed to the fact that a a tradeunion representative the applicant could have used official channel to disseminate information had public interest been his sole concern see paragraph above in conclusion the reason for the applicant prosecution and conviction were relevant and sufficient and no violation of article is disclosed for these reason the court unanimouslydeclares the complaint under article and the complaint under article in so far a it concern the applicant prosecution and conviction admissible declares the remainder of the application inadmissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on july pursuant to rule and of the rule of court ilse freiwirth yonko grozev deputy registrar president

the applicant wa born in and life in góis a background of the proceeding at the relevant time the applicant wa a chief corporal in the national republican guard guarda nacional republicana working at the góis territorial post on november the applicant sent an email to the general inspectorate of internal administration inspecção geral da administração interna on the subject suspected misuse of money in which he made reference to an alleged misuse of money by commander mc of the arganil territorial post in accordance with what he had heard in a conversation with colleague at the arganil territorial post he asked the general inspectorate to investigate the alleged fact stating a follows in the month of december the coimbra national republican guard territorial group distributed money to the territorial post of it area of command for the christmas dinner the only member of the military in arganil who attended the dinner were the commander of the post and corporal m the total amount of money that had been given to the military from the territorial post to pay for the dinner wa paid to the restaurant manager in exchange for a receipt it seems that the commander ha since then been going with his family to the mentioned restaurant where the cost of his meal is deducted from the money that wa not spent on the above dinner note i have just become aware of this matter through rumour within the military of the mentioned post who claim that they have not reported the situation for fear of reprisal and because of that fear of reprisal i ask you for secrecy during the investigation because i am also a member of the military on an unknown date the general inspectorate of internal administration forwarded the email to the general command of the national republican guard comando geral da guarda nacional republicana and to the lousã public prosecutor office ministério público on an unknown date the lousã public prosecutor office opened an investigation into the applicant allegation on february the lousã public prosecutor office discontinued the proceeding on the ground that following investigation by the criminal investigation police policía judiciária it had found no evidence of the criminal offence denounced by the applicant the general inspectorate of internal administration also conducted an inquiry into the applicant allegation on june the inquiry wa discontinued the general command of the national republican guard also started an internal inquiry into the allegation on december on december commander mc wa heard in that respect he then became aware of the email of november and it content on february the inquiry wa converted into disciplinary proceeding against commander mc at the request of the official in charge of the inquiry on the ground that the management of the cafeteria of the arganil territorial post showed sign of lack of transparency which required further investigation on july the disciplinary proceeding against commander mc were discontinued on the ground that there wa insufficient evidence to take disciplinary action the decision to discontinue the disciplinary proceeding also took into account the decision of the lousã public prosecutor office to discontinue the criminal proceeding against commander mcb criminal proceeding against the applicant on april commander mc lodged a criminal complaint before the lousã public prosecutor office accusing the applicant of defamation he alleged that the applicant email had disseminated injurious statement about him on july the public prosecutor brought charge acusação against the applicant for aggravated defamation on the ground that the statement made in his email called into question commander mc honesty honour and professional reputation which the applicant had intentionally attacked on september commander mc lodged a claim for damage against the applicant in the amount of euro eur in a judgment of january the lousã criminal court convicted the applicant of aggravated defamation and sentenced him to eighty dayfines totalling eur euro the applicant wa also ordered to pay eur in damage to commander mc the court described it finding of fact and the manner in which it had assessed the evidence and held a follows since the existence of such a rumor ha not been proved in any way the court is fully convinced that the defendant intention wa to undermine the honour of the offended party once he knew that this wa just a rumour and that therefore he wa making an allegation that wa not true the allegation made in the defendant complaint by it content put into question the offended party honesty honour and professional reputation a commander of a territorial post of the national republican guard which wa well known to the defendant the defendant ha therefore acted in a free voluntary and conscious way with the achieved aim of attacking the offended party honour and personal and professional reputation the disclosure of irregular situation ha to be seen a a duty a the performance of an obligation when it fall within the competence and responsibility of the whistleblower and when it doe not go beyond the fact which were effectively observed whistleblowing can not be used a a basis to cast suspicion which can not be supported by any factual element in the instant case the defendant accuses the offended party of fact which are objectively dishonorable without having any evidence to substantiate them indeed by submitting that the offended party and his family were using the existing credit to have dinner at the mentioned restaurant the defendant knew that he wa accusing the offended party of a dishonorable deed all the more because he knew that the offended party wa in charge of the national republican guard arganil territorial post he further knew that the allegation wa inconsistent with the truth and that he could easily have clarified it authenticity with the restaurant owner through such conduct the defendant acted of his own free will and in the knowledge that his action were not allowed on an unknown date the applicant appealed against the judgment to the coimbra court of appeal in particular he contested the established fact a in his opinion he had not acted with the intention of attacking commander mc honour and reputation on september the coimbra court of appeal upheld the firstinstance court decision it considered that there were no reason to change the fact established by the firstinstance court and a such no reason to reach a different conclusion with regard to the applicant guilt and conviction c disciplinary proceeding against the applicant on august the general command of the national republican guard instituted disciplinary proceeding against the applicant on february the official in charge of the inquiry within the disciplinary proceeding against the applicant submitted a final report in which he concluded that the applicant had breached his duty the relevant passage of the report read a follows the defendant breached the duty of loyalty a being on duty and being part of the góis territorial post in the quality of deputy commander of the post he did not inform his hierarchical superior in clear disregard of the functional hierarchy principle of the act allegedly committed in the report it wa also taken into account that the applicant allegation had been investigated by different authority all of which had discontinued their investigation additionally it had regard to the fact that the applicant had been convicted by the domestic court in the criminal proceeding against him the report further analysed the existence of a fine which commander mc had imposed on the applicant before the latter had sent the impugned email however the official responsible for the report considered that fact to be innocuous and irrelevant on march at the request of the official responsible for the disciplinary proceeding the general command imposed on the applicant a disciplinary sanction consisting of suspension from duty for six day it enforcement being suspended for a period of twelve month according to the material submitted in the case file it seems that the applicant did not lodge an appeal against the disciplinary sanction with the minister of home affair ii relevant domestic lawa relevant provision of the portuguese criminal code article anyone who when addressing a third party accuses another even if the accusation take the form of a suspicion or make a judgment that cast a slur on the honour or reputation of the other even when reproducing the accusation or judgment shall be liable on conviction to a maximum of six month imprisonment or dayfines article provides that if the reporting agent ha not complied with his duty to verify the information he ha disclosed he will not be deemed to have acted in good faith article of the criminal code increase the sentence by half if the victim is an agent of authority b relevant provision of the statute of the military service of the national republican guard law decree no of november article other duty serviceman of the national republican guard also have the following dutiesi to refrain from making statement which could affect the cohesion and reputation of the national republican guard or which are in breach of the hierarchic and disciplinary principle c regulation on the disciplinary conduct of the national republican guard law no of september in force at the material time article duty of loyalty in the exercise of their duty of loyalty serviceman of the guard shalla truthfully inform their hierarchical superior about any issue related to their job when requested to do sob when the issue doe not fall within their competence communicate immediately to their hierarchical superior any servicerelated fault or act on the part of other serviceman which are against express legal provision c in submitting a petition request complaint or any other similar written statement ensure that it is sent to the competent authority and always through the hierarchical channel the lawalleged violation of article of the convention the applicant complained under article and of the convention that his conviction by the domestic court for aggravated defamation had infringed his right to freedom of expression the court being master of the characterisation to be given in law to the fact of the case will consider this complaint solely under article of the convention which read a follows everyone ha the right to freedom of expression this right shall include freedom to hold opinion and to receive and impart information and idea without interference by public authority and regardless of frontier this article shall not prevent state from requiring the licensing of broadcasting television or cinema enterprise the exercise of these freedom since it carry with it duty and responsibility may be subject to such formality condition restriction or penalty a are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interest of national security territorial integrity or public safety for the prevention of disorder or crime for the protection of health or moral for the protection of the reputation or right of others for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence or for maintaining the authority and impartiality of the judiciary a admissibility the court note that the application is not manifestly illfounded within the meaning of article a of the convention it further note that it is not inadmissible on any other ground it must therefore be declared admissible b merit the party submission the applicant submitted that his right to freedom of expression had been breached in that he had been convicted for denouncing an alleged misuse of public money within the national republican guard he maintained that he had acted in good faith in disclosing the suspicion of alleged misuse of money a the veracity of the rumour could only be proved by mean of an investigation the only reason for his disclosure wa to have the alleged fact investigated the applicant acknowledged that he could have used the existing channel within the internal hierarchy of the national republican guard to make the disclosure however he contended that the disclosure wa made by email to an authority which had competence within the ministry of home affair to investigate the alleged fact a such he had complied with the chain of command he concluded that demanding that the disclosure of information be made only within the hierarchy of the general republican guard would limit freedom of expression referring to the case of heinisch v germany no echr the government contended that the protection of the workplace afforded by article of the convention could be guaranteed only when a disclosure of information wa made in good faith and favoured the internal channel of disclosure they considered that the allegation reported by the applicant could have been an issue of public interest given that the alleged misuse of public money wa at stake however the applicant allegation were based on a rumour which wa none the le investigated by three different entity and not proved the government submitted that the duty of loyalty wa particularly binding on serviceman in the national republican guard who were subject to special duty arising from the disciplinary regulation to which they were bound the applicant wa subject to a chain of command and should have disclosed the allegation to his hierarchical superior namely the commander of his territorial post or the commander of the territorial unit there were internal channel of disclosure which where used had been proven effective lastly the government submitted that past event the fact that the applicant had allegedly been fined by commander mc and that there wa a poor relationship between commander mc and the serviceman working at the arganil territorial post could lead to suspicion that the applicant may have felt some animosity towards commander mc the court assessment it ha not been disputed that the applicant conviction by the domestic court for aggravated defamation constituted interference by the public authority with his right to freedom of expression under the first paragraph of article of the convention such interference will constitute a breach of article unless it wa prescribed by law pursued one or more legitimate aim under paragraph and wa necessary in a democratic society for the achievement of those aim the court observes that the applicant conviction wa based on article and article of the portuguese criminal code and pursued the legitimate aim of protecting commander mc reputation it remains to be ascertained whether the interference wa necessary in a democratic society a the principle established by the court caselaw the court reiterates that freedom of expression constitutes one of the essential foundation of a democratic society and one of the basic condition for it progress and for each individual selffulfillment subject to paragraph of article it is applicable not only to information or idea that are favourably received or regarded a inoffensive or a a matter of indifference but also to those that offend shock or disturb such are the demand of pluralism tolerance and broadmindedness without which there is no democratic society a set forth in article this freedom is subject to exception which must however be constructed strictly and the need for any restriction must be established convincingly the general principle for assessing the necessity of an interference with the exercise of freedom of expression have been summarised recently in pentikäinen v finland gc no echr and bédat v switzerland gc no march the court further reiterates that the protection of article of the convention extends to the workplace in general and to the public service in particular see among other authority guja v moldova gc no february furthermore under the court caselaw the signaling by an employee in the public sector of illegal conduct or wrongdoing in the workplace should in certain circumstance enjoy protection this may be called for where the employee concerned is the only person or part of a small category of person aware of what is happening at work and is thus best placed to act in the public interest by alerting the employer or the public at large see guja cited above and heinisch v germany no july the court is at the same time mindful that employee owe to their employer a duty of loyalty reserve and discretion in the light of these duty disclosure should be made in the first place to the person superior or other competent authority or body it is only where this is clearly impracticable that the information can a a last resort be disclosed to the public in assessing whether the restriction on freedom of expression wa proportionate the court must therefore take into account whether the applicant had any other effective mean of remedying the wrongdoing which he or she intended to uncover see guja cited above heinisch cited above the court also reiterates that when it is called upon to rule on a conflict between two right that are equally protected by the convention it must weight up the interest at stake the state is called upon to guarantee both right and if the protection of one lead to an interference with the other to choose adequate mean to make this interference proportionate to the aim pursued in this context the court accepts that the state ha a wide margin of appreciation see fernández martínez v spain gc no echr in the present case the court must ascertain whether the domestic authority struck a fair balance between on the one hand the applicant right to freedom of expression under article and on the other the protection of reputation of commander mc a right which a an aspect of private life is protected by article of the convention see couderc and hachette filipacchi associés v france gc no november in this regard the court task is not to take the place of the national court but rather to review under article in the light of the case a a whole the decision they have taken pursuant to their discretionary power see stankiewicz and others v poland no no november b application of the above principle to the present case turning to the fact of the present case the court agrees with the government position that the applicant allegation could concern an important question of public interest the possible misuse of public money by a civil servant see paragraph above it note that the defamation claim originated in the applicant correspondence with the general inspectorate of internal administration which forwarded the applicant email to the general command of the national republican guard and to the lousã public prosecutor office in his email the applicant alleged that commander mc had been misusing public money he claimed that his intention wa to prompt an investigation into the allegation which he admitted were based on a rumour see paragraph above in order to ass the justification of a statement which is in issue a distinction must be made between statement of fact and value judgment while the existence of fact can be demonstrated the requirement to prove the truth of a value judgment is impossible to fulfil and infringes freedom of opinion itself which is a fundamental part of the right secured by article see among other authority pinto pinheiro marque v portugal no january the court considers that in the present case the applicant allegation constituted a statement of fact for a civil servant working for a lawenforcement authority the accusation that he misused public money wa a particularly serious one capable of affecting his reputation and to an even larger extent that of the national republican guard thus even if the applicant had intended to prompt an investigation he had to have a factual basis on which to base his allegation however he based his allegation on a mere rumour and had no evidence to support them the court therefore concludes that the domestic court finding that he had not acted in good faith see paragraph above wa proportional and justified in this regard the situation differs from that examined by the court in the case bargão and domingo correia v portugal no and where the applicant believed that the information disclosed wa true and were able to prove it ibid in fact the applicant knowing that his allegation were based on a rumour made no attempt to verify their authenticity before reporting them to the general inspectorate of internal administration the court note that the applicant had no evidence to support his allegation and that none of the three different entity which investigated them were able to establish their veracity additionally none of the three entity established that commander mc had committed a criminal act or had acted unlawfully see paragraph above the court further note that in the criminal proceeding against the applicant the domestic court were not able to establish the existence of the rumour which had given rise to the applicant allegation see paragraph above a to the addressee of the disclosure the court observes that the applicant wa aware that he had internal channel within the hierarchy of the national republican guard to which he could have reported the rumour namely a pointed out by the government the commander of his territorial post or the commander of the territorial unit see paragraph above notwithstanding that he did not convincingly explain why he did not disclose the allegation to a superior by not doing so the applicant did not comply with the chain of command and denied his hierarchical superior the opportunity to investigate the veracity of the allegation in the light of the above the instant case ha therefore to be distinguished from case of justified information of the superior or whistleblowing an action warranting special protection under article of the convention compare with guja and heinisch both cited above finally a regard the proportionality of the sanction the court note that the applicant wa ordered to pay a fine of dayfines eur plus eur in damage to commander mc those amount appear very moderate taking into account the gravity of the applicant allegation the harm caused to mc and the fact that the applicable maximum fine wa daysfine according to article and of the criminal code therefore the sanction imposed can not be found disproportionate having regard to the above consideration the court considers that the reason advanced by the domestic court in support of their decision were relevant and sufficient and that the interference wa not disproportionate to the legitimate aim pursued namely the protection of reputation the interference could thus be reasonably considered necessary in a democratic society within the meaning of paragraph of article of the convention therefore the court see no serious reason to substitute it own assessment for that of the domestic court which examined the question at issue with care and in line with the principle laid down by the court caselaw accordingly there ha been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the application admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on june pursuant to rule and of the rule of court marialena tsirli andrás sajóregistrar president

journalistphotographer working for a weekly magazine he had been assigned the task of covering a demonstration held in helsinki against the asia europe meeting asem it wa a political demonstration with economic undertone and by finnish standard an exceptionally large one the government themselves described it a an event of considerable public importance there wa unsurprisingly strong medium interest the authority expecting such interest made provision for a separate area from which journalist might follow event and take whatever photograph they could that area would presumably afford them some safety and comfort especially if it proved necessary for the police to take unpleasant suppressive measure the measure would not have been regarded a one meant to keep journalist at bay so that while they would have a fair view of general development they would not be able to spot or adequately distinguish incident occurring anywhere in the middle of the demonstration or at the far end instead one might reasonably have thought that the use of the area wa optional and that a journalist had freedom to move around and mingle with demonstrator in order to get a better understanding of event to obtain statement from participant and in the case of a photographer to take closeup which sometimes speak volume a it turned out journalist were denied this freedom according to prior intelligence there wa a risk of the demonstration turning violent and unfortunately it did the demonstration started at pm and after half an hour the police considered that it had become a riot they took measure to suppress it initially for about fortyfive minute no one wa allowed to leave save for a few individual then in furtherance of an order to disperse the police created exit route through which people could go on condition of showing an identity card and having their belonging checked shortly after pm only some twenty person remained at the scene the police called on them to leave and warned them that unless they did so they would be arrested the applicant wa among them still covering the event there is no indication that there wa at that stage a threat to public order the riot had already been quelled that is not to say of course that the police order ceased to have relevance a regard the demonstrator but the applicant wa not one of them and it ha never been suggested that he did anything inconsistent with his journalistic duty the applicant say that he did not expect that the order would apply to him a well at that stage he spoke about the matter with a colleague over the phone and asked for advice on whether he should leave or stay he decided to stay so a to cover the situation until it wa completely resolved he wa then arrested together with the others he claim that he wa wearing his press badge and had made his identity known according to the government he had not revealed his identity to the arresting officer but when taken to the police bus he showed both his id and his press badge however that made no difference at all section of chapter of the penal code a amended provides that the police may issue an order for the maintenance of public order or security or the performance of a duty and that to disobey would constitute contumacy towards the police a criminal offence punishable by a fine or by imprisonment for up to three month in the present case the order issued orally by the police could also have been orally revoked or varied according to what the circumstance might have required the object of the order wa to restore peace by dispersing the crowd in a controlled way it is surprising that it should have been thought that it could also apply to a journalist who wa lawfully present and covering the event in the context of his medium duty and that it could lead to his arrest the criminal court before which the applicant jointly with many others wa charged under the aforesaid provision simply found that he had been aware of police order that they had been clear and had covered everyone including him and that he had decided not to comply the domestic court having briefly considered article of the convention found that there had been an interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression that the interference had a lawful basis and pursued a legitimate aim namely preventing disorder and that the interference had been necessary for the purpose of putting an end to a violent situation still it may be noted that the situation had already been effectively dealt with by the time the applicant wa arrested the court found the applicant guilty a charged however it did not impose a sentence it regarded the offence a excusable because it considered that the applicant a a journalist must have faced a dilemma between his duty to his employer and the obligation imposed on him by the police order consequently by law the conviction wa not to be entered on the applicant criminal record thus the applicant wa first required to obey the police order and then when he failed to do so he had to be arrested and kept in detention for seventeen and a half hour it is to be noted that the domestic court never said that the arrest and detention were wrong or unnecessary subsequently the applicant had to be prosecuted and to stand trial and to be convicted of a criminal offence in the domestic court view all of that had been right and proper and well deserved but on the other hand the applicant would suffer no further consequence because the offence wa excusable the majority are content with that conclusion the applicant brought an appeal complaining inter alia that the trial court had not given reason why his arrest and conviction were necessary in a democratic society he wa obviously right in what he indicated but his appeal wa rejected without the court of appeal itself giving reason the supreme court refused leave for a further appeal it is not known why it seems to me that it wa only natural that the situation a it developed would heighten journalistic interest there wa nothing improper about that where a demonstration is peaceful the journalist function is essentially one of collecting and transmitting information and quite often adding comment but when tension build up and violence break out whereupon the authority resort to suppressive control measure the journalist assumes the role of public watchdog and his task then acquires even greater significance a to this role of the press see for example barthold v germany march series a no he is entitled to be in the very thick of thing until the very end and sometimes doe so at considerable risk to himself the reason is because in a democratic society the public have the right to know what happens during such difficult time this right form one of the basic safeguard of democracy hardly a day pass by when we are not made aware in one way or another of the need for journalistic freedom to perform that kind of role the domestic court view that the applicant wa inevitably faced with a dilemma a to where his loyalty lay and that this dilemma could only be resolved by giving precedence to the law quite miss the point it doe not in my respectful view reflect the true nature of the situation in which the applicant found himself he wa not one of the demonstrator he wa a journalistphotographer covering what the government themselves have described a an event of considerable public importance how could the police fail to realise the capacity in which the applicant wa present at the scene particularly at a stage when he wa with a very small remaining group a to whether he wa wearing his medium badge and whether he made his identity known to the police in good time i have already referred to the controversy on this point the domestic court made no finding on the matter but a i have noted it wa accepted that his identity wa established before he wa put on the police bus to the police station and further one might ask whether the applicant while locked up had not asserted his identity and remonstrated about spending the night in a cell there is a nagging question and it is this did the police really care whether the applicant wa a journalist or not the fact that he wa prosecuted tends to suggest that they did not it may also be added that if the police or the court were to have taken the view that the applicant prosecution should have been disconnected from his arrest and detention they would have been expected to look at these aspect separately and to give relevant explanation but they did not the majority take the view in line with the government position that the fact that the applicant wa a journalist did not give him a greater right to stay at the scene than the other people see paragraph of the judgment this aspect is seen a connected with the question of necessity the majority say paragraph that since these legal and legitimate order were not obeyed the police were entitled to arrest and detain the disobedient demonstrator but the applicant wa not a demonstrator and no one ha ever suggested that he wa the majority seem to be saying that since the applicant chose to stay among the demonstrator and not to use the area reserved for the press he should accept the same fate see paragraph and again referring to the question of necessity the majority say see paragraph that a to the necessity the court found that it had been necessary to disperse the crowd because of the riot and the threat to the public safety and to order people to leave thus the restriction on the applicant freedom of expression were justified i would respectfully observe that the majority conflate the meaning of the undoubted necessity to quell the riot with what the domestic court also saw a the necessity of compliance with a police order irrespective of it essence and it rationale an order which led to the imposition of restriction on a journalist freedom of expression through his arrest detention prosecution and conviction for a criminal offence simply because he had the courage to do his duty in furtherance of the public interest the majority speak of an analysis of article of the convention carried out by the domestic court my own understanding is that at least in the case of the applicant there wa no real analysis at all and that the domestic court judgment wa more by way of declaration than based on reasoning it ha not been substantiated why it wa necessary in a democratic society to equate a professional journalist operating within recognised professional limit in covering the demonstration with any of the people taking part in the demonstration and to impose drastic criminal restraint on him i consider that the order should not have been intended or interpreted a directed against the applicant a a journalist covering the event in question since his presence wa not connected with what needed to be countered and resolved i also consider that if the domestic court were unable to adopt such an interpretative approach they were bound in applying article of the convention to balance the competing interest involved yet they failed to do so it is incumbent on the national authority to convincingly establish by relevant and sufficient reason that curtailing press freedom is necessary in the sense that it meet a pressing social need see among many authority cumpănă and mazăre v romania gc no echr xi the court caselaw concerning the protection of journalistic source illustrates the court concern in this regard see goodwin v the united kingdom march report of judgment and decision ii and subsequent case such a tillack v belgium no november and voskuil v the netherlands no november which are particularly instructive in the latter case a journalist who wa called a a witness in criminal proceeding refused to name his source even when the judge ordered him to do so he wa punished by detention for noncompliance the court found a violation of article it held that the judicial order wa not justified by an overriding requirement in the public interest and so in balancing the competing interest the interest of a democratic society in securing a free press had to prevail there is no indication that any such balancing exercise wa carried out in the present case on the contrary the case reveals a onesided attitude on the part of the authority one likely to create a chilling effect on press freedom for the reason i have set out i regret that i am unable to follow the majority
