conjunction with article relying on article and of the convention the applicant complained that he wa dismissed from the military for his opinion and in a discriminatory manner the relevant part of article read a follows everyone ha the right to freedom of expression this right shall include freedom to hold opinion and to receive and impart information and idea without interference by public authority and regardless of frontier the exercise of these freedom since it carry with it duty and responsibility may be subject to such formality condition restriction or penalty a are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interest of national security territorial integrity or public safety for the prevention of disorder or crime for the protection of health or moral for the protection of the reputation or right of others for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence or for maintaining the authority and impartiality of the judiciary article of the convention read a follows the enjoyment of the right and freedom set forth in the convention shall be secured without discrimination on any ground such a sex race colour language religion political or other opinion national or social origin association with a national minority property birth or other status a the party submission the applicant the applicant complained of a violation of his right to freedom of speech he maintained that a a serviceman he had been responsible for many year for giving legal advice to the commander of the armed force on the question of statutory penalty his opinion on the statutory penalty the army imposed on soldier often did not correspond to that of others at the ministry of defence the applicant stated that he had made many proposal with the aim of improving inter alia serviceman procedural right when the new army disciplinary statute wa being drafted a his superior and the state president had failed to take his proposal into account the applicant had contacted the kauno diena daily and expressed his idea to the press the internal inquiry into his communication with the daily had been started the same day even though that inquiry had later been discontinued by the authority acknowledgement that the applicant had not violated military discipline the appeal to kauno diena and to the state president had had direct consequence for the applicant he wa dismissed from professional military service before the expiry of his contract most importantly in order to avoid accusation of interference with freedom of expression the authority at the ministry of defence chose to dismiss him not on the ground that he had appealed to the medium but formally on the basis of article of lm thus leaving no official trace of injustice if that provision had been applied to others in the same manner several hundred soldier would have been dismissed from service however none of them except the applicant had suffered the same consequence the example of four soldier rl v jš and mi he relied on during the administrative court proceeding confirmed that there were more soldier who should have been dismissed from the army but that this wa not done lastly he also challenged a misleading the two example provided by the government see paragraph and above the applicant then asserted that the interference with his right to express his opinion had no basis in lithuanian law nor wa it justified by any of the ground listed in article of the convention because his publicly expressed criticism over the staff reform had not disclosed any classified information or posed a threat to the state security the applicant dismissal from professional military service wa nothing other than revenge for his public appeal in the medium the government the government maintained at the outset that there had been no interference with the applicant right to freedom of expression because he had not experienced any negative effect in relation to the publication in kauno diena they noted that the majority of case examined by the court under article of the convention had involved either final criminal conviction or civil decision against a person in the instant case however the internal inquiry into the applicant action regarding the publication although opened on the very same day a that of the publication march wa discontinued on march on the ground that the act committed by him did not constitute a disciplinary violation of the statute of military discipline because he had acted within the bound of his right to impart information in accordance with article of lm a mere internal inquiry into the applicant action which in itself did not create any consequence for the applicant therefore could not be considered a constituting an interference with the right to freedom of expression even if the court assumed that the mere opening of an internal inquiry could be seen a interference the government considered that it wa authorised by inter alia article of lm which establishes certain restriction associated with military service including public expression of disagreement with policy being implemented by the government of a democratically elected state the opening of the internal inquiry into the applicant act pursued a legitimate aim in the interest of national security and for the prevention of disorder lastly the inquiry wa necessary and proportionate given that the applicant criticism of the new statute of military discipline had been expressed publicly and not internally see e v germany dec no november and grigoriades v greece november report of judgment and decision vii the government also considered that even if the court did see the applicant discharge from the military a an interference with the exercise of his right to freedom of expression that presumption would be incorrect the government categorically rejected any such consideration because the applicant had been discharged in accordance with the domestic law for having reached retirement age and not because of the criticism he had expressed in the article in kauno diena the government also pointed out that in the domestic proceeding concerning his discharge the applicant had raised his allegation of discrimination only very briefly while in essence disputing the interpretation and application of article of lm however having regard to the interpretation of that provision by the administrative court in the applicant case a well a in other relevant caselaw the applicant wa discharged from the military in accordance with the domestic law and there wa no ground to allege any possible discrimination in any regard the government further questioned the applicant argument that four other serviceman rl v jš and mi had had to be discharged from the military because of their age but had nevertheless continued to serve on this point the government referred to the domestic law and fact relating to the service history of those four officer see paragraph above in this connection the government also saw it a relevant to provide the court with two example which in their view were analogous to the applicant case where the serviceman were discharged from professional military service on the ground of their age despite the fact that they still had valid military service contract see paragraph and above finally the administrative court had been consistent in interpreting article of lm a having the effect that once a serviceman reached the age of retirement this wa an imperative ground to terminate his military service see paragraph and above above all that interpretation also remained consistent in the applicant case b the court assessment admissibility the court considers that the applicant complaint are not manifestly illfounded within the meaning of article a of the convention no other ground for declaring them inadmissible ha been established they should therefore be declared admissible merit the court ha held on numerous occasion that freedom of expression constitutes one of the essential foundation of a democratic society and one of the basic condition for it progress and for each individual selffulfilment subject to paragraph of article it is applicable not only to information or idea that are favourably received or regarded a inoffensive or a a matter of indifference but also to those that offend shock or disturb such are the demand of that pluralism tolerance and broadmindedness without which there is no democratic society freedom of expression a enshrined in article is subject to a number of exception which however must be narrowly interpreted and the necessity for any restriction must be convincingly established see vogt v germany september series a no with further reference article doe not stop at the gate of army barrack it applies to military personnel a it doe to all other person within the jurisdiction of the contracting state nevertheless a the court ha previously indicated it must be open to the state to impose restriction on freedom of expression where there is a real threat to military discipline a the proper functioning of an army is hardly imaginable without legal rule designed to prevent serviceman from undermining it it is not however open to the national authority to rely on such rule for the purpose of frustrating the expression of opinion even if these are directed against the army a an institution see grigoriades cited above see also vereinigung demokratischer soldaten österreichs and gubi v austria december series a no the government argued that there had been no violation of the applicant right to freedom of expression because he had not experienced any negative effect from the publication in the kauno diena newspaper on this point the court indeed note that the internal inquiry into the applicant action regarding that publication and his address to the state president were terminated on the ground that the applicant had acted within the boundary of article of lm and no disciplinary sanction wa imposed on him see paragraph above the court therefore considers that a far a it concern that inquiry in itself in view of it outcome the applicant can not claim to be a victim of a violation of the convention however it will nevertheless take that investigation into account when examining the main issue in the present case namely whether the applicant military service wa terminated solely a a result of the legal necessity to discharge him because of his age a the government claimed or whether a the applicant argued he wa dismissed because of his opinion the court find that although the sequence of event the applicant critical remark in kauno diena the internal investigation into his action a disciplinary penalty for failing to give proper legal advice see paragraph above and eventually the decision to start the procedure to discharge him because of his age assessed in it entirety might appear to corroborate the applicant version of event this doe not allow the court to conclude with certainty that the applicant wa punished for his opinion and that termination of his military service wa not simply the result of a proper application of article of lm see by converse implication ivanova v bulgaria no april in previous case the court ha indeed found that disciplinary sanction for public remark see e v germany cited above or even prosecution and conviction of the soldier see grigoriades cited above had been a clear indication of an interference with the right to impart idea at variance with article of the convention however in the instant case such tangible indication are absent unlike the fact in ivanova no new requirement for the applicant post which he did not meet had been introduced after the publication in kauno diena none of the applicant superior in the army had made public statement to the effect that he should be discharged from the military because of his opinion see in contrast and mutatis mutandis kosiek v germany august series a no it is also noteworthy that the obligation to terminate contract when the retirement age is reached had been confirmed by the supreme administrative court in it earlier ruling of and see paragraph and above which preceded the applicant case by some three year and thus illustrate the established practice of the domestic court the applicant also sought support for his claim of discrimination from the military service record of four soldier of his unit rl v jš and mi he considered that those four soldier had been in a similar situation to that of himself but had been treated differently on this point the court reiterates that article of the convention affords protection against different treatment without an objective and reasonable justification of person in similar situation see hoffmann v austria june series a no c and vojnity v hungary no february however having given due consideration to the fact paragraph above it is the court opinion that such an assertion is not substantiated the professional military service history of those four serviceman show that each of them wa entitled to serve until the expiry of their contract despite the fact that they had reached retirement age because unlike the applicant they had military specialist code conversely a the applicant himself acknowledged during the court proceeding at the time of his discharge from the army he had no such status see paragraph and above in view of the above the court find that the applicant discharge from professional military service once he had reached retirement age did not amount to interference with the exercise of his right to freedom of expression see harabin v slovakia no november there ha therefore been no violation of article of the convention taken alone or in conjunction with article thereof iii other alleged violation of the convention citing article and article of protocol no to the convention the applicant lastly brought forward a series of grievance which may be summarised a a complaint that his discharge from the army breached the principle of liberty and security caused him pecuniary damage and wa not examined by the ombudsman the court ha examined the remainder of the applicant complaint a submitted by him however having regard to all the material in it possession it find that these complaint do not disclose any appearance of a violation of the right and freedom set out in the convention or it protocol it follows that this part of the application must be rejected a manifestly illfounded pursuant to article and of the convention iv application of article of the convention article of the convention provides if the court find that there ha been a violation of the convention or the protocol thereto and if the internal law of the high contracting party concerned allows only partial reparation to be made the court shall if necessary afford just satisfaction to the injured party a damage the applicant claimed that after his dismissal from the military service before the expiry of his contract he suffered pecuniary damage because he received a lower pension he asked that the government be ordered to review the sum paid for his pension and compensate the unpaid part or alternatively to award him euro eur the applicant further claimed that he had received no salary food allowance or housing allowance which all together were equal to lithuanian lit ltl approximately eur lastly the applicant claimed eur for nonpecuniary damage he had suffered because of the internal inquiry into his contact with the medium and the court unwillingness to defend his human right the government considered that the pecuniary and nonpecuniary damage claimed by the applicant were absolutely unsubstantiated and excessive the court doe not discern any causal link between the violation found and the pecuniary damage alleged it therefore reject this claim on the other hand it award the applicant eur in compensation for nonpecuniary damage b cost and expense the applicant made no claim for cost and expense the court therefore make no award under this head c default interest the court considers it appropriate that the default interest rate should be based on the marginal lending rate of the european central bank to which should be added three percentage point for these reason the court unanimously declares the applicant complaint under article and admissible and the rest of the application inadmissible hold that there ha been a violation of article of the convention hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention taken alone or in conjunction with thereof holdsa that the respondent state is to pay the applicant within three month from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with article of the convention eur six thousand euro plus any tax that may be chargeable in respect of nonpecuniary damage to be converted into lithuanian lit at the rate applicable at the date of settlementb that from the expiry of the abovementioned three month until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amount at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the european central bank during the default period plus three percentage point dismisses the remainder of the applicant claim for just satisfaction done in english and notified in writing on november pursuant to rule and of the rule of court stanley naismith guido raimondi registrar president

the applicant wa born in and life in weinheim he is a campaigner against abortion and operates an antiabortion website babycaustde at the time of the proceeding outlined below the website included among other thing the following content on the starting page a picture of graf wa shown and the text underneath read then holocaust upon clicking on the picture the user wa directed to a page titled abortion the new holocaust on which the holocaust wa compared to abortion on the left margin of the starting page there were several link of which one wa called life or death upon clicking on it the user wa directed to a page with the headline prayer request for germany from that page the reader wa directed to a locationbased alphabetical list mentioning the name and practice address of doctor who performed abortion in germany and to a request for prayer for those doctor at the very bottom of the same page under the highlighted text german contemporary history in brief a sentence read perverted doctor murder unborn child at the request of the mother pervertierte ärzte ermorden im auftrag der mütter die ungeborenen kinder on the same page clicking on the button close page forwarded the user to a page where it wa stated pray if possible regularly for the doctor who personally undertake the aggravated murder of abortion killing beten sie wenn möglich regelmäßig für die mediziner welche den mord der abtreibungstötung selbst vornehmen emphasis in original somewhat farther down on the same page it wa stated that counselling centre that issued certification are enabling and facilitating the unpunished aggravated murder of child in their mother womb ermöglichen und begünstigen einen straffreien kindermord im mutterschoβ one of the doctor listed on the applicant website dr q sought a civil injunction ordering the applicant to remove his name and address from the website on may the mannheim regional court rejected dr q application on the ground that it wa a fact that dr q performed abortion and that the remainder of the website content wa covered by the applicant freedom of expression it observed in particular that the present case wa not comparable to similar case which had concerned an interference with personality right by the distribution of personalised leaflet the publishing of a doctor name on a list of abortion performing doctor had no comparable pillory effect subsequently dr q appealed and during the appeal proceeding modified his application seeking a civil injunction ordering the applicant to desist from labelling abortion such a those performed by dr q aggravated murder on february the karlsruhe court of appeal granted the sought injunction the court held that the applicant website led it to be understood that abortion performed by dr q constituted aggravated murder while the term aggravated murder did not have to be understood in a merely legal sense but could also be understood a a moral judgment the overall presentation of the website at the very least did not exclude a reading that dr q had perpetrated the criminal offence of aggravated murder even though the applicant had pointed out that abortion were exempt from punishment he had not referred to section a of the criminal code see paragraph below which exempted abortion a performed by dr q from criminal liability in addition the applicant had emphasised the term aggravated murder in the relevant part of the website and had compared abortion with the holocaust in sum the statement of the website could be understood a a personalised accusation against dr q of perpetrating aggravated murder on may the federal court of justice refused a request by the applicant for legal aid on the ground that the applicant intended appeal on point of law lacked sufficient prospect of success on july the federal constitutional court refused to admit a complaint by the applicant for adjudication for being inadmissible without providing reason no bv r ii relevant domestic law and practice article of the german basic law grundgesetz read in so far a relevant a follows every person shall have the right freely to express and disseminate his opinion in speech writing and picture and to inform himself without hindrance from generally accessible source these right shall find their limit in the provision of general law in provision for the protection of young person and in the right to personal honour the relevant provision of the german criminal code strafgesetzbuch read article aggravated murder whosoever commits aggravated murder shall be liable to imprisonment for life a murderer under this provision is any person who kill a person for pleasure for sexual gratification out of greed or otherwise base motif maliciously or cruelly or by mean that pose a danger to the public or in order to facilitate or to cover up another offence article abortion whosoever terminates a pregnancy shall be liable to imprisonment of not more than three year or a fine act the effect of which occur before the conclusion of the nidation shall not be deemed to be an abortion within the meaning of this law in especially serious case the penalty shall be imprisonment from six month to five year an especially serious case typically occurs if the offender act against the will of the pregnant woman or through gross negligence cause a risk of death or serious injury to the pregnant woman if the act is committed by the pregnant woman the penalty shall be imprisonment of not more than one year or a fine the attempt shall be punishable the pregnant woman shall not be liable for the attempt article a exception to liability for abortion the offence under section shall not be deemed fulfilled if the pregnant woman request the termination of the pregnancy and demonstrates to a doctor by certificate in accordance with section nd sentence that she obtained counselling at least three day before the operation the termination of the pregnancy is performed by a doctor and not more than twelve week have elapsed since conception the termination of pregnancy performed by a doctor with the consent of the pregnant woman shall not be unlawful if considering the present and future living condition of the pregnant woman the termination of the pregnancy is medically necessary to avert a danger to the life or the danger of grave injury to the physical or mental health of the pregnant woman and if the danger can not reasonably be averted in another way from her point of view the federal constitutional court in it leading judgment of may bverf ge accepted abortion being performed by doctor after a pregnant woman had obtained counselling by a third person and developed a rather singular approach by qualifying certain act of abortion a unlawful but not punishable abortion which are performed without the establishment of a medical indication must not be treated a being justified not unlawful schwangerschaftsabbrüche die ohne feststellung einer indikation nach der beratungsregelung vorgenommen werden dürfen nicht für gerechtfertigt nicht rechtswidrig erklärt werden however abortion performed by a doctor within twelve week of conception and following obligatory counselling are considered to be unlawful but are exempt from criminal liability the relevant provision of the conflict in pregnancy act schwangerschaftskonfliktgesetz read a follows section refusal nobody is obliged to assist in abortion the relevant provision of the german civil code bürgerliches gesetzbuch read a follows article a person who intentionally or negligently unlawfully injures the life body health freedom property or another right of another person is liable to pay compensation to the other party for the damage arising from this article if the ownership is interfered with by mean other than removal or retention of possession the owner may require the disturber to remove the interference if further interference are to be feared the owner may seek a prohibitory injunction according to the caselaw of the german civil court article and in conjunction with article in analogous application of the civil code grant any person whose personality right concretely risk being violated by another person a claim to compel that other person to refrain from performing the impugned action the lawalleged violation of article of the convention the applicant complained that the court of appeal order to desist from labelling abortion aggravated murder on his webpage had violated his freedom of expression a provided in article of the convention which read a follows everyone ha the right to freedom of expression this right shall include freedom to hold opinion and to receive and impart information and idea without interference by public authority and regardless of frontier the exercise of these freedom since it carry with it duty and responsibility may be subject to such formality condition restriction or penalty a are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society for the protection of the reputation or right of others a admissibility the court note that this complaint is neither inadmissible for nonexhaustion of domestic remedy see annen v germany no november nor manifestly illfounded within the meaning of article a of the convention it further note that it is not inadmissible on any other ground it must therefore be declared admissible b merit the party submission the applicant argued that the court of appeal desist order had interfered with his freedom of expression without being justified by the protection of the personality right of dr q he submitted that his website had contributed to a public debate and he had not personally attacked dr q who had been only one of the doctor listed on the website an overall assessment of the website showed that his intention had not been to slander a particular doctor but to criticise the legal situation in germany under which abortion performed by a doctor within twelve week of conception and following obligatory counselling were considered to be unlawful but were exempt from criminal liability in the light of his contribution to a public debate of great importance possible interference with doctor personality right had been justified the government submitted that the injunction by the court of appeal had not violated the applicant freedom of expression the court had carefully weighed the applicant freedom of expression against the right of the doctor concerned arising from article of the convention in doing so it had recognised the importance of the applicant freedom of expression especially within the context of the public debate about abortion within the scope of it margin of appreciation the court of appeal had come to the compelling conclusion that the content of the applicant website had been such a serious violation of dr q personality right a to justify a restriction on the applicant freedom of expression the government further argued that unlike in the case of annen cited above the karlsruhe court of appeal had carried out an extensive analysis of the content of the website and had documented part of it with screen shot in doing so it had sufficiently examined the applicant statement in the light of the right to freedom of expression and had also addressed alternative possibility of interpretation a a result the court had concluded that in characterising the medical activity of dr q a aggravated murder and equating them with the holocaust the applicant had committed a serious personal attack and had therefore violated dr q personality right the court assessment at the outset the court considers and this is not in dispute between the party that the injunction interfered with the applicant freedom of expression had a legal basis and pursued the legitimate aim of protecting the right and reputation of dr q it therefore remains to be determined whether the interference wa necessary in a democratic society and whether the balancing exercise undertaken by the domestic court wa in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw the fundamental principle concerning the question of whether an interference with freedom of expression is necessary in a democratic society are well established in the court caselaw and have recently been summarised a follows see delfi a v estonia gc no june with further referencesi freedom of expression constitutes one of the essential foundation of a democratic society and one of the basic condition for it progress and for each individual selffulfilment subject to paragraph of article it is applicable not only to information or idea that are favourably received or regarded a inoffensive or a a matter of indifference but also to those that offend shock or disturb such are the demand of pluralism tolerance and broadmindedness without which there is no democratic society a set forth in article this freedom is subject to exception which must however be construed strictly and the need for any restriction must be established convincingly ii the adjective necessary within the meaning of article implies the existence of a pressing social need the contracting state have a certain margin of appreciation in assessing whether such a need exists but it go hand in hand with european supervision embracing both the legislation and the decision applying it even those given by an independent court the court is therefore empowered to give the final ruling on whether a restriction is reconcilable with freedom of expression a protected by article iii the court task in exercising it supervisory jurisdiction is not to take the place of the competent national authority but rather to review under article the decision they delivered pursuant to their power of appreciation this doe not mean that the supervision is limited to ascertaining whether the respondent state exercised it discretion reasonably carefully and in good faith what the court ha to do is to look at the interference complained of in the light of the case a a whole and determine whether it wa proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and whether the reason adduced by the national authority to justify it are relevant and sufficient in doing so the court ha to satisfy itself that the national authority applied standard which were in conformity with the principle embodied in article and moreover that they relied on an acceptable assessment of the relevant fact the court further reiterates that the right to protection of reputation is protected by article of the convention a part of the right to respect for private life see chauvy and others v france no echr vi pfeifer v austria no november and polanco torres and movilla polanco v spain no september in order for article to come into play however an attack on a person reputation must attain a certain level of seriousness and be made in a manner causing prejudice to personal enjoyment of the right to respect for private life see a v norway no april axel springer ag v germany gc no february and delfi a cited above in case that concerned allegation of criminal conduct the court also took into account that under article of the convention individual have a right to be presumed innocent of any criminal offence until proved guilty see among other authority worm v austria august report of judgment and decision v and du roy and malaurie v france no echr x when examining whether there is a need for an interference with freedom of expression in a democratic society in the interest of the protection of the reputation or right of others the court may be required to ascertain whether the domestic authority have struck a fair balance when protecting two value guaranteed by the convention which may come into conflict with each other in certain case namely on the one hand freedom of expression protected by article and on the other the right to respect for private life enshrined in article see hachette filipacchi associés v france no june mgn limited v the united kingdom no january axel springer ag cited above and delfi a cited above although opinion may differ on the outcome of a judgment where a balancing exercise wa undertaken by the national authority in conformity with the criterion laid down in the court caselaw the court would require strong reason to substitute it view for that of the domestic court see lillo stenberg and sæther v norway no january with reference to axel springer ag cited above and von hannover v germany no gc no and echr turning to the circumstance of the present case the court note at the outset that the court of appeal in contrast to the court in the case of annen v germany no november assessed the website with reference to the situation at the relevant time the court therefore concludes that the legal protection received by the applicant at the domestic level wa compatible with the procedural requirement of article of the convention a regard the balancing of the applicant freedom of expression and the doctor personality right the court acknowledges like the court of appeal that the applicant statement addressed question of public interest it further observes that the court of appeal held that the applicant had stated on his website that the medical activity performed by dr q had constituted aggravated murder and examined in detail how the term aggravated murder had to be understood it concluded that the content of the website had been ambiguous and that the statement could be understood a a personalised accusation against dr q of having perpetrated the criminal offence of aggravated murder it therefore concluded that the applicant statement could be understood a statement of fact since the statement were evidently incorrect the court of appeal ordered the injunction the court reiterates that the classification of a statement a a fact or a a value judgment is a matter which in the first place fall within the margin of appreciation of the national authority in particular the domestic court see prager and oberschlick v austria april series a no having regard to the screenshots of the website provided by the government the applicant statement and the presentation of these statement the court find the classification by the court of appeal acceptable the court also agrees with the court of appeal conclusion that the applicant statement could be understood a an accusation that dr q had perpetrated the criminal offence of aggravated murder the court of appeal reasoned that the applicant had not made it sufficiently clear that doctor providing abortion in accordance with article a of the criminal code had been exempted from criminal liability therefore the present case ha to be distinguished from the case of annen cited above which concerned a leaflet of the applicant in which he had called abortion unlawful but had clearly provided an additional explanation that they had not been subject to criminal liability in the present case however the applicant did not provide such additional information but merely stated that abortion constituted aggravated murder and mentioned only once that they were unpunished see paragraph above this singular reference in the context of counseling centre could easily go unnoticed and did not have to be understood a elaboration of the legal situation in germany according to which doctor providing abortion in accordance with article a of the criminal code were exempted from criminal liability concerning the factual foundation for the applicant statement the court note that the applicant argued neither before the domestic court nor before the court that the abortion performed by dr q constituted aggravated murder in the legal sense of article of the criminal code the court therefore concludes that there wa no factual foundation whatsoever for the allegation that dr q committed the criminal offence of aggravated murder the court would further add that even where a statement amount to a value judgment there must be a sufficient factual basis to support it failing which it will be excessive see jerusalem v austria no echr ii consequently the court find that even assuming that the applicant statement were to be considered value judgment there wa not a sufficient factual basis for calling abortion a performed by dr q aggravated murder in that context the court also note that the accusation were not only very serious something reflected in the fact that a conviction for aggravated murder would carry a life sentence but might also incite to hatred and aggression lastly the court observes that the applicant wa not criminally convicted for slander or ordered to pay damage contrast pedersen and baadsgaard v denmark gc no echr xi but that the applicant wa only ordered to desist from labelling abortion such a those performed by dr q aggravated murder and to desist therefore from implying that dr q wa committing that criminal offence having regard to the foregoing and in particular to the seriousness of the accusation against dr q the court considers that the injunction wa not disproportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and that the reason given by the court of appeal were relevant and sufficient the interference with the applicant exercise of his right to freedom of expression could therefore reasonably be regarded by the domestic court a necessary in a democratic society for the protection of the reputation and right of others there ha accordingly been no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously declares the complaint concerning article admissible hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention done in english and notified in writing on september pursuant to rule and of the rule of court claudia westerdiek yonko grozev registrar president

the applicant is a lawyer who also writes article for various russian law journal and online legal information database and network according to the applicant his work usually requires extensive scientific research including in the field of law enforcement in the khabarovsk region he supported his assertion with copy of contract with wellknown russian publishing house and owner of a number of legal magazine including one supervised by the secretariat of the president of the russian federation under the contract he undertook the task of writing article on specific topic of legal and social interest having received an assignment to write an article on prostitution and the fight against it in the khabarovsk region on may the applicant wrote to the head of the khabarovsk region police department by registered letter asking for statistical data for his research the relevant part read i am interested in receiving information for the period between and in particular information on the number of people found administratively liable under article of the code of administrative offence prostitution with a breakdown by sex residence resident of the khabarovsk region or visitor nationality national of the russian federation foreigner or stateless person and the year of the offence information on the number of criminal case instituted during the abovementioned period under article and case related to sexual exploitation of the criminal code with a breakdown of the specific article and the year the case wa opened information on the number of individual found criminally liable under article and of the criminal code with a breakdown by sex age educational background permanent residence resident of the khabarovsk region or visitor nationality and period in which the crime wa committed general information on sentence imposed on individual found criminally liable under article and of the criminal code the type of sentence and in how many case they were imposed and the year they were imposed i stress that i do not need any specific personal information about individual found administratively or criminally liable i only need general statistical information for writing a scientific article it appears from an acknowledgement of receipt that the letter reached the khabarovsk region police department on may under russian law state official must provide a reply to letter from individual within thirty day in the absence of any response on june the applicant lodged a claim with the tsentralniy district court of khabarovsk the district court complaining that the police authority had failed to provide him with the information he had requested and requesting for access relying on the information act see below and article of the convention he argued that the official implied refusal to provide him with the information had been unlawful a he had not asked for access to any confidential personal information state secret or information related to internal government that the impugned measure wa taken a few month after the beginning of the applicant release on licence following his participation in a peaceful demonstration outside agen prison in support of basque prisoner who were held there which participation had attracted medium coverage the court also understands why in that context the judicial authority might have feared that the applicant would place himself in a position conducive to possible recidivism it therefore accepts having regard to the situation prevailing in the basque country see association ekin cited above that the restriction complained of pursued one of the aim listed in article namely prevention of disorder or crime the fundamental principle a regard the necessity in a democratic society of an interference with the exercise of freedom of expression are well established in the court caselaw and may be summarised a follows see among other authority hertel v switzerland august case report vi steel and morris v the united kingdom no echr ii mouvement raëlien suisse v switzerland gc no echr animal defender international v the united kingdom gc no echr morice v france gc no april and delfi a v estonia gc no echr i freedom of expression constitutes one of the essential foundation of a democratic society and one of the basic condition for it progress and for each individual selffulfilment subject to paragraph of article it is applicable not only to information or idea that are favourably received or regarded a inoffensive or a a matter of indifference but also to those that offend shock or disturb such are the demand of pluralism tolerance and broadmindedness without which there is no democratic society a set forth in article this freedom is subject to exception which must however be construed strictly and the need for any restriction must be established convincingly ii the adjective necessary within the meaning of article implies the existence of a pressing social need the contracting state have a certain margin of appreciation in assessing whether such a need exists but it go hand in hand with european supervision embracing both the legislation and the decision applying it even those given by an independent court the court is therefore empowered to give the final ruling on whether a restriction is reconcilable with freedom of expression a protected by article iii the court task in exercising it supervisory jurisdiction is not to take the place of the competent national authority but rather to review under article the decision they delivered pursuant to their power of appreciation this doe not mean that the supervision is limited to ascertaining whether the respondent state exercised it discretion reasonably carefully and in good faith what the court ha to do is to look at the interference complained of in the light of the case a a whole and determine whether it wa proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and whether the reason adduced by the national authority to justify it are relevant and sufficient in doing so the court ha to satisfy itself that the national authority applied standard which were in conformity with the principle embodied in article and moreover that they relied on an acceptable assessment of the relevant fact in leroy cited above relating to the publication of a satirical drawing in a basque weekly magazine and zana cited above referred to by the government the court pointed out that those principle apply to measure taken by national authority to maintain national security and public safety a part of the fight against terrorism and that it must with due regard to the circumstance of each case and a state margin of appreciation ascertain whether a fair balance ha been struck between the individual fundamental right to freedom of expression and a democratic society legitimate right to protect itself against the activity of terrorist organisation these consideration are relevant to the present case mutatis mutandis the court ha also emphasised that although article doe not a such prohibit prior restraint on publication or ban on distribution of information or idea the danger which restriction of that kind pose for a democratic society are such that they call for the most careful scrutiny on the part of the court see in particular association ekin cited above and éditions plon v france no echr iv that is particularly true in the case of measure to prevent the distribution of comment which are only potential at the time of adoption of the former in the present case therefore the court is concerned by the fact that when deciding to impose the impugned restriction on the applicant the sentence enforcement judge did not base his decision on the latter specific comment or writing but on potential comment or writing stating that it wa quite possible that he might be tempted to publish his memoir and make statement on the offence of which he wa convicted the court further considers it regrettable that the domestic judge neither balanced the competing interest nor fully characterised the risk of public disorder that being the case the court note that decision to apply article of the code of criminal procedure are not administrative but judicial because they are taken by the sentence enforcement judge and the convicted person in question can lodge an ordinary appeal followed by an appeal on point of law it note that the applicant availed himself of that right since he appealed to the paris court of appel against the judgment imposing the impugned obligation emphasising in particular that that obligation merely prohibited him commenting on or condoning the offence committed that it wa not a disproportionate measure in the light of the need to protect public order and that it in no way prevented him from expressing his political conviction and that he subsequently appealed on point of law to the court of cassation see paragraph and above he therefore benefited from judicial review providing genuine safeguard against abuse to which procedure the court attache great importance see association ekin cited above the court further note that the measure taken pursuant to paragraph of that article are limited in three respect they are limited with regard to the person on whom they can be imposed a they apply solely to person convicted of specific crime or offence culpable injury of life sexual assault or sexual abuse they are also limited not only in time ending at the same time a the period of release on licence but also in their purpose since they can only affect the person freedom of expression on the offence which he or she had committed in the present case moreover the paris court of appeal very clearly reiterated in it judgment of august that the restriction imposed on the applicant merely prohibited commenting on or condoning the offence committed see paragraph above it would therefore seem that contrary to his allegation the applicant retained the right to express his view on the basque question provided that he did not mention the offence of which he had been convicted when the court ass an interference with the right secured under article it also attache great importance to the limited nature of the measure adopted see for example donaldson v the united kingdom dec january furthermore the present case should also been seen in the light mutatis mutandis of the case of nilsen v the united kingdom dec no march in which relying on his freedom of expression a prisoner complained of the fact that the manuscript of his autobiography had been confiscated on the ground in particular that it had gone into detail on the crime of which he had been convicted while reiterating that prisoner in general continue to enjoy all the fundamental right and freedom guaranteed under the convention save for the right to liberty and in particular the right to freedom of expression and any restriction must be specifically justified in each case the court found that the complaint under article wa manifestly illfounded owing in particular to the fact that the impugned measure had not amounted to a complete restriction on the exercise of the right set out in that provision finally the court can not overlook the context in which the applicant freedom of expression wa restricted that is to say that the decision wa taken to restrict that right in the framework of the early release of a major wellknown figure in a terrorist organisation who had been sentenced to life imprisonment for murder committed in a terrorist context which early release a already mentioned in paragraph above had caused considerable emotion among the victim family and more broadly within the local population all these factor lead the court to accept that in imposing on the applicant in the framework of his release on licence the obligation to refrain from distributing any document or audiovisual material produced or coproduced by himself concerning in whole or in part the offence of which he wa convicted and to refrain from making any public reference to those offence the domestic court did not exceed the margin of appreciation available to them therefore there wa no violation of article of the convention for these reason the court unanimously hold that there ha been no violation of article of the convention
